questions.text: When does a secondary oocyte complete its second meiotic division to become a mature ovum?
questions.solution:
Option C: At fertilization

  • The primary oocyte is arrested in the diplotene stage of Meiosis I. Only after the luteinizing hormone surge, it will form a secondary oocyte. The secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase 2 of meiosis II
  • The secondary oocyte completes its second meiotic division to become a mature ovum at fertilization.

Option A: At ovulation

  • A secondary oocyte begins meiosis II at ovulation, but this division is arrested at metaphase.
  • The secondary oocyte will remain arrested in metaphase until a sperm penetrates it at fertilization.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the secondary oocyte degenerates.

 

Option B: Before ovulation

  • Meiosis I is a Reductional division during which the Maternal & paternal chromosomes are separated. The first polar body is released after the luteinizing hormone surge [before ovulation].
  • A Luteinizing hormone surge occurs 36 hours before ovulation, and a luteinizing hormone peak occurs 12 hours before ovulation (1 polar body released).

 

Option D: At puberty

  • The oocyte is resting in the diplotene stage of prophase I (1 Meiotic division) at the time of birth. Meiosis I completed at the time of ovulation (puberty).
  • Secondary oocyte & 1 polar body are released (at the time of ovulation). The secondary oocyte is arrested in "Metaphase II" (meiosis II) till fertilization.
  • After fertilization, 2nd polar body & ovum are released.
  • Oocytes are protected by granulosa cells, and those not protected undergo atresia.

questions.text: The sebaceous gland synthesizes and releases the sebum, protecting the skin from external factors and dehydration. It is responsible for the suppleness of hair and skin. The microscopic exocrine gland is an example of ?
questions.solution:
The correct option is: 3. Holocrine gland

Explanation of the options:

  1. Paracrine gland: Paracrine glands are glands that secrete substances that act on nearby cells, usually within the same tissue. They don't release their secretions into a duct, but rather influence neighboring cells through diffusion of their secreted molecules. An example of a paracrine gland is the pancreatic islets that secrete insulin and glucagon.

  2. Apocrine gland: Apocrine glands are a type of exocrine gland that release their secretions by pinching off a portion of their cell, along with the secretion, to form a vesicle. This vesicle is then released into a duct, which carries the secretion to the surface. Apocrine glands are found in limited areas of the body, such as the axillary and genital regions. They're responsible for producing sweat that can be acted upon by bacteria to cause body odor.

  3. Holocrine gland: Holocrine glands are a type of exocrine gland in which the entire cell becomes filled with the secretory product and then disintegrates, releasing the secretion along with cell debris. Sebaceous glands, which secrete sebum to lubricate the skin and hair, are a classic example of holocrine glands. The statement you provided about sebaceous glands is accurate, as they synthesize and release sebum, which has various protective and moisturizing functions for the skin and hair.

  4. Eccrine gland: Eccrine glands are another type of exocrine gland responsible for producing sweat, primarily for thermoregulation. These glands release their secretion directly onto the skin surface through a duct, without any destruction of the glandular cell. Eccrine glands are distributed throughout most of the body and play a vital role in controlling body temperature.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician with complaints of several episodes of dark urine over the past 3 weeks. He does not have dysuria or flank pain. He works in a factory that produces dyes. He takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 29 years and drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. His urine is pink; urinalysis shows 80 RBC/hpf but no WBCs. Cystoscopy shows a 3-cm mass in the bladder mucosa. The mass is resected. Pathologic examination shows a urothelial carcinoma with penetration into the muscular layer. The epithelium involved in the patient's pathology is present in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Membranous urethra

 

  • Membranous urethra is lined by stratified columnar epithelium.
  • This is a case of urothelial carcinoma, which involves transitional epithelium.
  • The membranous urethra is lined by stratified columnar epithelium.
  • The renal system develops from the intermediate mesoderm.
  • Intermediate mesoderm forms a major part of the genitourinary system
  • Urinary bladder and urethra: Comes from a urogenital sinus (endoderm of terminal hindgut)
  • Transitional epithelium begins at the tip of the collecting ducts and lines minor calyx - major calyx - renal pelvis - ureter - urinary bladder and proximal prostatic urethra.
  • The most male urethra is lined by stratified columnar epithelium except for the beginning and end.
  • The tip of the male urethra is lined by stratified squamous epithelium.

Option A: Minor calyx

  • The minor calyx is lined by Transitional epithelium

Option B: Renal pelvis

 

  • Major calyces join to drain the urine into renal pelvis
  • The renal pelvis is lined by Transitional epithelium

Option C: Ureter

  • The ureter is lined by Transitional epithelium

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese male presents to the hospital with a complaint of not being able to feel the bitter and sweet taste for 1 month. He has a past medical history of diabetes and hypertension for the last 6 months A medical consultant questioned a postgraduate resident that the taste pathway lies under which neural column?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Special Visceral Afferent:

  • A Special visceral afferent fiber (SVA) is an afferent fiber that develops together with the GIT tract.
  • They carry the senses of smell (olfaction) and taste (gustation).
  • The cranial nerves having SVA fibers are the olfactory nerve, the facial nerve, the glossopharyngeal nerve, and the vagus nerve.

 

  • The facial nerve receives taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, the glossopharyngeal from the posterior 1/3rd, and the vagus nerve from the epiglottis.
  • The sensory processes send projections to the medulla, from which they travel in the tractus solitarius, ending at the rostral nucleus solitarius.
  • Transmits information regarding smell and taste.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Special Somatic Afferent:

  • Special somatic afferent fibers (SSA) are the afferent nerve fibers that carry information from the special senses of vision, hearing, and balance.
  • The cranial nerves containing SSA fibers are the optic nerve (II) and the vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).
  • The term "SSA" also encompasses special somatic and visceral afferent fibers.

Option B - General Somatic Afferent:

  • The general somatic afferent fibers (GSA, or somatic sensory fibers) afferent fibers arise from neurons in sensory ganglia.
  • They are found in all the spinal nerves, except occasionally the first cervical, and conduct impulses of pain, touch, and temperature from the surface of the body through the dorsal roots to the spinal cord and impulses of muscle sense, tendon sense, and collective sense from the deeper structures.
  • Includes three sensory nuclei of CN 5.

Option D - General Visceral Afferent:

  • The general visceral afferent (GVA) fibers pass sensory impulses (commonly pain or Reflex sensations) from the glands, internal organs, and blood vessels to the CNS.
  • They are part of the visceral nervous system, which is closely related to the autonomic nervous system, but the 'visceral nervous system' and 'autonomic nervous system' are not direct synonyms, and care should be given when using these terminologies. Unlike the efferent fibers of the autonomic nervous system, the afferent fibers are not regarded as either sympathetic or parasympathetic.
  • GVA fibers create Referred pain by activating general somatic afferent fibers where the two meet in the posterior grey column.
  • The cranial nerves with GVA fibers include the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves.
  • Commonly, they are insensitive to cutting, crushing, or burning; however, excessive tension in smooth muscles and some pathological conditions create visceral pain (Referred pain).
  • Transmits General Visceral sensations like angina and colicky pain.
  • Carries information from viscera such as carotid body & sinus.

questions.text:
A surgeon has exposed the operative field for a cardio-thoracic procedure for a case of apical lung cancer and identified a few nerves in the region.



Injury to which of the marked nerves in the diagram may affect respiratory movements?
questions.solution:
Option A: A

  • The given scenario is about respiratory movements. Hence, it is the phrenic nerve(marker A).
  • The phrenic nerve arises from C3 to C5 spinal segments and joins the cervical plexus of nerves in the neck.
  • The phrenic nerve courses anterior to the scalenus anterior muscle, as shown in the diagram, and then passes behind the belly of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Then both the phrenic nerves, right and left, pass the thoracic inlet and enter the thorax to supply the diaphragm.
  • Injury to the phrenic nerve (marker ‘A’) compromises the diaphragm (and respiratory movements).
  • The labeling of the diagram in the question is shown below:

Option B: B

  • Arrow B points towards the Sympathetic chain.
  • The sympathetic chain is a ganglionated chain present bilaterally extending from the base of the skull to the coccyx.
  • It is the fundamental part of the sympathetic nervous system and a part of the autonomic nervous system.
  • It does not affect respiratory movements.

Option C: C

  • The Vagus nerve(arrow C) is the tenth cranial nerve (CN X).
  • The Vagus nerve is responsible for internal organ functions, such as digestion, heart rate, respiratory rate, vasomotor activity, and certain reflex actions, such as coughing, sneezing, swallowing, and vomiting.
  • It controls respiration rate by reflex mechanisms but does not play any role in the motor innervations responsible for respiratory movements.

Option D: D

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is a branch of the vagus nerve(marker 'D')
  • It carries fibers of sensory innervation from the larynx below the level of vocal cords. 
  • It supplies motor innervation to all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, except for the cricothyroid muscles, and has no association with regulating respiratory movements.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes in with a stab wound, cannot raise his arm horizontally, and exhibits a condition known as “winged scapula.” Which of the following structures of the brachial plexus would most likely be damaged?
questions.solution:
Option D: Roots

Winged scapula:

  • Supraspinatus supplied by the suprascapular nerve causes the first 0° to 15° arm abduction.
  • The next 15° to 90° arm abduction is caused by the Deltoid muscle supplied by the axillary nerve.
  • Beyond 90°, the abduction of the arm is done by Trapezius and Serratus anterior muscles supplied by the accessory and long thoracic nerves, respectively.
  • Serratus anterior is innervated by the long thoracic nerve by the nerve roots C5, C6, and C7.
  • It protracts (draws forward) the scapula as a prime mover in all reaching and pushing movements.
  • The upper part with the levator scapulae and the upper fibers of the trapezius suspends the scapula. The more extensive lower insertion pulls the inferior scapular angle forwards around the thorax, assisting the trapezius in the upward rotation of the bone (an action essential to raise the arm above the head).
  • In the initial stages of abduction, the serratus anterior helps other muscles to fix the scapula so that the deltoid acts effectively on the humerus and not the scapula.
  • While the deltoid raises the arm to a right angle with the scapula, the serratus anterior and trapezius are simultaneously rotating the scapula, thus raising the arm to be vertical.
  • Serratus Anterior is responsible for the latter part of abduction along with the trapezius.
  • The long thoracic nerve (Nerve of Bell) originates from the C5–C7 roots and descends in the axilla, posterior to the brachial plexus, to innervate the serratus anterior muscle.
  • Serratus palsy is usually a preganglionic injury to the C5, C6, and C7 nerve roots. When the serratus anterior is paralyzed, the medial border of the scapula and especially its lower angle stand out prominently. The arm cannot be raised fully. Pushing is ineffective; indeed, attempts to do so produce further projection known as winging.
  • Winged scapula is caused by paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle that results from damage to the long thoracic nerve, which arises from the roots of the brachial plexus (C5–C7)
  • The long thoracic nerve is frequently injured during operations around the first rib, in the posterior triangle, in the axilla, and by misplaced intercostal drains.

Option A: Medial cord

  • Medial cord: Anterior division of the Lower trunk continues as a medial cord
  • The nerve involved is the ulnar nerve

Option B: Posterior cord

  • The posterior division of the Upper, Middle and Lower trunk joins to form the Posterior Cord
  • The nerve involved is the Radial nerve

Option C: Lower trunk

  • Lower Trunk: C8 & T1 roots join to form the lower trunk
  • Winged scapula is caused by injury to the C5-C7

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true about the brachial plexus?

A. Lower trunk is formed by root C8 and T1

B. Lateral cord is formed by the upper and middle trunk

C. Posterior cord is formed by posterior divisions of all three trunks

D. Anterior division of the lower trunk continuous as medial cord and give rise to the radial nerve.
questions.solution:
Option D:  A, B & C only

Brachial plexus:

  • It may also receive contributions from the fourth cervical and the second thoracic spinal nerves.
  • The upper limb's muscle, joints, and skin are innervated by the ventral primary rami of C5, C6, C7, and C8, and nearly all of the ventral primary ramus from T1, collectively forming the brachial plexus.
  • The proportion of motor fibers is greatest in C5 and C8; the sensory contribution is greatest in C7.
  • A complex interchange of branches before the main nerves of the upper limb has formed the trunks, divisions, and cords.
  • The C5 and C6 form the upper trunk. The middle trunk is the continuation of C7. C8 and T1 form the lower trunk.
  • The trunks divide into anterior and posterior divisions.
  • The cords are formed by the confluence of divisions: the lateral cord from the anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunk; the posterior cord by all three posterior divisions; and the medial cord by the anterior division of the lower trunk and sometimes by a branch from the anterior division of the middle trunks.
  • Contribution by C4 to the brachial plexus is pre-fixed brachial plexus, not post-fixed to plexus.
  • Post-fixed brachial plexus has a contribution by T2.

 Option A:B only

  • The brachial plexus lies in the posterior triangle of the neck, at the angle between the clavicle and the lower posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.
  • It emerges between the scaleni anterior and medius, superior to the third part of the subclavian artery.
  • It is covered by platysma, deep the roots and trunks of the brachial plexus can be represented by a line passing between the middle of the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid and the middle of the clavicle.

 Option B: B & C

  • The brachial plexus is formed by the union of the ventral rami of the lower four cervical nerves and the greater part of the ventral ramus of the first thoracic spinal nerve.

 Option C:A, B & C only

  • The lower trunk is formed by roots C8 and T1
  • The lateral cord is formed by the upper and middle trunk
  • The posterior cord is formed by posterior divisions of all three trunks

questions.text: A 7-day-old male infant presents with worsening respiratory distress for 3 days. Examination reveals tachypnea, increased work of breathing, and decreased breath sounds on the left side of the chest. Chest X-ray shows left-sided herniation of abdominal organs. What statements are true regarding the involved structure?

choices.text: Spleen and intestines enter the thoracic cavity.

questions.solution:
Option B: Left crus is attaching to L1 and L2 only

  • This is a case of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
  • Right crus is longer than left crus
    • Right crus attaching to L1, L2, and L3 anteriorly
    • Left crus is attaching to L1, L2 only
    • Right crus connected to Left crus by Median (midline) arcuate ligament.
    • Esophagus passes through muscular fibers of the Right crus of the diaphragm at T10.
  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is of the following 2 types:

Bochdalek hernia:

Morgagni hernia
  • Usually left sided
  • It is a congenital diaphragmatic hernia
  • Deficiency in the left pleuroperitoneal cavity
  • Left lung hypoplasia
  • The right lung is also compressed
  • Cyanosis at birth
  • NEONATAL EMERGENCY
  • Mostly on the right side
  • Antero-medial & Retrosternal
  • Transverse colon herniates in front of the heart.
  • Less common
  • than Bochdalek hernia

 

Option A: Right crus is attaching to L3, L4 and L5 anteriorly

  • Right crus is attached to L1, L2, and L3 anteriorly.

Option C: Esophagus passes through muscular fibers of the Left crus of the diaphragm at T10

  • Esophagus passes through muscular fibers of the Right crus of the diaphragm at T10.

Option D: Left crus is longer than right crus

  •  The right crus is normally longer than the left crus.

questions.text: The letter C in the diagram below represents which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Option B: Quadratus femoris

  • Under the cover of the Gluteus Maximus, a Quadrangular Muscle attached to the femur bone is called Quadratus Femoris.

Quadratus femoris:

  • The quadratus femoris is a flat, square-shaped muscle.
  • It is the most inferior of the deep gluteal muscles, located below the Gemelli and obturator internus.
  • Attachments: It originates from the lateral side of the ischial tuberosity and attaches to the quadrate tuberosity on the intertrochanteric crest.
  • Actions: Lateral rotation.
  • Innervation: Nerve to quadratus femoris.

Option A: Gluteus minimus

  • The muscle listed as A is the gluteus minimus.
  • weak flexion and  medially rotation of hip.
  • lateral stablization of knee.
  • The superior gluteal nerve supplies it.

Option C: Gluteus medius

  • The muscle marked as A is the gluteus medius
  • Abducts and medially rotates the lower limb.
  • During locomotion, it secures the pelvis, preventing the pelvic drop.The superior gluteal nerve supplies it.

Option D: Gluteus maximus

  • The muscle marked as D is the gluteus maximus
  • It is the main Extensor of the thigh and assists with lateral rotation.
  • However, it is only used when force is required, such as running or climbing.
  • The inferior gluteal nerve supplies it.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the clinic due to numbness and tingling in the right lower extremity for the past 2 weeks. On examination, the muscle strength of right hip flexors is 3/5 compared to left hip flexors, which are 5/5. When the hammer strikes the right knee, no movement is seen. Which of the following muscles is responsible for the reflex movement of the knee?
questions.solution:
Option A: Quadriceps femoris

  • The patella (a sesamoid bone) develops within the tendon of the quadriceps femoris muscle.
  • When the reflex hammer strikes the patellar ligament, reflex contraction of the quadriceps femoris muscles and extension of the knee occurs, called the patellar reflex.
  • The femoral nerve is responsible for eliciting this reflex arc.
  • The patellar reflex is a deep tendon reflex mediated by the spinal nerves from the levels L3, and L4 in the spinal cord, predominantly in the root L4
  • Femoral nerve supplies quadriceps femoris (rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, medialis, and intermedius), which are the major knee extensors.
  • It also supplies the hip flexors, which include the pectineus, iliacus, and sartorius.
  • Sensory supply is to the anteromedial thigh via the anterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh and the medial side of the leg and foot via the saphenous nerve.

Option B: Quadratus femoris

  • The quadratus femoris is a flat, square-shaped muscle.
  • It is the most inferior of the deep gluteal muscles, located below the Gemelli and obturator internus.
  • It is supplied by the nerve to the quadratus femoris.
  • It is responsible for adduction and external rotation of the thigh
  • It does not extend the knee in the patellar reflex.

Option C: Sartorius

  • The sartorius muscle is a thin, long, superficial muscle in the anterior compartment of the thigh.
  • It is the longest muscle in the human body.
  • The femoral nerve supplies it.
  • It helps in hip and knee flexion.
  • It has no role in knee extension and patellar reflex.

Option D: Pectineus

  • The pectineus is a flat muscle found in the superomedial part of the anterior thigh.
  • It is responsible for flexion and adduction of the thigh at the hip joint.
  • It has no role in the extension of the knee.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the anatomical relations of the rectum?

choices.text: There are two rectal folds on the left
The anorectal junction is related to the puborectalis muscle
The upper 1/3 is entirely invested in the peritoneum
The lower third of the rectum has no peritoneal covering

questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: The upper 1/3 is entirely invested in the peritoneum

  • The upper 1/3 of the rectum is covered by the peritoneum at the front and sides only. The peritoneal covering is deficient posteriorly.

Option A: There are two rectal folds on the left

  • The rectal folds are the internal marking of the flexures of the rectum.
  • There are 2 rectal folds on the left side. So, this statement is correct about the anatomy of the rectum.
  • The rectal folds, or rectal valves of Houston, are the internal marking of the lateral curves or flexures of the rectum.
    • There are two rectal folds on the left (2nd and 4th).
    • They are usually three rectal folds; sometimes a fourth is found, and occasionally only two are present, and numbered from above downward are as follows:
      • The first fold (or superior fold) Is at the commencement of the rectum, distal to the rectosigmoid junction. It projects from the right (or left wall) and may occasionally encircle the rectal lumen.
      • Second fold projects from the left rectal wall along the concavity of upper lateral curvature. It lies opposite the middle of the rectum.
      • The third fold is the largest and most constant and lies immediately above the rectal ampulla. It projects from the anterior and right wall just below the level of the anterior peritoneal reflection, along the concavity of middle lateral curvature. It has prominent circular muscles.
      • The fourth (inferior) fold is the most variable and projects from the left wall of the rectum along the concavity of lower lateral curvature. It lies about 2.5 cm above the anus.

Option B: The anorectal junction is related to the puborectalis muscle

  • The puborectalis muscle, the innermost fibers of the levator ani, slings around the anorectal junction and pulls it anteriorly, helping to maintain fecal continence.

Option D: The lower third of the rectum has no peritoneal covering

  • The middle third of the rectum is covered with the peritoneum at the front, while the lower third has no peritoneal covering.

questions.text: Secondary ossification centre appears before birth at (FMGE / DNB Pattern)
Which one of the following is present in both Serum and Plasma?
questions.solution:
Option B: Factor VII

  • Factor VII is present in plasma and is also stable in serum (“Noble factor”).
  • It is a part of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation
  • It is also known as Proconvertin.
  • A deficiency of factor VII is a rare disorder.

PLASMA:

  • Plasma, also known as blood plasma, appears light-yellowish or straw-colored. It serves as the liquid base for whole blood.
  • Whole blood minus erythrocytes (RBCs), leukocytes (WBCs), and thrombocytes (platelets) makes up plasma
  • Serum, sometimes mistakenly synonymous with plasma, consists of plasma without fibrinogen.
  • Plasma contains 91% to 92% of water and 8% to 9% of solids.
  • It comprises:
    1. Coagulants, mainly fibrinogen, helps in blood clotting
    2. Plasma proteins, such as albumin and globulin, it helps to maintain the colloidal osmotic pressure at about 25 mmHg
    3. Electrolytes like sodium, potassium, bicarbonate, chloride, and calcium helps to maintain blood pH
    4. Immunoglobulins helps to fight infection and various other lesser amounts of enzymes, hormones, and vitamins

Option A: Fibrinogen

This is false because:

  • Factor I (Fibrinogen) is deficient in serum.

Option C: Factor V

This is false because:

  • Factor V (Labile/Proaccelerin) is deficient in serum.

Option D: Factor II

This is false because:

  • Factor II (Prothrombin) is deficient in serum.

questions.text: Which of the following Pulmonary function changes is not seen in emphysema?
questions.solution:
Option C: ↑ FEV1

  • Emphysema is a disease characterized by dilation of the alveolar spaces and destruction of the alveolar walls.
  • With their loss, much of the lung's elastic recoil is also lost.
  • To perform spirometry, the patient takes the biggest breath possible and blows it out as fast as possible. This is called a forced exhalation maneuver.
  • During this procedure, the total volume of air the patient can exhale in one breath is measured; this is the FVC.
  • The amount of air that the patient can exhale in the first second is also measured; this is the FEV1.
  • Each is measured in litre and is reported as a per cent predicted for that patient.
  • The per cent predicted is based on reference values that consider the patient's age, sex and race.
  • The FVC is a measure of the amount of air the lungs hold. The FEV1 is a measure of how easily air flows through the lungs. 
  • FEV1 and FVC =reduced in emphysema.
  • Compliance of the lung in emphysema is significantly above normal; the lung becomes easy to distend but empties slowly.
  • This results in a chronically overinflated lung (high total lung capacity, functional residual capacity, and residual volume), which lessens the curvature of the diaphragm, making it less efficient in generating even the small swings in pleural pressure necessary for breathing.
  • Pulmonary function tests on a patient with emphysema will reveal a compromised expiratory flow (due to their low lung recoil), including a low FEV1, FVC, and FEV1/FVC ratio.

Option A: ↑ TLC

  • Emphysema increases airway resistance & work of breathing difficulty in exhaling air due to compression of bronchioles leading to the eventual increase of TLC (barrel chest).

Option B: ↑ RV

  • Emphysema increases airway resistance & work of breathing difficulty in exhaling air due to compression of bronchioles, leading to an eventual increase in RV.

Option D: ↑ ΔV/ΔP

  • Destruction of alveolar septa leads to an increase in compliance (C= ΔV/ΔP)

questions.text: The most common cause of hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis is GI loss, which includes diarrhea or laxative use. Which of the following condition is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension and undetectable aldosterone levels?
questions.solution:
Option A: Liddle's syndrome

  • Dysfunction of sodium channels leads to Liddle's syndrome
  • Liddle's syndrome, also known as pseudohyperaldosteronism, is a rare, autosomal dominant cause of secondary hypertension.
  • Liddle's syndrome mimics the symptoms of mineralocorticoid excess, causing hypokalemia, hypertension, and metabolic alkalosis.
  • There are suppressed aldosterone and renin levels.

Disease

Phenotype

Proximal renal tubular acidosis (RTA)

Na+/HCO3-symporte

  1. Na+/K+/2Cl - symporter
  2. ROMK potassium channel
  3. chloride channel [basolateral membrane] or barttin protein necessary for the normal functioning of this channel

  2. H+ - ATPase

 

Collecting ducy

Metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, nephrolithiasis

METABOLIC ACIDOSIS VS METABOLIC ALKALOSIS

  • Metabolic acidosis is the acid-base imbalance characterized by excess accumulation of organic acids in the body, which is caused by abnormal metabolic processes. Organic acids such as lactic acid, ketoacidosis, and uric acid are formed by normal metabolism. The quantity of these acids increases due to abnormality in the metabolism.
  • Metabolic alkalosis is the acid-base imbalance caused by the loss of excess H+ resulting in increased HCO3– concentration. Some endocrine disorders, renal tubular disorders, etc., cause metabolic disorders leading to loss of H+. It increases HCO3– and pH in the body leading to metabolic alkalosis.

Option B: Bartter syndrome

  • Bartter syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by a defect in the thick ascending segment. It causes decreased sodium and water reabsorption resulting in loss of sodium and water through urine.

Option C: Gitelman syndrome

  • Gitelman syndrome(GS) is an AR kidney tubule disorder.
  • It is characterized by low blood levels of K+ and magnesium, decreased excretion of calcium in the urine, and elevated blood pH.

Option D: Renal tubular acidosis

  • Renal tubular acidosis due to decreased H+ excretion
  • It is associated with metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Which substance enhances the sensitivity of pain receptors but does not directly excite them?
questions.solution:
Option D: Prostaglandins

  • Prostaglandins enhance the sensitivity of pain receptors but do not actually excite them.

Option A: Bradykinin

  • Bradykinin is a molecule produced by enzymes at the site of an injury and then binds to receptors to cause pain. Bradykinin makes nerves more sensitive to pain.

Option B: Serotonin

  • Serotonin is an inhibitory substance and Inhibits impulses of pain sensation in the posterior grey horn of the spinal cord.

Option C: Potassium ions

  • Some of the chemicals that excite the chemical type of pain are bradykinin, serotonin, histamine, potassium ions, acids, acetylcholine, and proteolytic enzymes. Prostaglandins & substance P are believed to enhance the sensitivity of pain receptors but do not actually excite them.

Learning Objective

  • Prostaglandins & substance P are believed to enhance the sensitivity of pain receptors but do not actually excite them.
  • Some of the chemicals that excite the chemical type of pain receptors include bradykinin, serotonin, histamine, potassium ions, acids, acetylcholine, and proteolytic enzymes. In addition, prostaglandins enhance the sensitivity of pain endings but do not directly excite them.
  • Bradykinin:
    • Dilates the blood vessels and decreases the blood pressure. It is considered a potent vasodilator.
    • Increases the blood flow throughout the body by its vasodilator action.
    • Increases permeability of capillaries during inflammatory conditions, resulting in edema in the affected area.
    • Stimulates pain receptors.
    • Causes contraction of extravascular smooth muscles, especially smooth muscles of the intestine.
  • Serotonin:
    • Is an inhibitory substance.
    • Inhibits impulses of pain sensation in the posterior grey horn of the spinal cord.
    • Causes mood depression and induces sleep.
    • Causes vasoconstriction.

questions.text: During exercise, with elevated levels of adenosine and lactate in actively contracting muscles, which factor exhibits an inverse proportionality to peripheral vascular resistance?
questions.solution:
Option A: Radius of the vessel

  • The patient, in this case, is an athlete whose peripheral vascular resistance is studied.
  • In this case, adenosine and lactate are metabolites produced by the skeletal muscle cells in response to hypoxia (e.g., during exercise).
  • These local metabolites cause local vasodilation to increase blood flow to tissues.
  • According to the Poiseuille-Hagen equation: (for the flow of a fluid in a rigid cylindrical tube)
  • Q = P × (πr4/8ηl)
    • Q = flow, P (or P1 – P2) = pressure difference between two points,
    • r = radius of the tube, η = viscosity of the fluid, and
    • l = length of the tube.
  • By Ohm’s law: Q = P/R; OR R = P/Q. {R = resistance}
  • Thus, viscous resistance (R) can be given by combining the above two formulas:
    • R = (8ηl)/(πr4)
  • Thus, viscous resistance is
    • Directly proportional to the fluid's viscosity (η) and the length (l) of the tube
    • Inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius of the tube (blood vessel).

Option B: Viscosity of blood

  • Peripheral vascular resistance is directly proportional to the viscosity of the fluid.
  • The greater the blood viscosity, the slower the blood flow will be
  • The lesser the viscosity faster will be the flow of blood.

Option C: Length of the vessel

  • Peripheral vascular resistance is directly proportional to the length of the vessel.
  • The blood takes a greater length of the vessel to reach the periphery.
  • The shorter the vessel shorter will be the time the blood takes to reach the periphery.

Option D: Elasticity of the vessel

  • Peripheral vascular resistance has no uniform proportion with the elasticity of the vessels.
  • However, the vessel wall's elasticity is the vessel's ability to regain its regular shape after each compression and stretch.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about gastric secretion?

choices.text: Gastric phase accounts for 80% of gastric secretion
Enterochromaffin-like cells in gastric mucosa secrete somatostatin
Trefoil peptides prevent erosion of gastric mucosa by gastric acid
Daily gastric secretion is approximately 1.0 L

questions.solution:
Option C: Trefoil peptides prevent erosion of gastric mucosa by gastric acid

  • Trefoil peptides (TTF) are 40 amino acids peptides related to mucin-associated secretory molecules mediating many physiological roles that maintain and restore gastrointestinal mucosal homeostasis.
  • The surface cells of gastric mucosa secrete primarily mucus and bicarbonate.
  • This protects the stomach from digesting itself, as well as substances, are known as trefoil peptides that stabilize the mucus bicarbonate layer.
  • TTF is constitutively expressed in the gastrointestinal tract and is involved in defense and repair by promoting epithelial restitution.
  • Damage to these proteins causes erosions and even ulcers in the stomach.

Option A: Gastric phase accounts for 80% of gastric secretion

  • The gastric phase accounts for 60% of gastric secretion.

Option B: Enterochromaffin-like cells in gastric mucosa secrete somatostatin

  • Enterochromaffin-like cells in gastric mucosa secrete Histamine.

Option D: Daily gastric secretion is approximately 1.0 L

  • Gastric secretion 1.5-2.5 L/day

  • C fibre is unmyelinated and has the smallest diameter of any fibre type.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presented in emergency with respiratory depression and heightened awareness followed by painful muscular spasms a few hours after accidental ingestion of a rodenticide. Which of the following inhibitory neurotransmitters is affected by the pesticide present in the rodenticide?
questions.solution:
Option B: Glycine

  • Previously strychnine was available in pill form to treat many human ailments. It is used primarily as a pesticide, particularly to kill rats. It is also rarely found mixed with LSD, heroin, and cocaine.
  • The plant alkaloid strychnine blocks inhibitory glycine receptors (glycine is the inhibitory neuro-transmitter) 
  • The inhibitory control of the glycerine is lost resulting in tetany and muscular contraction (due to over-excitation).
  • It occurs because glycine normally activates chloride ion conductance resulting in a hyperpolarisation of the neuronal membrane and antagonism of other depolarising stimuli.
  • Symptoms usually appear within 15 to 60 minutes after ingestion. These include agitation, restlessness, painful muscle spasms, uncontrollable arching of the neck and back, rigid arms and legs, jaw tightness, muscle pain and soreness, difficulty breathing, dark urine, initial consciousness, and awareness of symptoms. Seizures can lead to lactic acidosis, hyperthermia, and rhabdomyolysis. Moreover, the paralysis of neural pathways that control breathing can lead to respiratory failure and death.

Option A: GABA

  • GABA mediates the majority of inhibitory synaptic actions in the CNS. It is formed from glutamate by the enzyme glutamic acid decarboxylase. High-affinity uptake systems terminate the actions of GABA in neurons and glia. GABA is released from the synaptic vesicles in a Ca++-dependent manner upon depolarisation of the presynaptic membrane
  • There are two types of receptors: the GABAa receptor increases chloride conductance and is the site of action of benzodiazepines and barbiturates, while the GABA-b receptor increases K+ conductance.

Option C: Substance P

  • It belongs to the neuropeptide family and acts as a neurotransmitter and neuromodulator.
  • Substance P is a potent vasodilator, and this function is dependent on nitric oxide release. It is also released as a local inflammatory response to certain types of infection or injury.
  • It is an important element in pain perception. Inhibition of the release of substance P is the basis for pain relief in opioids.

Option D: Aspartate

  • It is the excitatory neurotransmitter in the CNS that stimulates NMDA receptors. It is primarily present in the anterior spinal cord.
  • It opens as an ion channel and is inactivated by reabsorption into the presynaptic membrane.
  • It is an essential amino acid that does not cross the blood-brain barrier.

questions.text: Which of the following results in increased ADH activity?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hypovolemia

  • ADH is the anti-diuretic hormone that increases the permeability of the collecting ducts of the kidney so that water enters the hypertonic interstitium of the renal pyramids.
  • It acts through the G-protein-coupled receptors:
    • V1A in blood vessels: causes vasoconstriction via IP3-Ca2+ pathway
    • V1B in anterior pituitary: causes ACTH release via IP3-Ca2+ pathway
    • V2 in the late distal tubule and collecting duct: increases expression of aquaporin-2 and urea transporters at basolateral membrane via the cAMP pathway.
  • The urine becomes concentrated, and its volume decreases. The overall effect is the retention of water in excess of the solute; consequently, the effective osmotic pressure of the body fluids is decreased.
  • The table below shows the stimuli affecting the ADH (Vasopressin) secretion:

Vasopressin Secretion Increased

Vasopressin Secretion Decreased

Increased effective osmotic pressure of plasma Decreased ECF volume

Pain, emotion, "stress", exercise Nausea and vomiting

Standing

Clofibrate, carbamazepine

Angiotensin II

Decreased effective osmotic pressure of plasma

Increased ECF volume

Alcohol

 
  • One stimulus causing intense ADH secretion is decreased blood (ECF) volume. This occurs strongly when the blood volume decreases 15 to 25 percent or more.
  • ADH is considerably more sensitive to small changes in osmolarity than to similar percentage changes in blood volume.

Option A: Hypervolemia

  • As shown in the table above, an increased blood (ECF) volume occurs in hypervolemia, resulting in decreased secretion of ADH

Option B: Hypertension

  • There is an inverse relationship between the rate of vasopressin secretion and the rate of discharge in afferents from stretch receptors in the low and high-pressure portions of the vascular system.
  • The exponential increases in plasma vasopressin produced by decreases in blood pressure are shown in the image below.

 

  • As shown in the image, the release of ADH increases exponentially with a percentage decrease in mean arterial blood pressure. As in hypertension, the percentage change in mean arterial blood pressure increases; therefore, the ADH secretion decreases.

Option D: Decreased osmolarity

  • ADH secretion is increased in response to an increased plasma osmolarity. Therefore, a decreased plasma osmolarity will result in a decreased secretion of ADH.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of penile erection?

choices.text: Reflex sympathetic action on the arterioles
Parasympathetic impulses cause dilatation of arterioles
Reflex parasympathetic activity on the venules

questions.solution:
Option B: Parasympathetic impulses causes dilatation of arterioles

  • Penile erection is associated with sexual arousal caused by sexually related psychic and/or physical stimuli. During sexual arousal, signals from the genitalia and signals from the limbic system elicit motor impulses in the spinal cord.
  • The sacral parasympathetic fibers convey these impulses from the spinal cord, via the cavernous nerve branches of the prostatic plexus, into the penis. These signals cause smooth muscle relaxation of the corpora cavernosa and dilatation of the arterioles.
  • The transmitter responsible for relaxing the smooth muscle of the cavernosa and arterioles is nitric oxide (NO).

Option A: Reflex sympathetic action on the arterioles

  • The sacral parasympathetic fibers convey impulses from the spinal cord, via the cavernous nerve branches of the prostatic plexus, into the penis. These signals cause smooth muscle relaxation of the corpora cavernosa and dilatation of the arterioles leading to penile erection.

Option C: Reflex sympathetic activity on venules

  • The sacral parasympathetic fibers convey impulses from the spinal cord, via the cavernous nerve branches of the prostatic plexus, into the penis. These signals cause smooth muscle relaxation of the corpora cavernosa and dilatation of the arterioles leading to penile erection.

Option D: Reflex parasympathetic activity on the venules

  • The sacral parasympathetic fibers convey impulses from the spinal cord, via the cavernous nerve branches of the prostatic plexus, into the penis. These signals cause smooth muscle relaxation of the corpora cavernosa and dilatation of the arterioles leading to penile erection.

questions.text: Which of the following ions is involved in sound transduction by the Organ of Corti?
questions.solution:
• The organ of Corti consists of hair cells, the receptors for transduction.
  • Hair cells are surrounded by endolymph.
  • Endolymph has a rich concentration of K+.
  • Basilar fiber vibration, caused by pressure in the sound wave, leads to shearing between the tectorial membrane and the reticular lamina. It causes bending of stereocilia (at the top of hair cells), resulting in the opening of the K+ channels at the base of the hair cells.
  • The hair cells are depolarized by the influx of K+.
  • It leads to the release of the transmitter by the hair cell at its base where it synapses with the VIII nerve fiber.
  • Impulses are then sent to the VIIIth nerve.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents to the pediatrics outpatient department with the complaint of seizures for the past 6 months. On EEG, a variety of waveforms appear. Among them, alpha waves are also seen. Which of the following conditions is characterized by the alpha waves?
questions.solution:
ANSWER OPTION A: AWAKE WITH EYES CLOSED

  • Electroencephalography (EEG) shows the electrical activity in the brain during different states of the sleep-wake cycle.
  • These activities are represented in different waveforms.

  • Alpha waves are generated with eyes closed and mind wandering in thoughts
  • Mostly recorded from the occipital region, and their frequency is 8 to 12Hz

OPTION B: RAPID EYE MOVEMENT sleep

  • It is a false statement, as this phase is characterized by beta waves (β) which are high frequency and low amplitude waves.

 

  • There is a loss of motor tone in this phase.
  • Usually, nightmares, dreaming, and penile or clitoral tumescence occur in this phase.

OPTION C: NON-RAPID EYE MOVEMENT sleep

  • Q-waves characterize this phase of sleep.
  • Non-rapid eye movements occur during sleep.
  • They are further divided into N1, N2, and N3 phases
  • It includes deep sleep in which bruxism (teeth grinding) and sleepwalking occurs

 

OPTION D: AWAKE WITH EYES OPEN

  • This phase is characterized by full alertness with eyes wide open and active mental connections. 
  • Beta waves are recorded in this phase from the parietal-frontal region
  • They are of 15-30Hz

questions.text: A 28-year-old male athlete training for a marathon race is advised by his coach to increase his carbohydrate intake after the workout. The carbohydrate uptake will help to build up glycogen stores in the muscles. Glycogen synthase is the main enzyme involved in glycogen synthesis in the muscles. Which of the following acts as an activator of muscle glycogen synthase?
questions.solution:
Option C: Insulin

  • Glycogen synthesis (glycogenesis) in the resting muscle is an anabolic process.
  • Insulin is an anabolic hormone and therefore increases the rate of the anabolic pathways.
  • Insulin increases the activity of muscle glycogen synthase after the intake of carbohydrates & increases glycogen reserves in the liver & muscles.
  • It acts by cAMP-mediated dephosphorylation of glycogen synthase 
  • Simultaneously, it also decreases glycogen phosphorylase activity, thereby decreasing glycogenolysis.

Option A: Epinephrine

  • Epinephrine is a catabolic hormone.
  • It is released in the fasting state.
  • It will decrease glycogen synthesis by inhibiting glycogen synthase.
  • It will increase glycogenolysis.

Option B: Glucagon

  • Glucagon also is a catabolic hormone.
  • It is released mainly in the fasting state to promote glycogenolysis and suppress glycogenesis

Option D: cAMP

  • Phosphorylation of anabolic enzymes such as glycogen synthase and fatty acid synthase is carried out by cAMP.
  • The phosphorylated state of glycogen synthase is inactive, and glycogen formation is suppressed.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true about the rate-limiting enzyme of gluconeogenesis?

choices.text: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is an allosteric activator of this enzyme

questions.solution:
Option B: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is an allosteric activator of this enzyme

  • The rate-limiting enzyme of gluconeogenesis is fructose-1-6-bisphosphatase.
  • It converts fructose-1-6-bisphosphate to fructose-6-phosphate.
  • It is regulated by fructose-2,6-bisphosphate, which is produced from fructose-6-phosphate by the enzyme PFK-II (phosphofructokinase-II) in the fed state.
  • Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is a potent allosteric activator of PFK-1 and increases glycolysis.
  • Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate, is also an allosteric inhibitor of fructose-1-6-bisphosphatase and acts by reducing its affinity for its substrate and hence decreasing gluconeogenesis (see fig below).

Option A: Key glucogenic enzyme

  • It is a key glucogenic enzyme because it favors gluconeogenesis.
  • It is one of the three enzymes of gluconeogenesis that are different from glycolysis enzymes.

Option C: Catalyzes the hydrolysis reaction

  • Fructose 1,6 bisphosphatase is a hydrolase that catalyzes the removal of Pi from fructose 1,6-bisphosphate to form fructose 6-P by adding H2O.

Options D: Requires magnesium for the catalysis

  • This enzyme is an Mg2+ dependent hydrolase (usually kinase requires Mg2+).

questions.text:
Arrange the following gluconeogenesis enzymes in the correct sequence:


	Pyruvate carboxylase
	Glucose-6-phosphatase
	Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase
	Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase
questions.solution:
Option B: 1→3→4→2

  • All enzymes given in the question are used to bypass the irreversible steps of glycolysis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the clinic with delayed milestones, hypotonia, and growth retardation. Physical examination reveals depigmented grey and brittle kinky hair. Blood and urine examinations showed lower Cu levels than normal. Which of the following enzyme is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lysyl oxidase

Menke Disease:

  • XR disease due to Cu deficiency
  • Deficient production of Cu binding P-type ATPase ATP7A in the intestine (Cu stays in intestinal cells, unable to enter blood)

Clinical features:

  • ↓ Cu in blood and urine,
  • ↓ cp (ceruloplasmin)
  • Mental retardation, hypotonia, growth retardation, and premature birth
  • Presents in infancy, death usually by 3 years
  • As tyrosinase is affected, which forms melanin, so the patient has grey depigmented hair
  • As lysyl oxidase is affected, so defective collagen leads to brittle kinky hair

Option B: Prolyl hydroxylase

  • This enzyme hydroxylate proline residue in collagen fibril posttranslationally.
  • It requires Vitamin C as cofactor so, the deficiency of vitamin C leads to scurvy.

Option C: Lysyl hydroxylase

  • This enzyme hydroxylate Lysine residue in collagen fibril posttranslationally.
  • This enzyme requires Iron and vitamin C, so, deficiency of these two leads to defective collagen synthesis and scurvy.

Option D: Amino acid decarboxylase

  • These enzyme cause removal of CO2 from amino acid to form amine derivative. This requires vitamin B6.
  • The deficiency of vitamin B6 would lead to defective metabolism of the steps catalyzed by decarboxylases, aminotransferases, and cystathionine beta-synthase.

questions.solution:
POLYMERASE CHAIN REACTION

Components of PCR

questions.text: Which of the following metabolites of cholesterol biosynthesis can accumulate in a patient on long-term statin therapy?
questions.solution:
Option C: HMG-CoA

  • Statins inhibit the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, which reduces HMG-CoA to mevalonic acid. Therefore, HMG-CoA would be the metabolite that accumulates. It is important to note that this is the rate-limiting step in cholesterol biosynthesis.

Option A: Acetoacetyl-CoA

  • Option A is wrong as acetoacetyl-CoA would accumulate if HMG-CoA synthase were inhibited.

Option B: Mevalonate

  • Option B is wrong because statins do not inhibit phosphomevalonate kinase.

Option D: Squalene

  • Option D is wrong because statins do not inhibit squalene monooxygenase.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient is diagnosed with Alport syndrome. Further testing would reveal a defect in which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
• In Alport syndrome, There is defect in type IV collagen that changes composition of the basement membrane kidney glomeruli.
  • Due to absence of a function basement membrane, the kidneys are unable in properly filtering waste products from blood and both proteins and blood can enter the urine.
  • Type IV collagen is also found in inner ear so it is important for hearing and for the eye.
  • A mutation in α1-antitrypsin will lead to emphysema, mutations in fibrillin lead to Marfan syndrome, and mutations in β-myosin heavy chain can lead to FHC (Familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy)

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids has more than one chiral carbon atom?
questions.solution:
All amino acids have 1 asymmetric or chiral C (means this C has all 4 valencies occupied by different atoms or group of atoms)

EXCEPTIONS:

  • 0 → Glycine (So it lacks chirality. Hence glycine won’t show any optical activity)
  • 2 → Isoleucine, Threonine (double chiral carbons)

questions.text: Which of the following is the precursor of the deficient pigment in patients with albinism?
questions.solution:
Option D: Tyrosine

  • The shortage of Melanin, the primary pigment of the skin and eyes, is the cause of albinism.
  • Tyrosine is converted into melanin by melanocytes in the melanosome, an intracellular membrane-bound organelle.

  • Lack of melanin synthesis due to deficiency of enzyme tyrosinase, certain hereditary melanosome defects, or issues with melanocyte migration can all contribute to albinism.
  • Primary albinism can be localized or generalized clinically. Primary widespread albinism may manifest as cutaneous, ocular, or both.
  • Hypopigmentation in generalized oculocutaneous albinism can be either full or partial.
  • Complete albinos don't develop either widespread skin pigmentation (tanning) or localized skin pigmentation (pigmented nevi).
  • Because early actinic keratoses and squamous cell carcinoma are frequent occurrences in these people, treatment in all cases focuses on UV protection.

Option A: Histidine

  • Histidine forms histamine.
  • Histamine is a substance involved in an allergic response.
  • Patients with Wilson's disease have extremely low levels of 3-methylhistidine in their urine.

Option B: Tryptophan

  • Tryptophan is converted into serotonin.
  • Serotonin is a potent vasoconstrictor.
  • The low serotonin level in the brain can leads to depression.
  • The overproduction of serotonin in carcinoid syndrome results in low tryptophan levels.

Option C: Methionine

  • It is a source of the methyl group in the body once converted into S-adenosylmethionine.
  • A low level can result in the stoppage of reactions that require methyl groups, such as the maturation of DNA and RNA.
  • Homocystinuria type II is associated with a low level of methionine due to defect in methionine synthase.

questions.text: A 39-year-old female comes to the emergency department experiencing weakness in the upper bilateral extremities, and diffuse abdominal pain for the past two days. Examination shows bilateral loss of the biceps and triceps tendon reflexes. Lab analysis shows elevated levels of porphobilinogen and aminolevulinic acid in the blood. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Acute intermittent porphyria

  • This patient with bilateral limb weakness and acute diffuse abdominal pain for two days likely has acute intermittent porphyria.
  • This disease is an autosomal dominant disorder with a very low penetrance, caused by the deficiency of porphobilinogen deaminase, also known as uroporphyrinogen I synthase.
  • Common causes include tobacco, fasting, surgery, severe illness, alcohol, and some medications, e.g., cytochrome inducers P-450.
  • Manifestations are acute abdominal pain (the most common finding of this condition), CNS symptoms (hallucinations, psychosis, etc.), peripheral neuropathy (more prominent in the proximal upper extremities), and red-tinged urine, which changes in colour when exposed to air or light.
  • Common laboratory findings are elevated blood or urine levels of porphobilinogen and aminolevulinic acid. Hyponatremia and elevated LFTs are also common findings.
  • It is treated by hemin (a heme analogue as it inhibits the very first enzyme in heme synthesis) and glucose.             

Option A: Porphyria cutanea tarda

  • It manifests with red-brown or tea-coloured urine and skin lesions due to sun exposure. Limb weakness and abdominal symptoms are typically not found in this condition.

Option B: Lead poisoning

  • Lead poisoning inhibits many enzymes in heme syntheses, such as Ferrochelatase and Aminolevulinate dehydratase.
  • It causes microcytic sideroblastic anaemia with ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow.
  • Lead poisoning is an important differential diagnosis; it can also present with acute abdominal pain and weakness and causes anaemia (vs Acute intermittent porphyria).

Option C: Ischemic stroke  

  • Ischemic stroke is commonly present in elders if the patient presents with sudden limb weakness and confusion. Acute abdominal pain can also be present in acute mesenteric ischemia, but this is most unlikely in this patient without any history of high blood pressure or diabetes or any risk factor of stroke, e.g., atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with complaints of Recurrent Headaches has been advised to get a CT Head. CT scan exposes the Brain to Ionizing radiation, which of the following enzyme protects the brain from free radical injury is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Superoxide dismutase

  • Superoxidase dismutases (SODs) are found in many cell types and convert O2 radicals into hydrogen peroxide.
  • superoxide dismutase is an enzyme that prevents the cell from reactive oxygen species.

This group of enzymes includes:-

  • Manganese-SOD localized in mitochondria
  • Copper-zinc- SOD found in the cytosol.

One of the earliest discovered hereditary forms of Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) has mutations in the gene encoding copper-zinc superoxide dismutase (SOD1) on chromosome 21; this variant accounts for about 20% of familial cases.

Option A: Myeloperoxidase 

  • Myeloperoxidase is a peroxidase enzyme.
  • It is mainly present in neutrophil granulocytes
  • It produces hypochlorous acid to act as an antimicrobial enzyme.

Option C: NADPH oxidase

  • NADPH oxidase is the membrane-bound enzyme complex that faces extracellular space
  • It is used by neutrophils to engulf microorganisms.

Option D: Hydroxylase

  • Hydroxylases are enzymes that catalyze the addition of hydroxyl groups.
  • It is just involved in hydroxylation reactions.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man post orthotopic liver transplantation presents with decreased bile production during the first 3 days. Reperfusion injury is thought to be the cause of Poor graft function in this patient. Which of the following substances is most likely to cause reperfusion injury in the transplanted liver?
questions.solution:
Option D: Reactive oxygen species.

  • Ischemia OR reperfusion (I/R) injury is a common clinical problem in occlusive cardiovascular disease, transplantation, infection, shock, and many other circumstances.
  • The genesis of I/R injury relates to the interplay between the transient ischemia and the re-establishment of the blood flow (reperfusion).
  • Initially, the ischemia produces a type of cellular damage that leads to the generation of free radical species.
  • Subsequently, reperfusion provides abundant molecular oxygen (O2) combined with free radicals to form reactive oxygen species.
  • Oxygen radicals are formed inside cells through the xanthine oxidase pathway and released from activated neutrophils.

Option A: Cationic proteins

  • Cationic proteins are eosinophilic and are present in the body fluids of patients with allergic and inflammatory diseases.
  • Immunoglobulins,  complement factors induce their secretions, and serum opsonized particles.

Option B: Free ferric iron

  • Iron is essential for multiple processes like DNA synthesis, electron transport, and oxygen transport.
  • Ion exists in two oxidation States, the ferrous cation and ferric form.
  • Nonhemoglobin iron in food is mainly in the ferric state, which is the insoluble form of iron.
  • Only the ferrous form of iron is for reabsorption

Option C: Hydrochlorous acid

  • Hydrochloric acid is a weak acid that forms when chlorine dissolves in water and partially dissociates.
  • It is a weak acid that does not have any reactive properties, so it is not involved in reperfusion injury.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of fever and cough. He is vitally stable. On examination, right lower lobe crepitation is heard. A diagnosis of pneumonia is made. Pneumonia is an acute lung parenchymal infection. The protective response is the invasion of neutrophils at the area of infection. Neutrophils trap the extracellular microbes via a fibrillary network, known as neutrophil extracellular traps. The process is shown below:



Which of the following is the most important amino acid formed from the cellular reaction shown above?
questions.solution:
The most important amino acid in the context of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) is:

Option C - Arginine:

Arginine plays a crucial role in NETosis, which is the process by which neutrophils release web-like structures composed of chromatin (DNA) and antimicrobial proteins to capture and neutralize pathogens.

Here's why arginine is important in NET formation:

  1. Nitric Oxide (NO) Production: Arginine is a substrate for the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS), which generates nitric oxide (NO). Nitric oxide is involved in various cellular processes, including the regulation of NET formation.

  2. Citrullination: During NETosis, arginine residues on histones are converted into citrulline by a specific enzyme called peptidylarginine deiminase (PAD). This citrullination of histones is a crucial step in chromatin decondensation, which is necessary for NET formation.

As for the other amino acids mentioned:

Option A. Leucine, B. Methionine, and D. Valine are important amino acids in protein synthesis and other cellular processes, but they are not specifically known to play a central role in NETosis. Arginine, on the other hand, is directly involved in the processes critical for NET formation, making it the most important amino acid in this context.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man develops a significant respiratory stridor within minutes following a bee sting with dyspnea and wheezing. An epinephrine injection helps reverse these events completely, and then he recovers within a few minutes. Which of the following chemical mediator is not involved in the pathogenesis of this man's condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Myeloperoxidase

  • Myeloperoxidase (MPO) is an enzyme present in primary (or azurophilic) granules of neutrophils and takes part in the formation of reactive oxygen species.
  • In the presence of a halide such as Cl-, MPO converts H2O2 to HOCl.
  • Hypochlorous radical is used during the process of the respiratory burst.

Option A: Tumor necrosis factor-a (TNF-a)

  • It causes the adhesion of leukocytes to endothelium and their migration through vessels.
  • It is produced by activated macrophages and dendritic cells.
  • It is also released from T lymphocytes and mast cells.
  • It mainly contributes to local and systemic reactions of inflammation. The role of TNF-a in inflammation is as follows:
  • Endothelium activation causes the endothelium to induce a spectrum of changes called endothelium activation. These changes include:
  • Increased expression of endothelial adhesion molecules
  • Increased production of cytokines and chemokines, and eicosanoids
  • Increased procoagulant activity
  • Activation of leukocytes and other cells- It increases the response of neutrophils and stimulates the microbicidal activity of macrophages.
  • System acute-phase responses- including fever
  • It regulates energy balance by promoting lipid and protein catabolism and suppressing appetite.

Option B: Interleukin-1

  • Interleukin-1 is produced by macrophages, endothelial cells and some epithelial cells.
  • It stimulates the expression of endothelial adhesion molecules and the secretion of other cytokines.
  • It also has systemic effects (systemic acute-phase response).

Option D: Prostaglandins

  • They are produced by mast cells, macrophages and endothelial cells.
  • They are involved in vascular and systemic reactions of inflammation. The most important prostaglandins in inflammation are PGE2, PGD2, PGF2a, PGI2 and TXA2.
  • Prostaglandins causes:
  • TXA2- It promotes vasoconstriction and platelet aggregation.
  • PGE2- It causes vasodilation and increases vascular permeability.
  • PGI2-It causes vasodilation and inhibits platelet aggregation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of bilateral flank pain for one day. He is a known case of sarcoidosis. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The x-ray of the patient is done, which reveals two discrete areas of calcification within the inter-polar region of the renal parenchyma, which measured 6 and 3 mm, respectively. Laboratory evaluation revealed mild hypokalemia, hypercalcemia, mild hyperphosphatemia, a severe non-anion gap metabolic alkalosis, and a suppressed parathyroid hormone level. The above-mentioned pathological findings are due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Overproduction of 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D

  • This is a case of nephrocalcinosis secondary to sarcoidosis in which the patient presents with complaints of bilateral flank pain.
  • The x-ray of the patient is done, which reveals two discrete areas of calcification within the interpolar region of the renal parenchyma, which measured 6 and 3 mm. respectively. Laboratory evaluation revealed mild hypokalemia, hypercalcemia, mild hyperphosphatemia, a severe non-anion gap metabolic alkalosis, and a suppressed parathyroid hormone level which is suggestive of nephrocalcinosis secondary to sarcoidosis.
  • Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease of unknown cause. Sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases can cause hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria due to excessive production of vitamin D from the extrarenal conversion of 1,25 (OH)2D3
  • Nephrocalcinosis calcification of the interstitium and renal tubules. It is associated with hypercalcemia.
  • Significant degrees of calcinosis, under certain conditions, can lead to chronic tubulointerstitial disease and renal failure. Along with further damage, slowly progressive chronic kidney disease develops.

Option B: Dystrophic calcification

  • Dystrophic calcification is a localized calcification.
  • It is secondary to local injury or necrosis caused due to cardiovascular conditions, fat necrosis, infarcts or autoimmune connective tissue disorder.

Option C: Mutation in calcium-sensing receptors

  • The calcium-sensing receptor is a protein-coding gene.
  • Mutation in the calcium-sensing receptor gene can cause autosomal dominant hypocalcemia type-1.

Option D: Increased reabsorption of calcium

  • Nephrocalcinosis is associated with increased calcium intake.
  • Disorders associated with hypercalcemia, such as hyperparathyroidism, multiple myeloma, vitamin D intoxication, metastatic cancer, or excessive calcium intake (Milk alkali syndrome), can lead to the formation of calcium stones and calcium deposits in the kidneys, causing nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the office because of weakness in both legs for a day. Two weeks ago, he had a 4-day bout of gastroenteritis, and yesterday he developed burning sensations in his toes. Examination shows facial flushing, a systolic blood pressure range of 70-160 mm Hg, profuse diaphoresis, and bilateral facial paralysis. Lumbar puncture shows a normal white cell count and elevated protein. He is treated with plasma exchange and intravenous immunoglobulin and steadily recovers over three months.Which of the following most similarly describes the type of hypersensitivity reaction that caused this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer 

Option B: Type II hypersensitivity

  • The patient's presentation is consistent with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), a neurological disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and often ascending paralysis. Given the clinical details provided, the hypersensitivity reaction that caused this patient's condition is Type II Hypersensitivity Reaction.

    Type II hypersensitivity reactions involve the activation of antibodies (IgG or IgM) against specific antigens present on cell surfaces or in tissues. In Guillain-Barré syndrome, the immune system mistakenly targets the peripheral nerves, leading to demyelination and impaired nerve conduction. The autoantibodies target components of the peripheral nerve myelin, causing nerve damage and subsequent weakness and paralysis.

 

Option A: Type 1 hypersensitivity

  • This option is incorrect 

Option C: Type 3 hypersensitivity

  • This option is incorrect

Option D: Type 4 hypersensitivity

  • This option is incorrect

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents to the medical outpatient department with complaints of fever, nausea, fatigue, headaches, diarrhoea, night sweats, increased urinary frequency, and unintended weight loss from the last three weeks. Upon admission, vitals are remarkable for an elevated temperature and pulse, along with a decreased diastolic blood pressure of 110/60mmHg. Platelet levels are low, decreased fibrinogen concentrations, and prolonged prothrombin times are concerning for DIC. Abdominal ultrasound shows hepatosplenomegaly with iron deposition and a left lobe liver mass. The laboratory values are found to be haemoglobin of 11.2 g/dL, white blood cell count of 4.9 × 103/µL, platelet count of 118 × 103/µL, C-reactive protein of 4.98 mg/dL, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 35 mm/hour. In a peripheral smear at presentation, 4% monocytes, 3% metamyelocytes, and 8% lymphocytes are observed. A bone marrow biopsy is performed, and it reveals an NK cell neoplasm. Which of the following is NK cell neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mycosis fungoides

  • Clinical signs: Fever, nausea, fatigue, headaches, diarrhoea, night sweats, increased urinary frequency, and unintended weight loss from last three weeks, on examination hemophagocytosis, hepatosplenomegaly, and DIC, and raised C-reactive protein while in peripheral film 4% monocytes, 3% metamyelocytes and 8% lymphocytes are suggestive of aggressive NK cell neoplasm.
  • Mycosis fungoides is a Mature T and NK cell neoplasm.
  • Mature T and NK cell neoplasm
    • T cell prolymphocytic leukaemia
    • Mycosis fungoides
    • Sezary syndrome
    • Aggressive NK - cell leukaemia
    • Systemic EBV 4 T - cell lymphoma of Childhood
    • Adult T - cell leukaemia/ lymphoma
    • Follicular T - cell lymphoma
  • B- cell neoplasm:
    • Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) 
    • Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) 
    • Follicular Lymphoma (FL) 
    • Hairy cell leukaemia (HCL)
    • Hairy cell leukaemia variant (HCL-v)
    • Mantle cell lymphoma
    • Burkitt's lymphoma

Option B: Hairy cell leukaemia

  • It is not the NK cell tumour.
  • It is a B cell neoplasm.
  • The bone marrow produces too many lymphocytes in hairy cell leukaemia, a particular type of cancer (a type of white blood cell).

Option C: Mantle cell lymphoma

  • It is not the NK cell tumour.
  • It is a B cell neoplasm.
  • Aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), known as mantle cell lymphoma (MCL), develops from cells that originate in the "mantle zone."

Option D: Burkitt's lymphoma

  • It is not the NK cell tumour.
  • It is a B cell neoplasm.
  • Burkitt lymphoma is a non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma uncommon but extremely aggressive (rapidly growing) (NHL).
  • This condition may impact the bowel, kidneys, ovaries, central nervous system, jaw, and other organs.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presented with painless cervical lymphadenopathy. He has no other significant clinical features. The cervical lymph node biopsy indicated that it shows a nodular appearance with fibrous bands, effacement of the lymph node architecture, and numerous lacunar cells with the polymorphous background of T cells, eosinophils, plasma cells, and macrophages. He is diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma. Which of the following must be true regarding this disorder?

choices.text: Lacunar cells are positive for CD20 and CD45

questions.solution:
Option D: Relatively favourable clinical course

  • According to the patient's clinical features and biopsy report, the diagnosis is the Nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma.

  • The patient usually presents with stage I or II, having no other systemic clinical features.

  • It is the most common subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma (65% to 70% of cases)

  • It is most commonly seen in young adults, with similar incidence in males and females.

  • Overall, this subtype has a relatively favourable clinical course with a prognosis better than other types of Hodgkin lymphoma.

  • The characteristic cells are lacunar cells, which have multilobulated nuclei and lie within an open space.

  • Lacunar cells are considered a Reed Sternberg cell variant. The diagnosis of nodular sclerosis can be based on the finding of nodules separated by collagenous/fibrous bands and lacunar cells.

  • Lacunar cells are positive for CD15 and CD30 and negative for CD20 and CD45

Option A: Benign neoplasm

  • Lymphomas are the malignant neoplasm of the lymphatic system, i.e. lymph nodes, spleen and bone marrow.

  • Nodular sclerosis is the most common type of Hodgkin lymphoma.

Option B: Frequent association with EBV infection

  • It is uncommonly associated with EBV.

  • The Reed-Sternberg cells of mixed-cellularity type are infected with EBV in 70% of cases.

Option C: Lacunar cells are positive for CD20 and CD45

  • Lacunar cells are positive for CD15 and CD30 and negative for CD20 and CD45.

  • Lymphocyte-predominance has cells that are positive for CD 20

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of gum swelling and bleeding for the past few weeks. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly is noted. A bone marrow biopsy shows greater than 20% of blast cells. The gums finding of the patient is given below:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: AML

  • The gums infiltration is usually seen in AML.

AML:

  • Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is a tumour of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow.
  • Replacing the marrow with blasts produces marrow failure and complications related to anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia. AML occurs at all ages, but the incidence rises throughout life, peaking after 60 years of age.
  • Most patients present within weeks or a few months of symptoms with complaints related to anaemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia, most notably fatigue, fever, and spontaneous mucosal and cutaneous bleeding.
  • Thrombocytopenia results in abnormal bleeding, which often is prominent.
  • Cutaneous petechiae and ecchymoses, serosal haemorrhages into the linings of the body cavities and viscera, and mucosal haemorrhages into the gingivae and urinary tract are common.
  • Procoagulants and fibrinolytic factors released by leukemic cells, especially in AML with the t(15;17), exacerbate the bleeding tendency. Infections are frequent, particularly in the oral cavity, skin, lungs, kidneys, urinary bladder, and colon, and are often caused by opportunists such as fungi, Pseudomonas, and commensals.
  • Signs and symptoms related to the involvement of tissues other than the marrow are usually less striking in AML than in ALL, but tumours with monocytic differentiation often infiltrate the skin (leukaemia cutis) and the gingiva; this probably reflects the normal tendency of monocytes to extravasate into tissues. Central nervous system spread is less common than in ALL.
  • AML occasionally presents as a localized soft tissue mass known as myeloblastoma, myeloid sarcoma, or chloroma.
  • Without systemic treatment, such tumours inevitably progress to full-blown AML over time.
  • The overall prognosis is guarded, as AML is a difficult disease; about 60% of patients achieve complete remission with chemotherapy, but only 15% to 30% remain free of disease for 5 years.
  • However, the outcome varies markedly among different molecular subtypes.

Option A: ALL

  • ALL can present with hepatosplenomegaly and pancytopenia.
  • However, gums infiltration is not seen in ALL.
  • Moreover, CNS and mediastinal involvement is the feature of ALL.

Option C: CML

  • CML usually presents with hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Gums infiltration and more than 20% blast cells signify acute leukaemia, not chronic.
  • CML cases are usually detected when a very high leukocyte count is found during the laboratory examination.

Option D: CLL

  • CLL often presents with asymptomatic elevation in WBCs count.
  • Smudge cells are characteristic of CLL.
  • Moreover, CLL is not characterized by gum infiltration.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with generalized abdominal pain for the past 24 hours. On physical examination, tenderness is felt in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. He is taken to the operating room for laparoscopic appendectomy. Removal of the appendix has been associated with a protective effect against disease. Which of the following is a highly sensitive and specific marker for inflammation in that particular disease?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fecal lactoferrin

  • The appendix is an immunologic organ involved in the secretion of immunoglobulins.
  • An inverse association between appendectomy and the development of ulcerative colitis has been reported.
  • Routine resection of the normal appendix to improve the clinical course of ulcerative colitis is not generally indicated.
  • Faecal lactoferrin, a glycoprotein present in activated neutrophils, is a highly sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation in ulcerative colitis.

Option A: C-reactive protein (CRP)

  • Increased CRP is seen in almost all cases of ulcerative colitis, but it is a non-specific marker and can be elevated in many cases of inflammation.

Option C: Fecal calprotectin

  • Faecal calprotectin is a non-specific marker as it is present in neutrophils and monocytes, and levels correlate well with histologic inflammation, predict relapses, and detect pouchitis.
  • Faecal calprotectin levels can also be elevated in cases of acute diarrhoea.

Option D: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)

  • It is also a non-specific marker of inflammation, and its elevation can be seen in many inflammatory states of the body.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented to an outpatient clinic with a six-month history of shortness of breath. His blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, and his pulse is 85/minute. On the X-ray of the chest, there is evidence of hilar lymphadenopathy. The biopsy revealed the presence of non-caseating granulomas. Lab results show hypercalcemia. Which of the following pathogenic mechanisms is involved in sarcoidosis development?

choices.text: Intra-alveolar and interstitial accumulation of CD8+ T cells
Increased levels of T cell-derived TH1 cytokines such as IL-2 and IFN-γ
Decreased levels of cytokines in the local environment IL-8, TNF
Decreased the level of ACE enzyme

questions.solution:
Option B: Increased levels of T cell-derived TH1 cytokines such as IL-2 and IFN-γ

  • Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that affects multiple organs throughout the body. 
  • Multiple immune abnormalities are involved in the pathogenesis of sarcoidosis.
  • CD4+ T cell accumulation in intra-alveolar and interstitial spaces
    • Increase the CD4/CD8 T cell ratio to 15:1 from 5:1. 
    • The antigen-driven proliferation of T -cell subsets 
  • Increased levels of TH1 cytokines derived from T cells, such as IL-2 and IFN- γ
    • T cells proliferation 
    • Activation of macrophage
  • Increased cytokine production (IL-8, TNF, and macrophage inflammatory protein) 
    • Activated macrophages release TNF
    • Recruitment of T cells and macrophages 
    • Formation of granulomas
  • Dendritic cell dysfunction
