    • It acts as antigen-presenting cells. 
  • Sarcoidosis is also linked to family history, and certain HLA genotypes (HLA-A1 and HLA-B8) are more susceptible. 
  • Sarcoidosis is characterized by a TH1-type immune response, with increased levels of cytokines such as IL-2 and IFN-γ. These cytokines contribute to the formation of granulomas in affected tissues.

Option A: Intra-alveolar and interstitial accumulation of CD8+ T cells

  • Sarcoidosis causes the development of non-caseating granulomas. 
  • The pathogenesis of this disease is mediated by CD4+ T cells. 
  • While T cells are involved in sarcoidosis, it is primarily CD4+ T cells that accumulate in the granulomas seen in sarcoidosis, not CD8+ T cells.

Option C: Decreased levels of cytokines in the local environment IL-8, TNF

  • The pathogenesis of sarcoidosis involves an increase in cytokine production. 
  • An increase in IL-8 and TNF promotes the formation of granulomas. 
  • In sarcoidosis, there is often an increase in pro-inflammatory cytokines, including TNF (tumor necrosis factor). Decreased levels of these cytokines are not characteristic of sarcoidosis

Option D: Decreased the level of ACE enzyme 

  • ACE enzyme levels are increased in sarcoidosis. 
  • ACE converts angiotension I to angiotensin II. 
  • Sarcoidosis can lead to an increased level of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) in the blood, not decreased levels. Measuring ACE levels is sometimes used as a diagnostic marker for sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents in pulmonology OPD for a medical check-up. He complained about his dry cough and exertional dyspnea for the last 1.5 years. His symptoms are progressive and have recently gotten worse. Physical examination shows clubbing of his digits and fine inspiratory crackles on lung bases. High-resolution chest CT is suggestive of interstitial lung disease. Which of the following is the histological hallmark for diagnosing idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis on lung biopsy?

choices.text: Areas of fibrosis occur preferentially in the apical regions
Fibroblastic foci are the earliest lesion

questions.solution:
Option C: Fibroblastic foci are the earliest lesion

The patient described in the clinical vignette is a classical case of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, a type of interstitial lung disease (ILD)

Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF), also known as cryptogenic fibrosing alveolitis:

  • Grossly, the lung's pleural surfaces are cobblestoned due to the retraction of scars along the interlobular septa.
  • The cut surface shows tight, rubbery white areas of fibrosis, which occurs preferentially in the lower lobes, the subpleural regions, and along the interlobular septa.
  • The histologic pattern of fibrosis is referred to as usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).
  • Histologically, the hallmark is patchy interstitial fibrosis.
  • The earliest lesions contain exuberant fibroblastic proliferation (fibroblastic foci).
  • With time these areas become more collagenous and less cellular.

Option A: Dust-laden macrophages

  • They are not seen in IPF.
  • Dust-laden macrophages can be seen in pneumoconiosis.

Option B:  Areas of fibrosis occur preferentially in the apical regions

  • In IPF, fibrosis occurs preferentially in the lower lobes, the subpleural regions, and along the interlobular septa, not in the apical region

Option D: Masson bodies are characteristic

  • Masson bodies are seen in Cryptogenic Organising Pneumonia, not in IPF.

questions.text: A 12-year-old female presents to the neurology ward with a complaint of headache. She also complains of visual impairment but does not complain of photophobia. After a thorough assessment, a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma is made. The biopsy of the lesion confirms an adamantinomatous variant of craniopharyngioma. Which of the following is the least likely feature of this variant?

choices.text: Nests and cords of squamous epithelium embedded in the spongy reticulum
Papillae lined by well-differentiated squamous epithelium

questions.solution:
Option D: Papillae lined by well-differentiated squamous epithelium

  • The papillary variant is associated with papillae that are lined by well-differentiated squamous cell epithelium

Craniopharyngioma:

Description:

  • A relatively benign dysontogenetic tumour arising from a remnant of the Rathke pouch (ectodermal derivative)

Epidemiology

  • Bimodal distribution: 5–14 years; second peak at 50–75 years
  • Most common childhood supratentorial tumour

Clinical features:

  • The tumour arises in the suprasellar region and can extend into the intrasellar region.
  • Compression of the pituitary gland due to intrasellar extension → hypopituitarism
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
  • Failure to thrive
  • Central diabetes insipidus
  • Compression of the ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus → hyperphagia and obesity
  • Compression of the infundibular stalk → disconnection hyperprolactinemia
  • Compression of the optic chiasm → bitemporal hemianopsia
  • Compression of interventricular foramina and/or aqueduct → obstructive hydrocephalus

Diagnostics

  • Imaging: suprasellar calcified cyst with a lobulated contour
  • Biopsy: cholesterol crystals found in a motor oil-like fluid on gross examination

Histological variants

Adamantinomatous (common)

  • Reticular epithelial cells
  • Frequently associated with calcifications
  • Cysts and keratin nodules

Papillary

  • Metaplastic squamous cells
  • Calcifications and cysts are rare.
  • No keratin nodules

Treatment

  • Resection Adjuvant radiotherapy In the case of hypopituitarism: hormone replacement therapy

Option A: Nests and cords of squamous epithelium embedded in the spongy reticulum

  • The adamantinomatous variant comprises nests and cords of the squamous cell epithelium.

Option B: Compact, lamellar keratin formation ("wet keratin")

  • Wet keratin is one of the features of the adanmantinomatous variant of the craniopharyngioma

Option C: Dystrophic calcification and cholesterol crystals

  • Craniopharyngioma is one of the causes of dystrophic calcified masses.
  • It also has cholesterol crystals

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with neurological deficits and seizures. Imaging showed a lesion in the temporal lobe. Biopsy was taken from the lesion, and neural tissue was sent for histological examination (microscopy shown below). Based on the characteristic histological features, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Oligodendroglioma

  • The tumours are composed of spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm, giving a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • The tumour typically contains a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries ('chicken-wire capillaries).
  • Perineuronal Satellitosis is a feature of oligodendroglioma.
  • Most commonly presented in the fourth and fifth decades.
  • The lesion is mostly found in the cerebral hemispheres (mainly in the temporal or frontal lobes).

  • Image on the left showing perinuclear halos giving rise to a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • Image on the right showing Perineuronal satellitosis.

Option A: Glioblastoma

  • Glioblastoma is a Grade IV astrocytoma.
  • It is a common, highly malignant primary brain tumour with one-year median survival.
  • It is found in the cerebral hemispheres.
  • It can cross the corpus callosum "butterfly glioma" associated with EGFR amplification.
  • It is of astrocyte origin, glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) positive.
  • "Pseudopalisading" pleomorphic tumour cells with central border areas of necrosis, haemorrhage, and/or microvascular proliferation.

Option B: Pilocytic astrocytoma

  • It is a low-grade astrocytoma. Most common primary brain tumour in childhood.
  • Usually well circumscribed.
  • In children, most often found in the posterior fossa (e.g., cerebellum), but supratentorial can also be found.
  • It has a benign course and a good prognosis.
  • Histology shows it is of astrocyte origin, GFAP positive, with bipolar neoplastic cells with hairlike projections.
  • Associated with microcysts and Rosenthal fibres (eosinophilic, corkscrew fibres)

Option D: Medulloblastoma

  • Most common malignant brain tumour in childhood.
  • It commonly involves the cerebellum and can compress the 4th ventricle causing non-communicating hydrocephalus causing, headaches and papilledema.
  • It can involve the cerebellar vermis causing truncal ataxia.
  • It can send "drop metastases" to the spinal cord.
  • Histology shows it is a form of primitive neuroectodermal tumour (PNET).
  • "Homer-Wright rosette" (small blue cells surrounding the central area of the neuropil)
  • It is positive for synaptophysin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the physician with complaints of fatigue, intermittent left-sided flank pain, and diffuse extremity pain for two months. She was treated for a prolactinoma four years ago and had recurrent antral and duodenal peptic ulcers despite receiving appropriate treatment. The physical examination of the patient reveals a moderately distended abdomen that is diffusely tender to palpation. The patient also has mild left-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. The laboratory investigation of the patient reveals a calcium concentration of 12 mg/dL, a phosphorus concentration of 2 mg/dL, and a parathyroid hormone level of 422 pg/mL. An ultrasound abdomen of the patient was done, which revealed multiple kidney stones in the left ureteropelvic junction. The pathology associated with the patient’s pathology is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most commonly associated with the patient’s pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gastrinoma

  • This is a case of MEN 1 syndrome in which the patient presents with complaints of fatigue, intermittent left-sided flank pain, and diffuse extremity pain for two months.
  • She was treated for a prolactinoma four years ago and has had recurrent antral and duodenal peptic ulcers despite receiving appropriate treatment.
  • The physical examination of the patient reveals a moderately distended abdomen that is diffusely tender to palpation. The patient also has mild left-sided costovertebral angle tenderness.
  • The laboratory investigation of the patient reveals a calcium concentration of 12 mg/dL, a phosphorus concentration of 2 mg/dL, and a parathyroid hormone level of 422 pg/mL. An ultrasound abdomen of the patient was done, which revealed multiple kidney stones in the left ureteropelvic junction.
  • All these symptoms and findings suggest MEN 1 syndrome.
  • MEN 1 syndrome is associated with gastrinoma, which is also known as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
  • Gastrin hypersecretion is usually due to gastrin-producing gastrinomas; these can occur in the pancreas, duodenum, or peripancreatic soft tissue.
  • The classic “Z-E” syndrome comprises a triad of severe peptic ulcer disease, gastric hypersecretion, and pancreatic islet lesions.

Clinical Features:

  • Although the ulcers are identical to those found in the general population, they are often intractable to therapy; they may also occur in unusual locations such as the jejunum.
  • More than half of the gastrinomas have metastasized or are locally invasive at the time of diagnosis; approximately 25% arise in conjunction with other endocrine tumours as part of the MEN-1 syndrome.

Option B: Insulinoma

  • Insulinoma is usually a benign tumour of pancreatic islet beta-cell.
  • It is usually associated with increased insulin production.

Option C: Lipoma

  • Lipoma is a benign tumour of the soft subcutaneous tissue.
  • Its aetiology is unknown.
  • It is a slow-growing round, soft and non-tender tumour usually located at the head, shoulder, neck and back.

Option D: Glucagonoma

  • Glucagonoma is a neuroendocrine tumour of the pancreas.
  • It originates from the multipotential stem cells of endodermal origin.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the hospital with his brother but dies before getting treatment. Medical history reveals that he was a chronic alcoholic and had an illness characterised by ascites, increasing jaundice, and generalised wasting. Laboratory testing reveals hyperbilirubinemia, hypoalbuminemia, and mildly elevated liver enzymes. The appearance of the liver at autopsy is shown in the figure. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient's history and liver autopsy?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cirrhosis

  • In this case, the image shows the typical appearance of micronodular cirrhosis, Its most common cause is chronic alcoholism.
  • Major clinical manifestations:
    • Jaundice
    • Ascites
    • Signs of hyperestrinism (palmar erythema, spider telangiectasia, gynecomastia, testicular atrophy)
  • Consequences of increased portal venous pressure (oesophagal varices, distended abdomen).
  • Cirrhosis is an end-stage liver disease after many years of alcohol drinking.
  • It is characterised by liver fibrosis caused by long-term liver damage and results in improper functioning of the liver.
  • Causes of cirrhosis include:
    • Drinking too much alcohol over many years
    • Long-term infection of hepatitis B or C.
    • Severe non-alcoholic steatohepatitis or non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
  • In an autopsy examination of a patient who died due to cirrhosis, the most critical factor in the causing of alcoholic hepatic cirrhosis is the necrosis of hepatocytes due to the alcoholic toxic effects and autoimmune processes.
  • Destructive and dystrophic shifts can be detected by histological examination of the liver in the following regions:
    • Hepatoportal section of the liver acini
    • Tubular sections of the liver acini
    • Central sections of the liver cells.
  • According to the pathomorphological classification, there are three primary forms of hepatic cirrhosis which are as follows:
    1. Micronodular form of hepatic cirrhosis

                        It is characterised by a diameter of connective tissue nodes of < 3 mm.

    1. Coarse nodular form of hepatic cirrhosis

                        It is characterised by a diameter of nodes of > 3 mm

    1. Mixed hepatic cirrhosis

                         It is characterised by both small and large connective tissue nodes in the liver parenchyma.

Option A: alpha 1-antitrypsin deficiency

  • It is a genetic condition which results in lung and liver damage.
  • Symptoms are usually similar to emphysema, which includes:
    • Chronic cough
    • Shortness of breath
    • Wheezing
  • The autopsy report of this condition can show the following:
    • Alpha1-AT-positive intracytoplasmic globules.
    • Increased inflammatory infiltration with severe oedema and congestion
    • Thickened pulmonary alveolar walls with fibrin deposition in the lungs.

Option C: Hepatitis A

  • It is liver inflammation caused by the hepatitis A virus (HAV).
  • Hepatitis A does not result in chronic liver disease, and the patient usually recovers from it. It rarely results in fulminant hepatitis, which is acute liver failure and fatal.

Option D: Hepatitis C

  • It is a viral infection that causes inflammation of the liver sometimes and can lead to severe liver damage. It spreads through contaminated blood.
  • After prolonged infection of hepatitis C, cirrhosis may occur.
  • Scarring in the liver makes it difficult for the liver to function.
  • Even if the patient had hepatitis C, it died due to cirrhosis caused by hepatitis C infection.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his brother with complaints of a rash on his skin and irritability from the last few hours starting suddenly. The patient also complains of difficulty in breathing of sudden onset. On general physical examination, there are raised, itchy skin bumps spreading all over the body. His blood pressure is 90/60mmHg. Yesterday he developed a high-grade fever, cough and shortness of breath. The patient was given ampicillin 2 g intravenously. The patient should be managed by which of the following?

choices.text: 0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by intramuscular route
0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by intravenous route
0.5 ml of 1:10000 adrenaline by intramuscular route
0.5 ml of 1:10000 adrenaline by intravenous route

questions.solution:
Option A: 0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by intramuscular route

  • This is the case of anaphylactic shock in which the patient is brought to the emergency department with complaints of a rash on the skin, hypotension and irritability from the last few hours. All these signs and symptoms suggest the patient is in shock.
  • His blood pressure is 90/60mmHg.
  • The patient also complains of difficulty in breathing which starts suddenly.
  • On examination, there are raised, itchy skin bumps spreading all over the body.
  • The patient was given ampicillin 2 g intravenously due to a respiratory tract infection.
  • The management protocol of this patient is to give adrenaline by intramuscular route with the dose of 0.5 ml of 1:1000.

Option B: 0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by intravenous route

  • By intravenous route, a diluted form of adrenaline can only be given in immediate life-threatening conditions. Otherwise, it should not be given intravenously.
  • If given intravenously, then transfuse slowly with proper monitoring.

Option C: 0.5 ml of 1:10000 adrenaline by intramuscular route

  • The intramuscular dose of adrenaline is 0.5ml of 1:1000.
  • It should not be injected in diluted form.

Option D: 0.5 ml of 1:10000 adrenaline by intravenous route

  • According to the above-given case scenario, adrenaline should not be injected intravenously because the patient is not in a life-threatening condition.

questions.text: A research group wants to assess a new drug's safety and toxicity profile. A clinical trial is conducted with 20 healthy volunteers to estimate the maximum tolerated dose and monitor the apparent toxicity of the drug. The study design is best described as which of the following clinical trial phases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A : Phase I

  • The clinical trial phase involves administering doses of a new drug to healthy volunteers to determine its safety and preliminary pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic properties.
  • Following the initial evaluation of the drug to assess for its pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic properties (phase 0 trial), phase I clinical trials assess drug safety and determine tolerable drug dosages.
  • The results of the phase I trials are used to organize trials with a larger sample size that assess drug efficacy (phase II trials and phase III trials).

 

Option B: Phase II

  • The phase of a clinical trial in which a small number of individuals with the disease of interest take the drug to determine its efficacy, effective dosing, and adverse effects.
  • Phase II trials are the first trials that evaluate drug efficacy among a small group of patients with the disease of interest. The drug dosing of a phase II trial would be based on the research group's toxicity and side effect profile.

Option C: Phase III

  • The clinical trial phase involves a large-scale, randomized study to compare the experimental drug with a placebo or the current "gold standard" of treatment.
  • Phase III trials generally require large numbers of volunteers participating in a randomized control trial rather than the small number of volunteers studied here. Moreover, the primary goal of a phase III trial is to evaluate drug efficacy against the “gold standard” treatment rather than to study the safety, toxicity, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of a drug.
  • “The purpose of phase III trials is to obtain adequate data about the efficacy and safety of drugs in a larger number of patients of either sex in multiple centres usually in comparison with the standard drug.”

Option D: Phase IV

  • A post-approval/post-marketing stage in drug development assesses the effects of long-term drug use. This can result in the withdrawal of the drug from the market.
  • Phase IV trials are long-term “surveillance” trials. Often commenced and continued even after FDA approval, phase IV trials are meant to identify the long-term risks of drug treatment beyond those discovered during initial trials. Phase IV trials involve thousands of patients, many more than the small group of healthy volunteers included in the study.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man reports to the physician with symptoms including nausea, redness, swelling, and pain at the bite site lasting for 4 hours. He mentions being bitten by a spider while parking his car in the garage and washed the area immediately. He also experienced tremors en route to the hospital. The patient has no chronic illnesses, is stable, and shows no other abnormalities on examination. The spider in question, depicted in the image below, produces a toxin that leads to what?

choices.text: Blocking Active transport of Ach into the synaptic vesicle

questions.solution:
Option A: Excess release of acetylcholine

  • This is a case of spider bite in which the patient presents to the physician with complaints of nausea, redness, swelling and pain at the bite site for 4 hours. He further gives the history that he was bitten by a spider while he was parking his car in the garage. He says that he had washed his hand immediately after the bite.
  • The patient also started to develop tremors till the time he arrived at the hospital.
  • All these symptoms suggest excess acetylcholine release.
  • The spider shown in the image is a black widow spider.
  • The black widow spider produces a toxin which is known as alpha-latrotoxin.
  • It induces a massive release of acetylcholine.

Option B: Decrease the release of acetylcholine

  • The release of acetylcholine can be decreased by: Botulinum toxin

Option C: Inhibits synthesis of acetylcholine

  • The synthesis of acetylcholine can be inhibited by Hemicholinium (HC3) blocks choline uptake (the rate-limiting step in Ach synthesis) and depletes Ach.

Option D: Blocking Active transport of Ach into the synaptic vesicle

  • Active transport of Ach into the synaptic vesicle is Inhibited by vesamicol.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female comes to the hospital's emergency department after a tiring day at the office with complaints of severe headache, nausea, and dizziness, along with flushing. She is having pain, numbness, and discoloration in one hand. A pharmacological cardiac stress test is taken, and it comes out positive. Which cardiac medications have been associated with the ‘coronary steal’ phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Dipyridamole is a medication commonly used as a vasodilator and antiplatelet agent. It works by inhibiting the uptake of adenosine and blocking the breakdown of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). In certain situations, particularly when there are stenotic coronary arteries, dipyridamole can cause vasodilation in normal or non-stenotic blood vessels while leading to less dilation or stealing of blood flow from the stenotic vessels. This phenomenon is known as coronary steal.

The incorrect options are:

2. Glyceryl trinitrate: Glyceryl trinitrate, also known as nitroglycerin, is a vasodilator used to treat angina and manage acute coronary events. It does not cause the coronary steal phenomenon.

3. Disopyramide: Disopyramide is an antiarrhythmic medication used to treat certain types of cardiac arrhythmias. It does not cause the coronary steal phenomenon.

4. Diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used in the treatment of various cardiovascular conditions, including hypertension and angina. It does not cause the coronary steal phenomenon.

questions.text: A 3-year-old arrives at the ER, showing symptoms like excessive sweating, drowsiness, convulsions, and decreased consciousness after ingesting multiple metoprolol tablets. Physical exam and vital signs are normal. What's a characteristic feature of beta blockers?
questions.solution:
Option C: Bradycardia

  • In the above-given case, the findings of excessive sweating, drowsiness, convulsions, and decreased consciousness level after ingestion of metoprolol indicate the diagnosis of metoprolol poisoning.
  • Metoprolol is a beta antagonist. It acts on beta 1 receptors and causes bradycardia.
  • Clinical features of β blocker (Metoprolol) poisoning:
    • Decrease in heart rate.
    • Decrease in conduction.
    • Decrease in force of contraction.
  • Antidote for Beta-blocker toxicity is Glucagon.
    • As it acts through its G protein-coupled receptors in the heart. And by acting on that it reverses everything.
    • It increases the Heart rate, Increases the conduction and increases the Force of contraction.
    • Atropine is not used as an antidote because it will increase the heart Rate, conduction.

Option A: Narrow QRS complexes

  • Beta-blockers are generally given in tachycardia.
  • It decreases the heart rate and hence broad QRS complex on ECG.

Option B: Rapid pulse

  • Metoprolol is a drug used to treat patients with heart failure.
  • It affects the response to nerve impulses in some parts of the body, such as the heart. As a result, the heartbeat becomes slower and decreases blood pressure.

Option D: Shortened AV conduction times

  • Beta-blockers have a negative dromotropic effect on the AV node.
  • They prolong AV nodal refractory periods and increase t PR interval.
  • The prolonged PR interval rarely results in more than first-degree AV block in patients receiving maintenance therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency room with a complaint of sudden onset shortness of breath. On examination, fine inspiratory crackles are noted at the bases of the lungs. A chest X-ray is ordered, which reveals Kerley B lines. A diagnosis of acute pulmonary edema is made. Intravenous furosemide provides quick relief of dyspnoea by which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Causing rapid diuresis and reducing circulating blood volume

questions.solution:
Option C: Causing vasodilation

  • Furosemide is a high ceiling diuretic.
  • Its major mode of benefit in acute pulmonary oedema is vasodilation. Due to its vasodilatory action, it shifts the fluid from pulmonary to systemic circulation. This results in the rapid relief of symptoms.
  • Diuretic action develops later.

Option A: Producing bronchodilation

  • Bronchodilation is not an effect of furosemide.
  • It is caused by salmetrol, formetrol and salbutamol.

Option B: Causing rapid diuresis and reducing circulating blood volume

  • Rapid diuresis and reduced circulatory blood volume are effects of furosemide.
  • However, this effect occurs later; the primary effect is vasodilation.

Option D: Stimulating left ventricular contractility

  • Furosemide does not act by stimulating left ventricular contractility.
  • It is increased by positive inotropic drugs such as digoxin.

questions.text: In a 16-year-old boy with a history of eczema and recent respiratory symptoms, including cough, nasal congestion, and wheezing, which adverse effect is NOT typically associated with theophylline's blockade of adenosine receptors?
questions.solution:
Option D: GI discomfort

  • This patient is most likely suffering from bronchial asthma and receiving theophylline as part of his management. This drug exerts its bronchodilation effect by PDE inhibition and adenosine A1 antagonism. The side effects caused by these mechanisms of action are summarized below:
Nausea and vomiting PDE inhibition
Headache PDE inhibition
Gastric discomfort PDE inhibition
Diuresis Adenosine A1 antagonism
Arrhythmias PDE inhibition, A1 antagonism
Seizures Adenosine A1 antagonism
  • However, GI discomfort is not the side effect mediated by the blockade of the adenosine A1 antagonism.

Option A: Cardiac arrhythmias

  • These are the well-established side effects caused by the blockade of PDE inhibition and adenosine A1 antagonism.

Option B: Diuresis

  • The blockade of adenosine A1 antagonism causes diuresis.

Option C: Seizures

  • Adenosine A1 antagonism can lead to the development of seizures as a potential side effect.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the hospital's emergency department complaining about a loss of appetite, burning pain in her abdomen, and diarrhea. A stool test was taken to detect H.pylori and came out positive. What dose of amoxicillin must be administered in a triple-drug regimen for the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option C: 1g BD

  • This is a case of peptic ulcer disease in which the patient presents with complaints of loss of appetite, burning pain in her abdomen and diarrhoea for 4 days.
  • For the treatment of duodenal ulcers and helicobacter pylori infections, amoxicillin can be used.
  • Adults—20 milligrams (mg) or one capsule of omeprazole, 1000 mg or two capsules of amoxicillin, and 500 mg or one tablet of clarithromycin taken twice daily for ten days as a single dose.
  • When used alone, more than 2 g of amoxicillin per day does not affect H pylori eradication.
  • However, when combined with omeprazole, the concentration of amoxicillin in the gastric juice and its eradication efficacy increases significantly.

Option A: 500mg BD

  • When the amoxicillin dose was increased from 500 mg twice daily, CBS plus metronidazole eradication rates have been variable, with no consistent trend indicating that more frequent or more significant amounts of metronidazole are required to improve eradication efficacy.
  • Amoxicillin 500mg every 8 hours (or three times a day) or 875 mg every 12 hours is the recommended dose for a moderate chest infection in an average healthy adult.

Option B: 500mg TDS

  • Amoxicillin is typically administered three times per day.
  • Distribute the doses evenly throughout the day. Adults, for example, who have been prescribed an amount three times per day, could take one at 7 a.m., one at 3 p.m., and one at 11 p.m.

Option D: 1g OD

  • Taking one extra dose of the antibiotic or less by mistake is unlikely to cause serious harm.
  • However, it will increase the chances of experiencing side effects such as stomach pain, diarrhoea, and feeling or being sick.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presents to the gynaecology department with a complaint of bone pain. After making a thorough assessment, a diagnosis of post-menopausal osteoporosis has been made. The patient has been given Raloxifene. Which of the following is least likely associated with Raloxifene?

choices.text: It acts as an estrogen agonist in bone
It exerts estrogen-antagonistic action on the endometrium
It increases the risk of developing breast cancer
It can induce/aggravate menopausal hot flushes

questions.solution:
Option C: It increases the risk of developing breast cancer

  • Raloxifene decreases the risk of breast cancer as it has antagonist action in the breast
  • Selective estrogen receptor modulators:
    • Selective ER modulators (SERMs) are nonhormonal pharmacological agents that bind to ERs.
    • A characteristic feature of the SERMs is that a given agent will act as an estrogen agonist in one or more tissues and as an estrogen antagonist in one or more other estrogen-target organs.
    • Tamoxifen citrate, clomiphene citrate and Raloxifene are examples of nonsteroidal SERMs.
    • Tamoxifen is a partial estrogen agonist in the breast and thus is used as a treatment and chemopreventative for breast cancer.
    • Tamoxifen is a full agonist in bone and endometrium, and prolonged use of tamoxifen leads to a fourfold to fivefold increase in the incidence of endometrial cancer.
    • Raloxifene is a new SERM approved for use in the treatment and prevention of osteoporosis because it has estrogenic activity in bone.
    • Raloxifene is an estrogen antagonist in both breast and endometrial tissues.
    • The estrogen-like properties of Raloxifene result in the maintenance of a favourable serum lipid profile (decreased low-density lipoprotein levels with no change in either high-density lipoproteins or triglycerides).
    • Raloxifene is 95% bound to plasma proteins.
    • Absorption of Raloxifene is impaired by cholestyramine.
    • Tamoxifen, clomiphene, and Raloxifene are orally active.
    • The primary route of excretion of all three drugs is in the faeces.
    • The undesirable effects common to all three of these SERMs are increased
    • frequency of hot flashes and increased risk of thromboembolism.
    • Both effects are attributable to their estrogenic activity.
    • Fulvestrant is a SERM with no known agonist activity in the ER.
    • It is administered as a monthly injection.
    • Phase III clinical trials showed good activity against advanced breast cancer.

 

Option A: It acts as an estrogen agonist in bone

  • Raloxifene has an agonist effect on the bone.
  • Therefore, it is used in the post-menopausal osteoporosis

 

Option B: It exerts estrogen-antagonistic action on the endometrium

  • Raloxifene has antagonist action on the endometrium
  • It also exerts a negative effect on the endometrium

 

Option D: It can induce/aggravate menopausal hot flushes

  • Raloxifene has been shown to increase hot flashes symptoms.
  • This is likely due to the antagonist action of the Raloxifene.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the diabetic clinic for a follow-up appointment. She takes 20 units of intermediate-acting insulin twice a day. Her recent renal function tests show a GFR of 30 ml/min/1.73 m2. What adjustment in insulin dosage is required?

choices.text: Decrease in the morning dose only

questions.solution:
Option B: Decrease the dose of insulin

  • The kidney plays a vital role in the clearance and degradation of circulating insulin and is also an important site of insulin action.
  • 60% of the insulin is cleared from the body via glomerular filtration and 40% by active secretion in the distal tubules.
  • No dose adjustment is required if the GFR is more than 50 mL/min/1.73m2.
  • If GFR is less than 50 mL/min, then the insulin dose should be reduced as it increases the half-life of insulin in the body and predisposes individuals to recurrent hypoglycemia.

 

Option A: Increase the dose of insulin

  • The patient has chronic kidney disease and markedly deranged renal function (GFR 30ml/min).
  • The current dose of insulin is already more than his requirements since the half-life of insulin is increased; therefore, the patient needs a reduction in the dose of insulin instead of an increase in dose.

 

Option C: Decrease in the morning dose only

  • The patient has chronic kidney disease and markedly deranged renal function (GFR 30ml/min).
  • The current dose of insulin is already more than his requirements since the half-life of insulin is increased; therefore, the patient needs a reduction in the complete dose of insulin. Reduction in only the morning dose is not logical since the removal of insulin from the circulation is reduced irrespective of the time of the day.

 

Option D: No alteration in the dose

  • In patients of chronic kidney disease in whom the GFR is < 50ml/min/1.73m2, insulin clearance from the body is reduced markedly, predisposing them to recurrent hypoglycemia.
  • This patient has a GFR of 30ml/min/1.73m2. If the dose of insulin is not decreased, it will increase the risk of recurrent hypoglycemia in the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Lorazepam and the drugs in its class?

choices.text: The antidote for these is protamine sulphate

questions.solution:
Option C: These act as GABA facilitators

  • Barbiturates bind to the GABA-BZD-Cl channel complex and exert GABA mimetic (direct activation of GABAA receptors) and GABA facilitatory actions.
  • Benzodiazepines bind to a different site (BZD receptor) and increase the binding of GABA to the GABA-A receptor (GABA facilitation effect). These drugs increase the opening frequency of the Cl–channel.
  • Benzodiazepines(BZDs) are preferred over barbiturates as hypnotics for several reasons:-
    • BZDs have flat dose-response curves (these have a high therapeutic index and require a high dose to induce coma).
    • These cause fewer hangovers and less disruption of sleep architecture. The duration of REM sleep is shortened, but the increase in the number of REM cycles compensates for this. Nitrazepam increases REM sleep.
    • These are less prone to drug interactions (because they do not induce microsomal enzymes).
    • Liability for abuse is less.
    • BZD poisoning can be treated with a specific antidote, flumazenil.

Option A: These are very dangerous drugs

  • BZDs have flat dose-response curves (these have a high therapeutic index and require a high dose to induce coma).
  • Thus, the safety index for BZD is good.

Option B: These are strong enzyme inducers

  • These are less prone to drug interactions (because they do not induce microsomal enzymes).

Option D: The antidote for these is protamine sulfate

  • BZD poisoning can be treated with a specific antidote, flumazenil

questions.text: Heparin mainly inhibits which coagulation factor?
questions.solution:
Option C: Factor Xa

  • This is a case of deep vein thrombosis in which a bed-bound patient presents with complaints of leg swelling.
  • Normally, antithrombin III inactivates factors Xa and IIa (thrombin), but the reaction is very slow.
  • Heparin accelerates this inactivation process by binding to Antithrombin III.
  • Anticoagulants are classified into two: Indirect thrombin inhibitors and direct thrombin inhibitors.
  • Indirect thrombin inhibitors include heparin (unfractionated), low molecular weight heparin, fondaparinux, and danaparoid.
  • Low molecular weight heparin includes enoxaparin, reviparin, nadroparin, dalteparin, parnaparin, and ardeparin.
  • It acts indirectly by activating plasma antithrombin III.
  • The heparin-ATIII complex binds to clotting factors of intrinsic and common pathways (Xa, IIa, IXa, XIa, XIIa, and XIIIa) and inactivates them.
  • The anticoagulant action is exerted mainly by inhibiting factor Xa as well as thrombin-IIa mediated conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin.
  • Indications for LMW heparins include prevention of DVT and pulmonary embolism, treatment of established DVT, unstable angina, and MI.

Option A: Factor IIIa

  • Clotting factor-IIIa is also known as thromboplastin.
  • It primarily initiates the extrinsic coagulation pathway.
  • Heparin does not inhibit clotting factors of the extrinsic pathway.

Option B: Factor VIIIa

  • Clotting factor VIIIa is also known as the anti-hemophilic factor (AHF).
  • The F8 gene encodes this factor, which, if defective, will result in haemophilia A, an X-linked disorder.
  • As this factor belongs to the intrinsic pathway, it might get secondarily affected by heparin. But the main factor that gets inhibited is factor Xa.

Option D: Factor XIIa

  • Factor XIIa, an active form of factor XII (Hageman factor), belongs to the intrinsic coagulation pathway.
  • Heparin also accelerates the inhibition rate of factor XIIa, but it mainly inhibits factor Xa.

questions.text: A 19-year-old medical student presents to an emergency department with delirium, fever, severe headache, and neck pain. There is a high suspicion of meningitis. The sample was stripped to identify the causative organism, and the results are shown in the image below. Identify the staining preparation.
questions.solution:
Option B: Negative staining

  • The staining preparation shown above is Negative staining / India ink staining.
  • Negative staining needs an acidic dye such as India Ink or Nigrosin.
  •  The acidic stain readily gives up a proton, and the chromophore of the dye becomes negatively charged. As the surface of most bacteria is negatively charged, the cell surface repels the stain, and the bacteria remain clear of the stain. On the other hand, the slide's glass is stained with dye. The bacteria will appear as clear spots against a dark background.
  • The diagram demonstrates the capsule, which appears refractile, the delineated clear space surrounding Cryptococcus's round budding yeast cell against the black background.

Option A: Gram staining

  • Gram staining is a common technique used to differentiate two significant groups of bacteria based on their different cell wall constituents.
  •  The Gram stain differentiates Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria by colouring these cells in red or violet.
  • Gram-positive bacteria stain violet due to a thick layer of peptidoglycan in their cell walls, which retains the crystal violet.
  • On the other hand, Gram-negative bacteria stain red due to a thinner peptidoglycan wall, which does not retain the crystal violet during the decolouring process.
  • Initially, the cells are stained with crystal violet dye. Then, a Gram's iodine solution comprising iodine and potassium iodide is added to form a complex between the crystal violet and iodine.
  • After that, a decolourizer such as ethyl alcohol or acetone is added to the sample, dehydrating the peptidoglycan layer and shrinking and tightening it.
  •  The large crystal violet-iodine complex cannot penetrate this tightened peptidoglycan layer and is thus trapped in the Gram-positive bacteria cell.
  • On the other hand, the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria is degraded, and the thinner peptidoglycan layer of Gram-negative can not retain the crystal violet-iodine complex, and the colour is lost.
  • In the end, a counterstain, such as safranin, is added to the sample, staining red. Since safranin is lighter than crystal violet, it does not disrupt the purple colouration in Gram-positive cells. However, the decolourized Gram-negative cells are stained red.

Option C: Z. N. staining

  • The Ziehl-Neelsen staining technique is a differential technique also known as acid-fast stain due to the use of acid alcohol.
  • This technique is used on microorganisms not easily stained by basic stains such as negative or  Gram staining.
  • One of the most complex microorganisms that require Ziehl-Neelsen compounds is the Mycobacterium.
  • Mycobacterium, Actinomycetes, Norcadia, Isospora, Cryptosporidium, and some fungi contain a thick cell wall containing mycolic acid.
  • Mycolic acid is difficult to stain; therefore, superficial stains like gram staining can not penetrate the thick cell wall of these organisms.
  • They require harsher treatments to allow stain penetration for identification and examination, hence the use of the Ziehl-Neelsen or the hot method of Acid-fast stain.

Option D: Wayson staining

  • The Wayson stain is a basic fuchsin-methylene blue staining procedure to detect Yersinia pestis.
  • The presence of a central vacuole provides a characteristic safety pin appearance to Yersinia pestis.

questions.text: A young female brought her 5-year-old boy to the emergency department complaining of stomach pain, watery diarrhoea, loss of appetite, and vomiting. The sample was sent to the laboratory for diagnosis. The causative organism showed effacement and attachment of intestinal cells, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Option A: EPEC

  • The above is infectious diarrhoea by EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli).
  • The organism which shows effacement and attachment of intestinal cells is EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli).
  • Enteropathogenic E.coli (EPEC) causes attaching and effacing lesions.
  • Paediatric age group diarrhoea (infantile) by attaching to enterocytes and causing their effacement.
  • Factors which promote attachment and effacement (loss of microvilli) are:
    • Bundle-forming pilus encoded by a plasmid EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
    • Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE).

Option B: ETEC

  • ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E.coli) causes attachment through CFA (colonization factor antigen).

Option C: EHEC

  • EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E.coli) causes VT (verotoxin) mediated capillary microangiopathy.

Option D: V. Cholerae.

  • Vibrio cholerae lives in contaminated water.

  • It enters the human body by the consumption of uncooked seafood (e.g., raw shellfish).

  • Vibrio cholerae is a Facultative anaerobe, Oxidase positive, and Straight or curved (comma) shaped bacteria.

  • It has a Polar flagellum.

  • Grows in alkaline media → acid-labile →requires a large infectious dose.

  • Cholera toxin (enterotoxin) is a protein that causes “rice-water” diarrhoea.

  • It causes bacterial gastroenteritis.

  • Fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin)

questions.text: A 22-years-old female presents to the physician with complaints of sore throat and swelling of the neck for four days. The patient is vitally stable. On examination, there is pseudo membrane and bull neck formation. The doctor suspects it to be caused by an organism which produces toxins. On culture examination, Gram-positive bacilli were seen in a cuneiform pattern of the arrangement. Which of the following is the organism involved in the patient's pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option A: C. diphtheriae

  • This is a case of diphtheria in which the patient presents with complaints of sore throat and swelling in the neck for four days.

  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae bacteria cause diphtheria.

  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae is a toxin-producing bacteria.

  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae is arranged in a Cuneiform pattern.

Mechanism of Action of diphtheria toxin:

  • Strong exotoxin.

  • Has two fragments:

  • Fragment A (active unit)

  • Fragment A is internalized into the host cells and then causes→ ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2(EF2) → Inhibition of EF2 → Irreversible inhibition of translation step of protein synthesis→ cell death.

  • Fragment B (binding unit)

  • Binds to the host cell receptors (such as epidermal growth factor)

  • Helps in the entry of fragment A.

Other Options

Option B: C. jeikeium

  • Corynebacterium jeikeium usually causes opportunistic infections in humans.

Option C: C. hofmanni

  • Corynebacterium doesn't produce toxins.

  • It also doesn't cause diphtheria.

Option D: C. minutissimum

  • It causes Erythrasma

  • Coral red fluorescence is seen.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to a rural hospital in Ghana with fever, mucopurulent discharge, pain during sex, and generalised malaise. Upon lab examination, Neisseria gonorrhoeae is found to be the causative agent from the specimen. It is resistant to penicillin, ciprofloxacin, and cotrimoxazole. Which of the following virulent factor is not included in this pathogen?
questions.solution:
Option C: M protein

  • It is the case in which the causative agent is Neisseria gonorrhoea. It is gram-negative diplococci that are usually non-capsulated. It is a kidney-shaped bacteria.
  • These symptoms present the picture of cervicitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It is a condition in which inflammation of the cervix occurs.
  • Myeloma protein is an essential virulent factor. Viruses and bacteria are usually coated in protein or sugar molecules that gain their entry into the host organism. M protein is such a molecule, and it is highly anti-phagocytic.
  • M protein is a virulent factor but not for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It acts as an infectious factor for Streptococcus pyrogens which belongs to the group of A streptococci.

Option A: Outer membrane proteins

  • It is one of the virulent factors of gonococci. They serve as a nutrient scavenging and evasion from the host defense mechanism.
  • It includes various proteins, such as porin(protein 1), which forms membrane channels or pores. Protein 2, also called opacity-associated protein, helps in adhesion and invasions. Transferrin-binding and lactoferrin-binding protein is required for the uptake of iron.

Option B: IgA protease

  • This virulent factor also includes the group of gonococci. They hinge on the function of human IgA1, causing the elimination of the host defense.
  • It degrades the mucosal IgA antibody. It also acts as an autotransporter protein as its gene encodes to direct its secretion outside the cell.

Option D: Pilli

  • It is a principal virulent factor of the gonococci. Pili helps the bacteria attach in vitro to the human epithelial cells and evade phagocytosis.
  • It also helps in the adhesion and motility of the cells.

questions.text: A 55-year-old hospital worker from Mumbai came to the medical OPD complaining of fever with rigours, weight loss, night sweats, tiredness and fatigue and loss of appetite for the past three months. Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection spread through inhaling tiny droplets from the coughs or sneezes of an infected person. Chest X-ray reveals segmental consolidation and mediastinal lymphadenopathy associated with pleural effusion. One of the drugs given in the 2 months of intensive phase is bacteriostatic, i.e., it inhibits mycobacterial growth without actively killing the bacteria. Which one is that mentioned drug in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ethambutol

  • The patient here is suffering from Pulmonary TB.
  • In the intensive phase of tuberculosis (TB) treatment, the combination of drugs used includes isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. Among these drugs, ethambutol is considered bacteriostatic.
  • Ethambutol's mechanism of action is not completely understood; however, there is evidence that it works by inhibiting proper mycobacterial cell wall synthesis.
  • The mechanism of action is shown below:

 


 

  • It is a bacteriostatic antitubercular medication.

Option A: Isoniazid

  • Also works by inhibiting the mycobacterial cell wall.
  • It is a bactericidal drug.

Option B: Rifampicin

  • Works by inhibiting transcription of mycobacterial DNA into RNA.
  • It is a bactericidal drug.
  • Patients can complain of side effects like dark-colored or red-colored urine.

Option D: Pyrazinamide

  • Bactericidal to M.tuberculosis.
  • Has an unknown mechanism of action.
  • Usually given in the intensive phase of treatment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who has had HIV for 2 years and has a CD4 count of 150 cells//µL presents with the complaint of fatigue, weight loss, and cough for several days. He is also complaining of chest tightness on breathing. The patient says that the symptoms are getting worse every day. The doctor ordered sputum microscopy. The Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain of his sample showed black-coloured cysts, as shown in the image below. Select the true statement about the pathogen causing the above-mentioned disease as shown in the image.

choices.text: Ampicillin is the drug of choice
Occurs in patients with CD4+ count 400/µL

questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option A: Stain : - Gomori Methenamine Silver (GMS)

The given image shows Pneumocystis jirovecii

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii (previously known as Pneumocystis carinii) causes PCP (Pneumocystis pneumonia)
  • It most commonly infects HIV patients (with CD4+ cell count below 200/µL) and patients on long-term immunosuppressive regimens.
  • It mostly affects only immunocompromised individuals.
  • Patients with hematologic and non-hematologic malignancies.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiographs show perihilar haziness with diffuse mottling.
  • Sputum induced by inhalation of a hypertonic saline solution is a useful specimen for microscopic demonstration of the organism.
  • Gomori’s methenamine silver (GMS) staining is the method of choice to demonstrate the cysts of P. jirovecii. The cysts resemble black-coloured crushed ping-pong balls against the green background.
  • Cotrimoxazole is the DOC for Pneumocystis pneumonia.

Image: The spore cases (cysts) of pneumocystis stained with the Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain.

Other Options

Option B: Ampicillin is the drug of choice

  • The drug of choice for pneumocystis jirovecii is amphotericin B.
  • Ampicillin is the drug of choice in infections caused by a beta-lactamase-negative type of H. influenza, enterococci, and L. monocytogenes.

Option C: Occurs in patients with CD4+ count 400/µL

  • It usually occurs in patients with a CD4+ count below 200/µL.
  • Recurrent bacterial pneumonia occurs when CD 4 count is 200-500/ µL.

Option D: Diagnosed on X-Ray imaging

  • This disease is most commonly diagnosed through sputum microscopy.
  • The X-ray can show consolidation, but diagnosis is confirmed by sputum culture,

questions.text: A 25-year-old female complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, and bilateral nasal blockage for one year. She has had a history of asthma and allergy since childhood. On examination, multiple ethmoidal polyps are noted with mucosal thickening and secretions are impacted in both nasal cavities. A biopsy is taken, and the material is cultured, which shows the growth of many hyphae with dichotomous branching, typically at 45 degrees. Which of the following is the most likely responsible organism for causing the disease?
questions.solution:
Option A: Aspergillus fumigatus

  • The most likely responsible organism is Aspergillus fumigatus.
  • Key points towards diagnosis:
    • Recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, bilateral nasal blockade.
    • History of asthma and allergy
    • Hyphae with dichotomous branching at 45 degree

  • All symptoms point towards Aspergillus infection.
  • It is the most common type of fungal infection of the nose, and paranasal sinuses due to Aspergillus.
  • Aspergillus has septate hyphae that branch typically at 45 degrees (V-shaped).
  • Hyphae with dichotomous branching at 45 degrees

 

Option B: Rhizopus

  • Broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching are seen in members of Zygomycetes. i.e. Rhizopus.
  • Rhizopus is a fungus that can cause systemic mucormycosis.
  • This can exist in multiple forms like Rhinocerebral mucormycosis, disseminated, pulmonary, dermal, and cutaneous.
  • Rhinocerebral zygomycosis is a serious fulminating infection, angioinvasive, thrombosis, and ischaemic tissue necrosis.

Option C: Mucor

  • Broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching are seen in members of Zygomycetes. i.e. Mucor
  • Mucormycosis (previously called Zygomycosis) is serious fulminant sinusitis but a rare fungal infection caused by a group of moulds called Mucormycetes
  • Treatment is by the combination of anti-fungal therapy, surgical debridement, and elimination of predisposing factors.

Option D: Candida

  • Candida: Gram-positive oval budding yeast cell with pseudohyphae.
  • It is a normal commensal of the oral cavity, gut, and vagina.
  • It causes problems only if the immunity is decreased or normal skin or mucous membrane is breached.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of loose stools, fever,  and lower abdominal pain. The rest of the vital signs are within normal limits except for the temperature (100°F). The patient is asked for stool examination, and the results show the presence of leukocytes, which raised suspicion of amoebic dysentery. Which of the following statements best describes intestinal amoebae?

choices.text: They can cause peritonitis and liver abscesses.
Quadrinucleate cyst is an infective form.

questions.solution:
Option B: Cyst is the invasive form

  • The stool examination for faecal leukocytes is the diagnostic test to separate invasive from secretory diarrhoea.

Amoebic dysentery:

  • It is a gastrointestinal illness which is caused by E. histolytica and spreads through human faeces.
  • Symptoms include loose stool, nausea, fever and stomach cramps.

 

E. histolytica:

  • A protozoan parasite that is able to inhabit the human intestine and cause amoebic dysentery.
  • The life cycle starts when food or water contaminated with the faeces of a person infected with E. histolytica is ingested.
  • It contains the inactive form of quadrinucleate (four nuclei) cyst and releases the trophozoite stage (active form) in the digestive tract by the process of excystation in the small intestine.
  • During excystation, 8 small metacystic trophozoites are formed.
  • The presence of infection can also be asymptomatic, and the infected person may seem healthy but will be the carrier of infection.
  • However, if the infection spreads, trophozoites may reach the bloodstream. From the bloodstream, it spreads to the vital organs, mostly the liver and sometimes to the lungs, brain and spleen.
  • Under unfavourable conditions, they again form quadrinucleate cysts, which are released outside by faeces, and the cycle continues.

Option A: They are usually non-pathogenic.

Following are the intestinal amoebae:

  • Entamoeba hartmanni,
  • Escherichia coli, 
  • Entamoeba Polecki
  • Endolimax nana
  • Entamoeba histolytica 

Except for E. histolytica, all others are considered to be non-pathogenic.

Option C: They can cause peritonitis and liver abscesses.

  • Peritonitis and liver abscesses are common in diseases which are extra-intestinal.
  • Amoebic dysentery is an intestinal infection.

Option D: Quadrinucleate cyst is an infective form.

  • A quadrinucleate cyst is an infective form, but the spread of infection is due to active cyst trophozoites, which invade the vital organs of the body.

questions.text: A 29-year-old forest officer came to the clinic complaining of high-grade fever, chills, intense frontal headache, severe myalgia, body aches, vomiting, and other gastrointestinal symptoms for 5 days. On examination, his temperature is 1010 F, his pulse is 94 beats/min, his blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg, and his respiratory rate is 18 breaths /minute. The doctor suspected it as kyasanur forest disease. Which of the following statement is true about the given condition?

choices.text: The virus causing this is a positive strand DNA virus
Hemorrhagic manifestation is the most common complication

questions.solution:
Option C: Hemorrhagic manifestation is the most common complication

  • Genus Hepacivirus, The single-stranded RNA virus family Flaviviridae, causes Kyasanur forest disease.
  • The most common hemorrhagic manifestations are mild and include a positive tourniquet test, skin haemorrhages (petechiae, hematomas), epistaxis (nose bleed), gingival bleeding (gum bleed), and microscopic hematuria
  • Flaviviruses carry a methylated nucleotide capsule, while other members of this family are uncapped
  • There are 89 species in the family Flaviviridae, divided into four genera :
  1. Genus Flavivirus
  2. Genus Hepacivirus
  3. Genus Pegivirus
  4. Genus Pestivirus
  • Other complications of this disease include:
    1. Aseptic meningitis
    2. Focal neurological deficit
    3. Seizures
  • The vector for a disease transmitted by Haemaphysalis spinigera is a tick.
  • Monkeys are the main amplifying hosts in the case of the KFD virus and are also affected by the virus.
  • The virus is transmitted from the infected monkeys to the humans after contact.

Option A: Transmitted by a person-to-person contact

  • They are mainly spread through arthropod vectors, mainly from ticks and mosquitoes.
  • The vector for a disease transmitted by Haemaphysalis spinigera is a tick.
  • Humans suffer from infection from the bite of the immature form of the ticks.
  • They are not transmitted by person-to-person contact.

Option B: The virus causing this is a positive strand DNA virus

  • The single-stranded RNA virus family Flaviviridae causes Kyasanur forest disease.
  • Virus particles are covered with capsules and spherical icosahedral-like geometries with pseudo T=3 symmetry.
  • They are about 40–60 nm in diameter.
  • Flaviviruses carry a methylated nucleotide capsule, while other members of this family are uncapped

Option D: Man is the common host

  • Monkeys are the main amplifying hosts in the case of the KFD virus and are also affected by the virus.
  • The virus is transmitted from the infected monkeys to the humans after contact.
  • Man is a terminal host, and there is no human-to-human transmission because the human domestic environment does not sustain the ticks.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of a tender rash on his right hand and painless lesions on the tip of his penis for one week. He further explains that the rash continued to enlarge and became pruritic even after initial treatment. The patient is homosexual. He is vitally stable, and other general examinations reveal no abnormalities. The doctor sent him for VDRL testing. What type of antigen-antibody reaction is seen in the investigation involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Slide flocculation

  • This is a case of syphilis in which the patient complains of a tender rash on his right hand and a painless lesion on the tip of the penis for one week.
  • Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease.
  • It is caused due to bacteria treponema pallidum.
  • VDRL is a slide flocculation test.
  • Flocculation: Soluble antigen binds to the antibody (at optimal temperature, pH, electrolytes) to form floccules.
  • Slide flocculation test: VDRL and RPR tests are used to diagnose syphilis.
  • VDRL slide: Refer to the image below.

Option A: Slide agglutination

  • Agglutination: Insoluble (Particulate) antigen binds to the antibody (at optimal temperature, pH, electrolytes) to form clumps.
  • Slide agglutination tests:
  • Slide widal test
  • Serotyping
  • Blood grouping

Option B: Tube agglutination

  • Tube agglutination is routinely used for:
    • Typhoid fever (Widal test): Detects Ab against both H (flagellar) and O (somatic) Ag.
    • Acute brucellosis (Standard agglutination test).

Option D: Tube flocculation

  • Tube flocculation test: Kahn test was used previously for syphilis.

questions.text: The body of the 27-year-old woman has been recovered from the site where it was buried after the suspect confessed to the crime. Autopsy findings suggest that the woman has been physically and sexually assaulted but death has occurred secondary to traumatic asphyxia. Traumatic asphyxia is a type of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Suffocation

  • Suffocation is a form of asphyxia caused by mechanical obstruction to the passage of air into the respiratory tract by means other than constriction of the neck or drowning.
  • Classification: Smothering; choking; gagging; overlying; traumatic asphyxia; burking.
  • Traumatic asphyxia: Asphyxia resulting from respiratory arrest due to mechanical fixation of the chest, so that the normal movements of the chest wall are prevented. One man does smothering while another seating over his chest causing traumatic asphyxia.

Option A: Hanging

  • Hanging is a form of asphyxia caused by the suspension of the body by a ligature that encircles the neck, the constricting force being at least part of the weight of the body.

Option B: Ligature Strangulation

  • A strangulation is a form of violent asphyxial death caused by constriction of air passage at the neck by means of a ligature or by any means other than suspension of the body.
  • Classification: Ligature strangulation, manual strangulation or throttling, mugging, bansdola, garroting, etc.
  • Ligature strangulation: When ligature material is used to compress the neck.

Option D: Manual strangulation

  • Manual strangulation or throttling: When human fingers, palms or hands are used to compress the neck.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions favour mummification?
questions.solution:
Option B: Absence of moisture

  • Ideal conditions for mummification: High temperature, dry condition, absence of moisture, and free circulation of air.

Option A: Warm & Humid climate

  • A warm & humid climate favours adipocere, not mummification.

Option C: Clostridium perfringes

  • Clostridium perfringes favour adipocere, not mummification.

Option D: Intrinsic Lipases

  • Intricis lipases favour adipocere, not mummification.
  • Ideal conditions for Adipocere formation: Warm temperature, moisture, less air, bacteria, and fat-splitting enzymes (lipases).

questions.text: Mark the false statement about neonatal line :

choices.text: Incremental line found on the surface of tooth enamel that indicates that an infant was born live
Counting perikymata can provide an accurate method of age determination
Grossly can be seen in about 4 weeks after birth

questions.solution:
Neonatal line

  • Incremental line found on the surface of tooth enamel(perikymata) that indicates that an infant was live born.
  • Provide an accurate method of age determination
  • Neonatal line is formed very soon after birth.
  • Grossly can be seen in about 3 weeks
  • By electron microscopy within 1-2 days after birth.
  • It is useful to estimate the age of a dead infant.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has been accused of rape by his 26-year-old female friend. The woman allegedly was lured by the man on a pretext of helping with an assignment but had later spiked her drink and raped her while she was unconscious. The team has taken swabs of his urethral lining to test for the presence of vaginal cells. The test that would be done for the same is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lugol’s iodine test

  • Lugol’s iodine test is to detect vaginal epithelial cells containing glycogen.

Option B: Takayama test

  • Takayama test is to detect blood stains.

Option C: Florence test

  • Florence test is a test for seminal stain.

Option D: Precipitin test

  • Species identification is done by the precipitin test.

questions.text: Role of sodium fluoride as a preservative for blood in viscera packing are all except?
questions.solution:
Option B: Acts as anti-coagulant

  • Sodium fluoride doesn't act as anti-coagulant.
  • Potassium oxalate act as anticoagulant, should be used for preserving blood.

Option A/C/D: It prevents glycolysis/ Inhibits bacterial growth/ Inhibits enolase enzyme

  • 10 mg/ml of sodium or potassium fluoride prevents glycolysis, inhibits enzyme enolase, and inhibits bacterial growth.

questions.text: In a 54-year-old man diagnosed with dilated cardiomyopathy, who is a non-smoker but consumes one pint of beer thrice a week and presents with severe left ventricular dysfunction, worsening shortness of breath and difficulty in walking 100 meters or taking bath on his own for the past 2 months  doctor diagnosed him with "Beer drinker's heart" is associated with which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cobalt:

  • Regular consumption of beer to which cobalt chloride or sulfate has been added (to enhance foaming) over a period of time can result in cardiomyopathy, referred to as beer drinker’s heart which carries a relatively high mortality of nearly 50%.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Copper:

  • Vineyard sprayer lung: Due to inhalation of copper sulphate spray and characterized by histiocytic granulomatous lung.
  • Kayser-Fleischer Ring is seen in Copper poisoning.
  • Gastric lavage with 1% potassium ferrocyanide, which acts as an antidote by forming cupric ferrocyanide (insoluble). If not available, plain water can be used.
  • Chelating agents: D-penicillamine given in usual doses is very effective.

Option B - Magnesium:

  • Magnesium toxicity or hypermagnesemia, generally occurs when magnesium is ingested in large quantities as a supplement or medication.
  • Symptoms including diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal cramping after taking a magnesium-base laxative or antacid may indicate excessive magnesium or magnesium toxicity.

Option C - Molybdenum:

  • Molybdenum toxicity is associated with copper intake or depleted copper stores in the body, humans who have an inadequate intake of dietary copper or some dysfunction in their copper metabolism that makes them copper-deficient could be at greater risk of molybdenum toxicity.
  • Excessive intake of molybdenum can cause copper deficiency, which may lead to anemia.
  • Other possible symptoms of molybdenum toxicity involve joint and muscle pain, weakness, fatigue, loose stool, and weight loss.

questions.text: 20 pregnant women were asked about their history of smoking when they came for a regular antenatal visit and then followed up to see how many of them had low birth weight babies. What is the type of study?
questions.solution:
• 20 pregnant women were asked about their history of smoking when they came for a regular antenatal visit and then followed up to see how many of them had low birth weight babies.
  • Since the persons with exposure were followed to see the occurrence of the disease, this is an example of a Prospective Cohort.
  • Prospective cohort study
    • This study design gives us incidence and RR which is very accurate.
    • Advantage is very accurate.
    • Major disadvantage is time taking.
  • Retrospective Cohort Study
    • The combination of prospective cohort study and case-control study is known as a retrospective cohort study.
    • This study gives Incidence, RR, AR, PAR, and this study also saves time.
  • Mixed Cohort Study
    • Combination of both retrospective & prospective cohort study.
    • Mixed cohort study is the cohort study because the direction is from exposure to outcome.

questions.text: In a study carried out prospectively, out of 1000 truck drivers who were using mobile while driving, 300 met an accident. During the same period, out of 5000 truck drivers who were not using mobile while driving, 300 met an accident. What is the Relative Risk?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: 5

  • Exposure is mobile usage while driving, the incidence of accidents under consideration is that of:
  • Incidence of exposure (IE)= 300/1000
  • Incidence of non-exposed (INE) = 300/5000
  • RR (Relative Risk) = = 5 (thus mobile usage is associated with 5 times increased incidence of accident).

questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to draw some study designs. Identify the study design given in the image below?
questions.solution:
Option D - Nested case-control study

  • The given image depicts a Nested case-control study.
  • Nested case-control study:
  • - Type of cohort Study
  • Temporality → forward-looking study
  • Only done in
    • New & Rare diseases
    • If Diagnostic tests are very Expensive.
  • It is a small case-control study that is nested in a big cohort study.

Other options

Option A - Cross-sectional study

  • Cross-sectional study:
    • Aka Snapshot study/ Prevalence study (as prevalence is calculated).
    • Done at point of time (neither forward, nor backward).
    • Based on primary data.
    • Can't calculate the strength of association.

Option B - Retrospective cohort study

  • Retrospective Cohort Study
    • The combination of a prospective cohort study and case-control study is known as a retrospective cohort study.
    • This study gives Incidence, RR, AR, PAR, and this study also saves time.

Option C - Case-control, study

  • Case-control study is better for rare diseases.
  • Case-control study has 2 groups
    1. Cases: Having the disease
    2. Controls: They are comparison groups not having the disease
  • We ask about the history of the same exposure in both groups & then compare both groups.

questions.text: A community medicine intern was asked to compare two study patterns. As compared to a routine case-control study, a Nested case-control study avoids problems related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Temporal association

  • In Nested case-control studies, the exposure has been either measured before the study itself or the samples have been collected, so that the findings cannot change due to any bias.
  • Temporal association
    • It implies that the suspected cause comes before the observed effect or that the effect comes after the alleged cause.
    • It is the most crucial criterion for determining causality.
    • The best way to find out is to do a concurrent cohort study.

Option B: Confounding bias

  • Confounding: Any factor associated both with exposure as well as the outcome.
  • Confounding leads to wrong results or errors.
  • Confounding bias is not reduced by the Nested case-control study.

Option C: Need for long follow up

  • Since a nested case-control study is part of a cohort study, it actually takes more time.
  • In a Nested case-control study, interviews are performed at the beginning of the study (at baseline), and data are obtained before the disease has developed, thereby eliminating the problem of Recall bias.

Option D: Randomization

  • Randomization is not involved in a nested case-control study.

questions.text: Clinical trials of a drug were being recorded. Good clinical practices (GCP) are not a part of which of the following?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option D: Pre–Clinical Trials

  • Before doing a trial of a new drug in humans, preclinical trials should be conducted on animals.
  • Pre-clinical trials are performed on animals (lab– experiments/lab– trials), so good clinical practices (GCP) are not required.
  • Many properties of the drug become clear, after preclinical trials in animals.

Option A: Phase I Clinical Trials

  • Phase I (healthy human volunteers), Phase II, III, and IV (patients) require GCP.
  • Used to evaluate the Maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of a new drug.
  • Healthy human volunteers are used.
  • It is done for safety and non-toxicity.

Option B: Phase II Clinical Trials

  • Maximum drug failure in the drug is seen in Phase 2.
  • Phase 2 is done on patients to know the efficacy of the drug.

Option C: Phase IV Clinical Trials

  • Post-marketing surveillance is done under phase 4 of the trial.
  • Phase 4 is the longest trial.
  • Long-term and rare side effects are identified.

questions.text: What is the study unit in the ecological study?
questions.solution:
Option A: Population

  • The study unit in an ecological study is a population.
  • Since the unit of Ecological study is population, results cannot be applied at the individual level. This is known as ECOLOGICAL FALLACY.

Option B: Patients

  • Patients are units of study in the randomized controlled trial.

Option C: Community

  • Community is the unit of study in the community trails.

questions.text: Gujarat recently reported an massive earthquake disaster causing loss of life and leading to sufferings. Which of the following is the most common reported disease in post disaster period?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acute Gastroenteritis

  • Most Common reported disease in post disaster phase is Acute Gastroenteritis, Typhoid & Cholera.

Learning Objective

  • Most Common reported disease in post disaster phase is Acute Gastroenteritis, Typhoid & Cholera.
  • Most important step during Post-disaster phase is, Chlorination of water > Vaccination.
  • All vaccines are CI in post-disaster phase; except Measles.
  • Chairman of National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) of India is Prime Minister of India.

questions.text: A community in sub-African area has a weekly report of 50-60 malarial cases, all in children. No adult case has been reported. This week count of cases is 55. What kind of disease it would be classified as?
questions.solution:
• The above given case is an example of endemic disease as the no. of cases are still between the usually expected cases in an area and as only children are affected it is a holoendemic disease.

  • Hyperendemic disease
    • Refers to endemic disease affecting all age groups.
    • It would have been labelled as epidemic if the no. of cases show an abrupt increase than expected cases in an area.

questions.text: A diagnostic test for a particular disease has a sensitivity of 0.90 and a specificity of 0.90. A single test is applied to each subject in the population in which the diseased population is 10%. What is the probability that a person positive to this test, has the disease?
questions.solution:
BAYES' THEORM

In the given question,

  • Sensitivity=0.90=90%
  • Specificity=0.90=90%
  • Prevalence=10%

PPV = (Sensitivity*Prevalence)/ [(Sensitivity*Prevalence)] + [(100-Specificty)(100 – Prevalence)] * 100

Thus, PPV=90*10/ [90*10] + [(100-90)(100-10)]*100 = 50%(0.50)

questions.text: According to ‘The registration of births & Deaths act 1969’ Birth and death registration must be done within?
questions.solution:
Option C: 21 days each

  • According to ‘The registration of births & Deaths act 1969’ both the births and deaths are to be registered with 21 days each.
    • Marriages within 30 days/ 60 days/ 90 days.
    • Child born to NRI couple abroad, birth registration is done within 60days of arrival.
    • Birth registration is responsibility of hospital.

questions.text: Maternal mortality is defined by the World Health Organization (WHO) as "the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy. Which of the following is the most common cause of Maternal mortality in India?

questions.text: Which of the following is matched correctly?

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of Spinal cord – Vitamin B1 deficiency
Seizures in Infants – Vitamin B6 deficiency

Nutritional deficiencies -

questions.text: Strength of Sewage can be assessed by All EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Sewage → Contains 99.9% water

Strength is assessed by

1. BOD (Biological O2 Demand) - Best method

O2 absorbed by sewage at 200 C

2. COD (Chemical O2 demand)

3. Suspended solids

questions.text: A food inspector wants to monitor the quality of food supplied all over the country. For monitoring of food standards in international market, Which of the following standard is followed?
questions.solution:
(a) CODEX ALIMENTARIUS: The codex Alimentarius commission, which is the principal organ of the joint FAO/ WHO Food Standard Programme, formulates food standards for international market. The food standards in India are based on the standards of the codex alimentarius.

codex alimentarius logo" />

(b) PFA STANDARDS: Prevention of Food Adulteration Act Standard by the “Central Committee of Food Standards”. The purpose is to obtain a minimum level of quality of foodstuffs attainable under Indian conditions.

(c) AGMARK STANDARDS are set by the Directorate of Marketing Inspection of the Government of India gives the consumer an assurance of quality in accordance with the standards laid

(d) BUREAU OF INDIAN STANDARDS: guarantee of good quality accordance with the standards prescribed by the Indian Standards

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant female was found to be HIV positive in her 1st trimester. Which among the following is the correct dose of Nevirapine given to New-born for Prevention of Mother to child transmission of HIV?
questions.solution:
Option A: 2 mg/kg

  • 2 mg/kg is the correct dose of Nevirapine given to New-born for the Prevention of Mother to child transmission of HIV.
  • Nevirapine: Single oral dose
  • Mother: 200 mg at labor onset
  • Child: 2mg/kg within 72 hrs of birth

Learning Objective

Birth Weight NVP daily dose (in mg) NVP daily dose (in ml) Duration
Infants with birth weight <2000gm 2 mg/kg once daily 0.2 ml/kg once daily Upto 6 weeks irrespective of exclusively breast fed or exclusive replacement fed
Birth weight 2000 -2500gm 10 mg once daily 1 ml once daily
Birth weight more than 2500gm 15 mg once daily 1.5 ml once daily

questions.text: A 28-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after an episode of shortness of breath and palpitations. He had a history of fainting and lightheadedness previously. A series of ECGs were taken, as shown in the image below. Which is correct about the ECG shown below?
questions.solution:
