Option D: Atrial flutter 4:1 conduction

Atrial flutter

  • An atrial flutter is a form of supraventricular tachycardia. It results due to a re-entry circuit within the right atrium. The atrial rate ranges around 300 beats per minute (200-400).
  • The AV conduction ratio governs the ventricular rate. The most common ratio is 2:1, with higher degree blocks causing 3:1 or 4:1 blocks.
  • A ratio of 1:1 block can occur due to sympathetic stimulation or due to an accessory pathway. Also, AV-nodal blocking agents in a patient with WPW syndrome can cause it. A 1:1 block leads to severe hemodynamic instability and progression to ventricular fibrillation.
  • The ventricular rate is 75/min with the normal axis. Sawtooth flutter waves are seen in all leads with a 4:1 block.
  • The 4:1 block shows inverted flutter waves in II, III and aVF at a rate of 260 beats per minute. There is an upright flutter in the V1-V2 leads, and the ventricular rate is 65 beats per minute, as shown in the image above.
ECG Features
 
  • d/t large reentrant circuit in the wall of the right atrium
  • Biphasic "sawtooth" flutter waves at a rate of ~ 300 bpm
  • Usually, either a 2:1 or 4:1 block at the AV node results in ventricular rates of either 150 or 75 bpm.

Option A: P pulmonale

  • The P pulmonale is a peaked P wave produced due to right atrial enlargement.
  • The most common cause is pulmonary hypertension due to underlying chronic lung disease (cor pulmonale, tricuspid stenosis, tetralogy of Fallot, pulmonary stenosis) and pulmonary hypertension.
  • Its amplitude is:
  1. > 2.5 mm in the inferior leads (II, III and AVF)
  2. > 1.5 mm in V1 and V2

Option B: Electrical Alternans

  • It is defined as alternating QRS amplitude seen with pericardial effusion (when the heart swings backwards and forwards within a large fluid-filled pericardium).
  • It is also associated with other conditions, e.g. ventricular tachycardia, Wolff-Parkinson white and supraventricular tachycardia.

Option C: Atrial flutter 1:1 conduction

  • A 1:1 block might happen due to supplementary pathways or sympathetic activation. In a patient with WPW syndrome, AV-nodal blocking medications may also be the culprit. Severe hemodynamic instability brought on by a 1:1 block progresses to ventricular fibrillation.
  • There is a rapid, regular complex tachycardia at 250-300 beats per minute. The flutter waves are not seen clearly.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male is brought to the operation theatre for heart valve surgery. He has a history of syncopal attacks on exertion and angina. The intra-operative appearance is shown below. Which kind of pulse is expected to present in this case before surgery?
questions.solution:
Option D: Anacrotic pulse

  • Valvular Aortic stenosis is the condition shown in the image.
  • Aortic stenosis, also known as aortic valve stenosis, is a form of disease that affects the heart's valves (valvular heart disease). The aorta is the major artery in the body, but the valve that leads from the lower left chamber of the heart to it is constricted and does not open all the way. Because of this, blood flow from the heart to the aorta and the rest of the body is reduced or blocked completely.

Symptoms of aortic valve stenosis:

  • A stethoscope can pick up an abnormal sound coming from the heart called a heart murmur.
  • Pain or tightness in the chest (angina) brought on by physical activity
  • Experiencing lightheadedness, vertigo, or fainting as a result of physical activity
  • Symptoms of shortness of breath, particularly during physical activity
  • A state of extreme tiredness, often during periods of intense activity
  • A heartbeat that is irregular and racing (palpitations)
  • Consuming insufficient food (mainly in children with aortic valve stenosis)
  • losing too much weight too quickly (mainly in children with aortic valve stenosis)
  • Examination Findings of Aortic stenosis include:
    • Pulsus parvus et tardus
    • Anacrotic pulse ( due to increase in ejection velocity)
    • Double apical impulse
    • Narrow/Paradoxical split S2
    • Ejection-systolic murmur

​​​​​​​Option A: Dicrotic pulse

  • Twice beating pulse palpable both in systole as well as diastole
  • It is seen in dilated cardiomyopathy

Option B: Pulsus bigeminus

  • A cardiovascular condition known as pulsus bigeminus is characterised by clusters of two quick heartbeats followed by an extended pause.

Option C: Pulsus bisferiens

  • Pulsus bisferiens is a Fast rising pulse with a fast fall.
  • Seen in Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother who noticed his lips turning blue whenever he cries or gets sick. She says that the squatting position relieves the bluish discoloration. Examination revealed a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left parasternal area. His complete blood count shows a hemoglobin 18 g%. What is the underlying defect?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: Cyanotic heart disease

  • This patient with cyanosis and a harsh holosystolic murmur of ventricular septal defect is most likely suffering from Tetralogy of Fallot.
  • In Tetralogy of Fallot, the affected child suddenly becomes increasingly cyanosed after feeding or a crying attack and may become apneic and unconscious. These attacks are called Tet spells.
  • Some children characteristically obtain relief by squatting after exertion (this increases the afterload to the left heart and decreases the right to left shunting).
  • In older children, Tet spells are uncommon, but cyanosis becomes increasingly apparent, with stunting of growth, digital clubbing, and polycythemia.

OTHER OPTIONS

Option A: Acyanotic heart disease

  • Acyanotic heart disease is an abnormality of the heart that interferes with blood flow normally, A hole in the heart's wall is one illustration.
  • As the name indicates, the patient has no episodes of cyanosis in these conditions.
  • Although the disease is present at birth, symptoms or issues may not appear until much later in life.
  • Sometimes the issue resolves itself when a child is still young.

Option C: Eisenmenger syndrome

  • Eisenmenger syndrome is caused by uncorrected left to right shunting, leading to pulmonary arterial hypertension and right ventricular hypertrophy. It raises blood pressure on the heart's side which receives less oxygen-rich blood (blue blood).
  • As a result, oxygen-rich blood and blood with low oxygen content might mix due to a hole (shunt) in the heart or blood arteries.

Option D: Lutembacher syndrome

  • Congenital atrial septal defect (ASD) exacerbated with acquired mitral stenosis is known as Lutembacher's syndrome.
  • It is an acyanotic heart disease and does not present with “squatting attacks.”

questions.text: A 79-year-man is brought to the emergency department after feeling lightheadedness and palpitation. The patient’s past medical history is significant for myocardial infarction 2 months back, for which he was treated with stent placement in the left anterior descending artery. He has been non-compliant with his current medications, which include amlodipine, aspirin, propanolol, and rosuvastatin. On examination, his blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg, his pulse is 128 beats/min irregular, and his respiratory rate is 22 breaths/min. The patient appears restless. His ECG reveals irregular rhythm without significant ST or T wave changes, and the echocardiogram reveals an LV aneurysm. Which of the following is an indication of intracardiac defibrillator use?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

Intracardiac defibrillator or implantable cardioverter defibrillator(ICD):

  • An implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) is an electronic device which is connected to the heart. It is used to continuously monitor and help regulate potentially fast and life-threatening arrhythmias.
  • Indications of ICD are as follows:
  1. Ventricular fibrillation(VF) or sustained unstable ventricular tachycardia(VT) not in the setting of a completely reversible cause.
  2. Left ventricular ejection fraction(LVEF) <35%, congestive heart failure NYHA class 2 and 3.
  3. Ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, LVEF <40%, non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) and inducible sustained VT.
  4. Syncope, LV dysfunction, inducible sustained VT.
  5. High-risk patients with: hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, long QT syndrome, RV dysplasia, and Brugada syndrome.
  • Therefore, all the above options, i.e. arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia, Brugada syndrome and LV aneurysm, are indications of an implantable cardiac defibrillator.

 

Option A: Arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia

  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia (ARVD) is a rare type of cardiomyopathy, which occurs when the cardiomyocytes in the right ventricle die and are replaced with scar tissue. This disrupts the heart's electrical signals and causes arrhythmias. Symptoms include palpitations and fainting after physical activity.
  • Arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia is an indication of ICD, but other options B and C are correct too.

Option B: Brugada syndrome

  • Brugada syndrome is an inherited disease that predisposes patients to fatal cardiac arrhythmias.
  • This is an indication of ICD, but arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia and LV aneurysms are indications of ICD as well.

 Option C: LV aneurysm (Post MI)

  • LV aneurysm symptoms can range from thromboembolism and arrhythmias to structural wall abnormalities.
  • Severe LV aneurysm is managed with ICD; however, arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia and Brugada syndrome are strong indications of ICD too.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to a physician for a normal routine check-up. He wants to get his sugar level checked because sometimes he experiences fatigue and thirst but very mildly. He has had a family history of diabetes for successive last two generations. The physician finds a high blood glucose level as fasting blood Sugar is 255mg/dl. There are no other classical symptoms of diabetes. Hence, he suspects a case of maturity-onset diabetes in young. Which of the following statement regarding maturity-onset diabetes in young (MODY) is incorrect?

choices.text: Most common type of MODY is MODY 3
HNF1-alpha gene is involved in the pathogenesis of MODY
Pancreatic beta cell mass is reduced

questions.solution:
Option D: Pancreatic beta cell mass is reduced

  • Maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is an autosomal dominant condition affecting individuals of age less than 25.
  • The insulin secretion is decreased even though beta cells are normal in amount.
  • In MODY type, the β-cell mass is normal, but HFN1-alpha gene mutations cause beta cell dysfunctioning by altering glucose metabolism in beta cells.
  • Thus, leading to impaired glucose-induced secretion of insulin

Other options

Option A: Most common type of MODY is MODY 3

  • There are six types of maturity-onset diabetes of the young; the most common type of MODY is MODY 3.
  • All types involve mutation of the nuclear transcription factor that regulates islets gene expression, except MODY 2 is due to mutation of the glucokinase gene.

Option B: HNF1-alpha gene is involved in the pathogenesis of MODY

  • Mutation of the hepatic nuclear factor 1 alpha (HNF- 1α) gene is involved in the pathogenesis of MODY 3, and it runs in families.
  • This is positive for the person with a history of diabetes in the last two generations.

Option C: Treatment is initiated with Glimepiride

  • Treatment is started with sulfonylureas (Glimepiride) to stimulate β-cell to produce more insulin because, in this condition, there is a decrease in the ability of the body to produce insulin.
  • It binds to sulfonylurea receptors on beta cells. It causes closure of ATP-sensitive potassium channels in beta cells, thus leading to depolarization of cell membrane and subsequent release of insulin.
  • It achieves blood glucose lowering with the lowest dose of any sulfonylurea drugs.
  • A single daily dose of 1mg/day has shown to be effective, and the maximum recommended dose is 8mg.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a history of peptic ulcer disease and diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency with a complaint of nausea, abdominal pain and lethargy for 2 days. He reports having occasional dark, tarry stools. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated blood glucose and a high anion gap metabolic acidosis on an arterial blood gas sample. Which of the following types of insulin should be used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Regular insulin

  • This patient with a history of vomiting, lethargy and abdominal pain with elevated blood glucose, high anion gap metabolic acidosis and positive urine sample for ketones most likely has diabetic ketoacidosis precipitated by his gastrointestinal bleed (history of peptic ulcer disease and black tarry stools).
  • Diabetes mellitus (DM) is a disease of beta cells of the pancreas. It is classified into 2 types:
    • Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus type 1 is an autoimmune disease characterized by T-cell-mediated destruction of the beta cells of the pancreas (due to the presence of glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies). Onset is typical in people aged <30 years. 
    • Non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus type 2 is caused by increased resistance to insulin leading to progressive pancreatic beta-cell failure; it is associated with obesity, and the onset is >40 years.
  • Types of insulin preparations are based on their duration of action. These include:
    • Ultra-short acting insulin
    • Short-acting insulin
    • Intermediate-acting insulin
    • Long-acting insulin

Type of insulin

Onset

Duration

Examples

Ultra-short/rapid-acting
  • 15 minutes
  • 2-4 hours
  • Lispro, aspart, glulisine

Short-acting
  • 30-60 minutes
  • 4-6 hours
  • Regular insulin
  • The only type of insulin that can be given intravenously.

Intermediate-acting
  • 2-4 hours
  • 18-28 hours
  • A peak in 4-10 hours
  • NPH
  • The most commonly used form of insulin.

Long-acting
  • 3-4 hours
  • 24 hours
  • Glargine, detemir.
  • Given at bedtime

Option B: Lispro

  • Lispro is ultrashort-acting insulin. It can not be given intravenously.

Option C: Glargine

  • It is long-acting insulin given subcutaneously at bedtime.

Option D: Aspart

  • Aspart is short-acting insulin given subcutaneously. While managing emergencies such as diabetic ketoacidosis, intravenous insulin should be given.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with increased weight gain and fatigue. She delivered a baby five months ago with no prenatal complications. Initially, she considered it average postpartum weight gain, but her health continued to deteriorate with an increase in fatigue by every day. Physical examination shows swelling in the neck, dry skin, and brittle nails. Lab shows an increase in TSH and a decrease in T3 and T4. Which of the following statements is irrelevant to the diagnosis of this patient?

choices.text: Glucocorticoids are almost always helpful as a treatment option

questions.solution:
Option D: Glucocorticoids are almost always helpful as a treatment option

  • A female with complaints of weight gain, fatigue, brittle nails, dry skin and increased neck swelling after pregnancy mostly suffers from postpartum thyroiditis.
  • It is a self-limiting disease and resolves itself.
  • No steroid use is advised.

Option A: It is self limiting disease

  • A female with complaints of weight gain, fatigue, brittle nails, dry skin and increased neck swelling after pregnancy mainly suffers from postpartum thyroiditis.
  • The lab values are also consistent with the diagnosis.
  • The patient first develops thyrotoxicosis, followed by hypothyroidism and then resolution.
  • it is a self limiting disease

Option B: It is associated with thyrotoxicosis

  • Thyrotoxicosis means an increase in the number of circulating thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) in the body due to any condition.
  • In postpartum thyroiditis, initially, thyrotoxicosis occurs due to the preformed thyroid hormones during the breakdown of the thyroid gland, which causes hyperthyroidism in the body.
  • This clinical state is followed by hypothyroidism, leading to a euthyroid state.

Option C: It is associated with hypothyroidism

  • Hypothyroidism occurs due to the depletion of thyroid hormone in the body.
  • It is a brief state.
  • It eventually leads to a euthyroid state. ​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and bilateral lower extremity oedema. His medical history has been consistent with diabetes and hypertension for the past 20 years. He was diagnosed with CKD about 5 years ago. A thorough assessment reveals metabolic acidosis. Which is correct about the prediction of compensation in metabolic acidosis?

choices.text: pACO2 will rise by 1.25mm Hg for every mmol/ L fall in bicarbonate
pACO2 will fall by 1.25mm Hg for every mmol/ L fall in bicarbonate
Paco2 will ↑ 6 mmHg per 10 mmol/L ↑ in [HCO3 – ]
pACO2 will fall by 10mm Hg for every mmol/ L fall in bicarbonate

questions.solution:
Option B: pACO2 will fall by 1.25mm Hg for every mmol/ L fall in bicarbonate

  • Primary respiratory disturbances (immediate changes in Paco2 ) invoke compensatory metabolic responses (secondary changes in [HCO3 −]), and primary metabolic disturbances elicit predictable- The degree of respiratory compensation expected in a metabolic acidosis can be predicted from the relationship:
    Paco2 = (1.5 × [HCO3 −]) + 8 ± 2.
  • Thus, a patient with metabolic acidosis and [HCO3 −] of 12 mmol/L would be expected to have a Paco2 of ∼26 mmHg.
  • Values for Paco2 <24 or >28 mmHg define a mixed disturbance (metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis or metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis, respectively).

Option A: pACO2 will rise by 1.25mm Hg for every mmol/ L fall in bicarbonate

  • A decreasing bicarbonate ion would result in a compensatory fall in carbon dioxide level.

Option C: Paco2 will ↑ 6 mmHg per 10 mmol/L ↑ in [HCO3 – ]

  • This is a compensatory response for metabolic alkalosis.

Option D: pACO2 will fall by 10mm Hg for every mmol/ L fall in bicarbonate

  • A fall in bicarbonate for every mmol/L would result in a rise in pCO2 by 1.25 mmHg

questions.text:
A 64-year-old patient is admitted to the surgical ward with a 16.3-cm hepatocellular carcinoma and marginal liver reserve. The first-stage operation of associating liver partition and portal vein ligation for staged hepatectomy is performed. The patient is found to be anuric with grossly deranged electrolytes after the first-stage operation. Tumour lysis syndrome is diagnosed.

Which of the following includes the management of tumour lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option E: All

Tumour Lysis syndrome

⇒ Common features

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia

Option A: Rasburicase

  • Rasburicase is a DNA recombinant urate oxidase derived from the fungus Aspergillus flavus.
  • Urate oxidase is an enzyme that catalyses the metabolism of uric acid to allantoin, which is an inert and inactive molecule that, unlike uric acid, is rapidly excreted in the urine.
  • Infusions of rasburicase lower serum uric acid levels by hastening its excretion and have been shown to be effective in rapidly lowering uric acid levels in patients with tumour lysis syndrome

Option B: Hydration

  • Hydration with normal saline appeared to be effective in preventing uric acid precipitation. High tubular fluid flow, regardless of the method of diuresis (solute vs water diuresis), is the primary mechanism for protection in acute uric acid nephropathy.

Option C: Allopurinol

  • The standard approach consists of allopurinol and aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor which decreases the production of uric acid from xanthine

Option D: Hemodialysis

  • Hemodialysis is a treatment to filter wastes and water from your blood
  • A machine filters wastes, salts and fluid from your blood when your kidneys are no longer healthy enough to do this

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy comes to the clinic with complaints of fever, night sweats and weight loss for the past two weeks. His examination reveals a firm, mobile and painless masses in his neck. Lymph node biopsy is positive for Reed Sternberg cells. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Minimal Change Disease

  • The patient's condition of fever, night sweats, weight loss with lymphadenopathy, and Reed Sternberg cells is indicative of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common nephrotic syndrome in children and presents with selective proteinuria.
  • It responds well to steroids and can be treated as such.
  • It is usually idiopathic but can be caused by secondary conditions, including immunisations, infections, and malignancies.
  • MCD is the most common nephropathy associated with Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Option A: Membranous Nephropathy

  • Membranous nephropathy is the most common nephrotic syndrome in adults.
  • In addition to infections and autoimmune conditions, membranous nephropathy is usually associated with solid organ malignancies, including lung, breast, and gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma. It is not associated with Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Option C: Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis

  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is an immune complex/complement deposition mediated condition which can present with either nephritic or nephrotic range proteinuria and hematuria.
  • It is usually associated with autoimmune conditions (e.g. SLE) or infections. (e.g. hepatitis B, hepatitis C)
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis may be associated with Nonhodgkin’s lymphoma in certain cases, not Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Option D: IgA Nephropathy

  • IgA nephropathy occurs after a viral infection and is signified by hematuria and proteinuria.
  • The patient presents with flank pain and hematuria 3-5 days after a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection.
  • It is not associated with any malignancy.

questions.text: Immune thrombocytopenia purpura (ITP) is the immune-mediated destruction of platelets. It is characterized by autoantibodies that bind to the platelets, which are then removed by the splenic macrophages. Which of the following statements is true regarding ITP?

choices.text: Acute ITP occurs in children between 2-6 years of age
Chronic ITP has Hemorrhagic bullae in the mouth
Acute ITP more common in girls than boys

questions.solution:
Option A: Acute ITP occurs in children between 2-6 years of age

  • Acute ITP predominantly occurs in children between 2-6 years of age.
  • Chronic ITP usually occurs in adults.

Option B: Chronic ITP has Hemorrhagic bullae in the mouth

  • Hemorrhagic bullae are usually absent in chronic ITP.
  • They are present in children in acute ITP.

Option C: Acute ITP more common in girls than boys

  • Acute ITP affects male and female children equally. There is no sex predilection.
  • Chronic ITP, in contrast, is more common in females.

Option D: Chronic ITP has spontaneous remission

  • Chronic ITP rarely shows spontaneous remission. It almost always requires steroid therapy.
  • Acute ITP usually remits spontaneously.

questions.text: A 76-year-old female is brought to the emergency department by his son due to sudden left-sided weakness for 1 hour. She has had a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease for 10 years. Her pulse is 83 beats/min, and her blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg. Neurological examination reveals right-sided facial nerve paralysis and left-sided upper and lower limb weakness. Sensations are normal bilaterally. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain reveals occlusion of the basilar artery branches. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lateral gaze palsy

  • The patient presents with clinical features of Foville syndrome.
  • Foville syndrome is an inferior medial pontine stroke syndrome.
  • Occlusion of perforating branches of the basilar artery results in Foville syndrome.
  • It commonly presents with the following:
  • Contralateral hemiparesis
  • Ipsilateral facial (CN VII) palsy
  • Ipsilateral abducens (CN VI) palsy (lateral gaze palsy)
  • Ipsilateral Horner syndrome
  • Loss of hearing
  • Loss of facial pain/ temperature sensation
  • Contralateral loss of vibration, fine touch and proprioception
  • CT scan shows occlusion of the basilar artery.
  • Treatment includes antiplatelet therapy, statin therapy, and secondary prevention by controlling vascular-related risk factors.
  • Another syndrome similar to Foville’s syndrome is named Millard-Gubler syndrome (ventral pontine syndrome). All findings are similar except eye findings in which the lateral rectus has weakness only because the abducens nerve is damaged, not the nucleus.

Option B: Medial gaze palsy

  • A medial gaze palsy is a conjugate, bilateral limitation of eye movements in the horizontal direction.
  • As the abducens nerve is affected, the lateral gaze is affected rather than the medial gaze.
  • It is not a part of Foville syndrome.

Option C: Third nerve palsy

  • Third nerve palsy causes a completely closed eyelid and deviation of the eye outward and downward.
  • The eye cannot move inward or up; the pupil is typically enlarged and does not normally react to light.
  • It is not a feature of Foville syndrome.

Option D: Nystagmus

  • Nystagmus is caused by lesions of CN VIII and its nuclei.
  • CN VIII is not affected by Foville syndrome.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic for his routine yearly examination. He has no active complaints and is using his medications regularly. He has had a history of hypertension for 25 years, type II diabetes mellitus for 10 years and a left-sided stroke 2 years ago. Various tests are performed to test the patient's functioning. One of the tests performed for the functioning of the corticospinal tract is shown below. Which of the following is a reflex being tested in the image above?
questions.solution:
Option C: Flexor finger reflex

  • The image above shows the flexor finger reflex.
  • The finger flexor reflex, also known as Hoffmann’s reflex, is done with the patient's relaxed hand with dorsiflexion at the wrist and partial flexion at the fingers.
  • To test the reflex, the middle finger is held loosely, and the examiner flicks the fingernail downward, allowing the middle finger to flick upward reflexively.
  • A positive response is seen when there is flexion and adduction of the thumb and flexion of the index finger of the same hand.
  • A positive finger flexor reflex is suggestive of hypertonia due to corticospinal dysfunction.
  • It is also positive in multiple sclerosis, hyperthyroidism, and anxiety.
  • 3% of healthy individuals also have a positive response.
  • This reflex is a C8 spinal segmental reflex.
  • The test is analogous to a positive Babinski sign.

Option A: Brachioradialis reflex

  • The brachioradialis reflex, also known as the supinator reflex, is observed by striking the brachioradialis directly with a reflex hammer when the patient's arm is relaxing. 
  • This reflex is carried by the radial nerve, whose spinal level is C5 and C6.

Option B: Wartenberg sign

  • Wartenberg sign is a neurological sign consisting of involuntary abduction of the fifth finger, caused by unopposed action of extensor digiti minimi.
  • It reflects damage to the innervation of the palmar interosseous muscle, which is innervated by fibres of the ulnar nerve.

Option D: Supinator reflex

  • To test the supinator reflex, the lower end of the radius is struck with a hammer just above the wrist. 
  • This causes contraction of the brachioradialis normally, and flexion of the elbow occurs.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of a headache for the past 1 month. She is a chronic smoker and has a 20-pack-year history. You diagnose her with a metabolic headache. Which of the following abnormalities are not considered to be a cause of metabolic headaches?
questions.solution:
Option D: Hyperglycemia

  • Hyperglycemia does not  cause  metabolic headache.
  • Metabolic headache causes and their physiology is given in the following table:
  • Metabolic headache takes place due to abrupt vasodilation of the cerebral vessels that can cause oedema to build up and will cause a headache
  • This patient was a chronic smoker and had a 20-pack-year history. She can have COPD and which causes hypercapnia and hypoxia in a patient, which suggests the headache in the patient

Option A: Hypoxia

  • Hypoxia does cause a metabolic headache as it causes the cerebral vessels to dilate and which causes the headache

Option B: Hypercapnia

  • Hypercapnia is a cause of metabolic headache as it causes cerebral vasodilation and oedema, which in turn cause the headache

Option C:Hyponatremia

  • Hyponatremia can cause metabolic headaches due to cerebral oedema

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with multiple episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizure for the last 10 days. On general examination, he has multiple hyper-pigmented papules over the nasolabial region and cheeks, along with multiple hypo-pigmented macules over the lower limbs and a Shagreen patch over the lateral aspect of the right buttock. His neurological examination reveals the increased tone of both upper and lower limbs with brisk deep deep tendon reflexes and bilateral positive Babinski's sign but absent superficial reflexes. Subsequently, his computed tomography (CT) scan of the head shows sub-ependymal nodules. Based on the history and findings, this patient is most likely to suffer from which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Option A: Tuberous Sclerosis

  • This is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in either the TSC-1 gene (chromosome 9) encoding hamartin or the TSC-2 gene (chromosome 16) encoding tuberin.
  • Classic triad of clinical features comprises learning disability, epilepsy and skin lesions, but there is a wide spectrum of clinical features.
  • Patients with tuberous sclerosis may present with the following clinical features:
  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Hypomelanotic macules small white oval (ash leaf) macules which usually present in early childhood.
  • Adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas), occurring later on in adolescence,
  • Shagreen patch (cobblestone-like plaques, which are made up of excess fibrous tissue, usually at the lower back).
  • Periungual fibromas
  • Renal angiomyolipomas
  • Cardiac rhabdomyomas

In the image above, there is adenoma sebaceum(arrow) present, which looks like extensive acne in a butterfly distribution.

  • These patients have an increased incidence of subependymal nodules, cortical tubers, and subependymal giant-cell astrocytomas (SEGAs).
  • Patients frequently require anticonvulsants for seizures.
  • Definite tuberous sclerosis is diagnosed by either two major features or one major feature and two minor features.
Major features  Minor Features 
Facial angiofibromas or forehead plaque Multiple randomly distributed pits in dental enamel
Nontraumatic ungual or periungual fibroma Hamartomatous rectal polyps
Hypomelanotic macules (more than 3) Bone cysts
Shagreen patch (connective tissue nevus) Cerebral white-matter "migration tracts"
Cortical tuber, subependymal nodule Gingival fibromas
Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma Non-renal hamartoma
Multiple retinal nodular hamartomas Retinal achromic patch
Cardiac rhabdomyoma, single or multiple Confetti skin lesions
Lymphangiomyomatosis Multiple renal cysts
Renal angiomyolipoma  

Option B: Von Hippel Lindau

  • It is a dominantly inherited disease.
  • Caused by the mutations of the VHL tumour suppressor gene on chromosome 3
  • VHL is associated with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

Option C: Sturge Weber syndrome

  • Sturge-Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder with angiomas.
  • Angiomas that involve leptomeninges and skin of the face.
  • The hallmark of Sturge Weber syndrome is a facial cutaneous venous dilation, also referred to as nevus flammeus or Port-wine stain.

Option D: Ataxia Telangiectasia

  • It is an autosomal recessive multisystem disorder.
  • Patients with ataxia telangiectasia (AT) present in the first decade of life with progressive telangiectatic lesions associated with deficits in:
    • Cerebellar functions
    • Nystagmus
    • Progressive neurological impairment
    • Predisposition to malignancy

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient comes to the clinic complaining of weakness and stiffness in his right leg for the past 1 week. On physical exam, the Babinski sign is positive, and the deep tendon reflexes of the right knee are 4+. Anterior cerebral artery stroke caused these U.M.N symptoms. All of the following are examples of upper motor neuron lesions except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Anterior horn cell disease

  • Anterior Horn cell disease is because  it comes under lower motor neuron lesion
  • The anterior horn cell is where the nerves of P.N.S start from
  • Anterior horn cell disease comprises SPINAL MUSCULAR ATROPHY 1 and 2.
  • S.M.A. is Congenital anterior horn cells diseases
  • The infants experience Flaccid paralysis from birth and have all the signs of L.M.N lesions like hyporeflexia and decreased tone of muscles as opposed to U.M.N lesion symptoms of hyperreflexia and spasticity

Option A: Prion disease

  • Prion disease is acute dementia within months plus startles myoclonus.
  • The myoclonus is a feature of U.M.N disease

Option B: Multiple sclerosis

  • In Multiple sclerosis, there are lesions in the C.N.S white matter tracts, so that is why it  will cause U.M.N lesions

Option D: Subacute combined degeneration

  • Dorsal column sensory lesions are present in the spinal cord, and corticospinal tract lesions are present in SCAD
  • Corticospinal tract lesions will cause U.M.N  lesion symptoms

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with right arm weakness, paraparesis, and increased reflexes for the past 5 days. T1w MRI with contrast and coronal view showed dumbbell schwannoma at C3-C4 level with bone erosion of the vertebral body. The characteristic 'Schwannoma of spinal nerve roots is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Neurofibromatosis 1

  • Schwannoma is a benign tumour arising from Schwann cells of cranial and spinal nerve roots.
  • NF-1 is associated with an increased incidence of schwannomas of spinal nerve roots. (NEUROFIBROMAS)
  • NF -1is an  autosomal dominant disorder that can present with
    • café au lait macules
    • neurofibromas
    • Lisch nodules
    • axillary and inguinal freckling
    • pheochromocytoma
    • optic glioma
  • Vestibular schwannoma or acoustic neuroma arises from vestibular portion of 8th cranial nerve.
  • Patients with NF-2 have an incidence of vestibular schwannomas that are frequently bilateral.

Option B: Neurofibromatosis 2

  • NF-2 will present with vestibular Schwannoma

Option C: Turcot syndrome

  • Turcot syndrome is characterized by the formation of multiple benign growths (polyps) in the colon that occur in association with a primary brain tumor.

Option  D: Li – Fraumeni syndrome

  • Li- Fraumeni syndrome is due to P53 mutation and is characterised by sarcoma, breast carcinoma, adrenal carcinoma, and leukaemia.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman presents to her general physician for a follow-up visit after having a high BP on her last visit. She was again found to be hypertensive and was prescribed hydralazine, a β-blocker, and furosemide. The woman takes no additional prescription or over-the-counter medications. She complains of muscle aches, joint pain, and rash. Physical exam reveals a temp. Of 37.7°C (100.0°F) and a scaling erythematous rash on her face. The physician orders an autoantibody panel:

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): Positive

Anti-histone antibodies: Positive

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hydralazine-induced lupus erythematosus

Rash, arthralgias, and anti-histone antibodies suggest drug-induced systemic lupus erythematosus (DIL).

  • Drug-induced lupus (DIL) is an autoimmune phenomenon where drug exposure leads to the development of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) like clinical features.
  • DIL is a clear example of an environmental trigger leading to the development of lupus in a genetically susceptible individual. Hydralazine was the first agent to be associated with the development of lupus-like symptoms.
  • Hydralazine is the causative drug in this case.
  • Positive ANA is nonspecific as there are many conditions, mostly infectious and autoimmune, that show positive ANA (RIM pattern is specific for SLE).
  • The sensitivity of ANA for drug-induced SLE is 100%, so if ANA is negative drug-induced SLE can be ruled out.
  • Drugs are known to induce SLE- Procainamide, chlorpromazine, isoniazid, methyldopa, minocycline, penicillamine, and diltiazem.
  • Drug-induced lupus is common in whites and has less female predilection as compared to SLE.

Pathophysiology:

  • Different mechanisms are used for the induction of autoimmunity by lupus-inducing drugs.
  • There are some genetic risk factors, such as HLA-DR0301, HLA-DR4, and complement C4 null allele, which varies between different agents.
  • The acetylators with genetic deficiency of N-acetyltransferase are at a higher risk of DIL, especially Procainamide and hydralazine.

Option A: Systemic lupus erythematosus

  • 95% of patients develop arthralgias or myalgia, or Arthritis in SLE
  • SLE is diagnosed by a physician using symptom assessments, X-rays, physical examinations,  and lab tests. SLE can be difficult to diagnose because its early signs and symptoms are nonspecific and may seem like signs and symptoms of other diseases.

Option C: β-blocker-induced systemic lupus erythematosus

  • Keratinocytes possess adrenergic receptors, which have been reported as being exclusive of the β2-subtype.
  • β2-adrenergic receptors are densest at the basal cells and decrease in number towards the stratum corneum, while intracellular calcium concentrations are lowest at the basal cells, increasing towards the stratum corneum, thus correlating with keratinocyte differentiation.

Option D: Furosemide-induced systemic lupus erythematosus

  • Moderate Potential Hazard, Moderate probability.
  • Furosemide use has been associated with exacerbation or activation of systemic lupus erythematosus.
  • Therapy with furosemide should be administered cautiously in patients with a history of lupus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to OPD with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs and getting up from a chair. She is a known case of ovarian cancer. Heliotrope rash and redish purplish spots on the knuckles, elbows, knees, and toes are seen on physical examination. Muscle weakness in the hip, neck, back, and shoulders is also persistent. Mark the incorrect statement about the cutaneous manifestation of the given condition.

choices.text: Gottron’s papules: Erythema seen over elbows and knees
Heliotrope rash- Erythematous to violaceous eruption on the upper eyelids
Shawl sign- violaceous erythema rash on deltoids, Posterior shoulder, nape of the neck, area of the neck, upper chest

questions.solution:
Option A: Gottron’s papules: Erythema seen over elbows and knees

The given clinical scenario is Dermatomyositis.

  • Dermatomyositis causes skin rash and muscle inflammation.
  •  It causes swelling and muscle inflammation.
  •  It's different from others because it also causes skin complications.
  • Dermatomyositis is used to describe both muscle and skin complications.
  • It may affect any age, but it most commonly affects adults ages 55 to 70.
  • Women are more likely to get the disease than men.
  • People with this condition also have a connective tissue disorder, such as rheumatoid arthritis or lupus.

Causes:

  • Abnormal genes you are born with
  • Cancer, especially in older people
  • Autoimmune disease is a type of illness that is responsible for the body's immune system attacking its own tissues.
  • A medication, infection, or another exposure in your environment triggers the disease.

Symptoms:

The symptoms are caused by inflammation and swelling in the blood vessels that supply your muscles and skin and can include:

  • Painful or itchy red or purple rash on sun-exposed areas that may be
  • Purple or red swelling of the upper eyelids (heliotrope).
  • Red or purple spots on the elbows, knuckles, knees, and toes (Gottron's papules).
  • Joints that turn pale and feel stiff and painful in cold conditions and feel better when warmed (Raynaud's phenomenon).
  • Scaly, rough, dry skin can lead to hair thinning.
  • Swollen, red areas around the fingernails.
  • Hard lumps under the skin are caused by calcium deposits (calcinosis).
  • Muscle weakness in the hip, neck, shoulders and back.
  • Voice changes and Trouble swallowing
  • Fever, tiredness, and weight loss.
  • Muscle pain.
  • Trouble getting out of bed or rising from a chair due to muscle weakness.
  • Sometimes the weakness of muscles also spreads to the GI tract, heart, and lungs.
  • This can cause coughing and breathing trouble.
  • Adults can have a low-grade fever, along with sensitivity to light and lung inflammation.

other options

Option B: Heliotrope rash- Erythematous to violaceous eruption on the upper eyelids

  • The heliotrope rash is caused by dermatomyositis (DM), a rare connective tissue disease.
  • People with this disease have a purple or bluish-purple rash that develops on certain areas of the skin.
  • They may also suffer from muscle weakness, fever, and joint pain.
  • The rash may be itchy or cause a burning sensation.
  • It usually appears on sun-exposed parts of the skin, including the following:
    • Face (including eyelids), knuckles, neck, elbows, chest, back, knees, hips, shoulders, and nails

Option C: Shawl sign- violaceous erythema rash on deltoids, Posterior shoulder, nape of the neck, area of the neck, upper chest

  • Shawl sign: The shawl sign is a widespread, flat, reddened area that appears on the upper back, shoulders, and back of the neck.
  • It can worsen with exposure to ultraviolet light.

Option D: Mechanic’s hands-Palmar hyperkeratosis

  • The presence of “mechanic’s hands” is one of the clinical clues for collagen vascular diseases.
  • However, the exact relevance of “mechanic’s hands” in collagen vascular diseases has not been well documented.
  • The purpose of this study was to reveal the relevance of "mechanic's hands" to collagen vascular diseases, including various skin lesions and interstitial pneumonia.

questions.text: A 40 years old male labourer by occupation presented to opd with the complaint of discolouration of nails. He also complains of decreased appetite, fatigue and backache. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. He drinks two alcoholic beverages daily and takes no medications. The nails show a typical appearance, as shown in the image below. All are possible diagnoses in these changes in nails except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Wilson’s disease

  • In patients with Wilson's disease, the lunula of the nail takes on a blue colouration called the azure lunula.
  • Excessive fluoride ingestion can turn nails brown or black. Hepatolenticular degeneration in Wilson’s disease leads to bluish discolouration of the lanula or base of fingernails. In Wilson's disease, the discolouration is most intense in the base and fades out proximally.

Systemic

  1. Addison’s disease
  2. Cushing’s disease
  3. AIDS
  4. Alkaptonuria /Ochronosis
  5. Irradiation
  6. Secondary syphilis
  7. Nelson syndrome

Dermatological

  1. Amyloid (primary)
  2. Basal cell carcinoma/Bowen’s disease
  3. Lichen planus
  4. Malignant melanoma
  5. Peutz- Jeghers - Syndrome
  6. Porphyria cutanea tarda
  7. Radiotherapy and radiodermatitis

Option A: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

  • The most prominent cutaneous feature of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is the appearance of pigmented spots, also called melanocytic macules.
  • Bluish-black or dark brown, flat patches are seen around the mouth, lips, gums, inner lining of the mouth, eyes, hands and feet, fingers and toes, anus and genital areas.
  • Pigmentation usually appears before 5 years of age and may fade after puberty.

Option B: Addison disease.

  • In Addison's disease, the adrenal gland produces insufficient steroid hormones.
  • Patients with Addison's disease experience hyperpigmentation of the skin, which turns their skin brown or black.

Option C: Cushing disease.

  • Cushing's disease causes the overproduction of cortisol.
  • Secondary hypercortisolism can cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.

questions.text: What is the reason for the increased bilirubin level in prehepatic jaundice?

choices.text: Decreased bilirubin production in the liver.
Bilirubin cannot be excreted from the liver.
Increased hemolysis of red blood cells.

questions.solution:
Here are four options to consider:

Option 1: Decreased bilirubin production in the liver. Explanation: This is not the correct answer. In prehepatic jaundice, the liver is functioning normally in terms of bilirubin production. The issue is primarily due to an increased breakdown of red blood cells, leading to an excess of unconjugated bilirubin.

Option 2: Liver dysfunction impairs bilirubin processing. Explanation: This is not the correct answer. In prehepatic jaundice, the liver itself is not dysfunctional; it's the excessive breakdown of red blood cells that results in increased unconjugated bilirubin levels. The liver's ability to process bilirubin is not impaired.

Option 3: Bilirubin cannot be excreted from the liver. Explanation: This is not the correct answer. In prehepatic jaundice, bilirubin can be produced and processed by the liver. However, the problem lies in the increased production of unconjugated bilirubin due to hemolysis, and this bilirubin cannot be efficiently excreted by the liver.

Option 4: Increased hemolysis of red blood cells. Explanation: This is the correct answer. In prehepatic jaundice, the main reason for increased bilirubin levels is the increased breakdown of red blood cells (hemolysis), which leads to an excess of unconjugated bilirubin in the bloodstream. The liver is not the primary cause of the problem, as it is still capable of processing bilirubin, but it cannot keep up with the excessive production due to hemolysis.

So, the correct answer is option 4: Increased hemolysis of red blood cells.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of loss of appetite, lack of sleep, low energy, fatigue, impaired concentration, and sad mood for the previous 2 months. He is having suicidal thoughts and plans to act on them. The physician diagnosed him with major depressive disorder. He lives alone, drinks alcohol, and has attempted suicide in the past. Which of the following is the greatest risk factor for suicide in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Previous suicide attempt

A history of suicide attempt in a patient is the biggest risk factor for suicide.

The following are the risk factors for suicide:

  • Male sex
  • Age group (young or older adults)
  • Depression
  • A previous attempt at suicide
  • Substance use
  • Psychosis
  • Medical illness
  • A plan for suicide
  • No social support system
  • Stated an intent to attempt suicide in the future

Option A: Alcohol

  • Although substance intoxication increases the risk of suicide, a history of suicide attempt remains the biggest risk factor.

Option B: Living alone

  • A person living alone without the support of family and friends is more likely to attempt suicide.

Option C: Major depressive disorder

  • Psychiatric disorders increase the risk of suicide attempts.
  • A history of suicide attempt in a patient is the biggest risk factor for suicide.

questions.text: All of the following are seen in post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Option B: Hallucinations

  • Hallucinations are a psychotic symptom
  • PTSD is a neurotic disorder, therefore hallucinations is not a symptom of PTSD

Option A: Emotional numbing

  • It is a common symptom seen with PTSD

Option C: Hyper arousal

  • It is a common symptom seen with PTSD
  • Hyper-vigilance, exaggerated startle response

Option D: Flashbacks

  • It is a common symptom seen with PTSD
  • The patient vividly re-experiences a traumatic event

Learning Objective

  • PTSD is characterized by:
    • Intrusive symptoms: Re-experiencing trauma in form of flashback, vivid dreams, nightmares
    • Avoidance
    • Arousal symptoms: Hypervigilance, insomnia, exaggerated startle response, Emotional numbing and Anhedonia.
    • Symptoms must last for 1 month to diagnose as PTSD.
    • PTSD is a neurotic disorder
  • Neurotic Disorders: Judgement, insight and contact with reality is intact.
  • Psychotic Disorders: Judgement, insight and contact with reality is not intact.
  • Depression is the only illness that comes under neurotic illnesses but can develop psychotic symptoms.

questions.text: A 54-year-old lady with cirrhosis and an alcohol use disorder goes to the emergency room with a change in mental status. She moves slowly during the assessment, is disoriented to time and place, and has asterixis. The ammonia level is high. On an electroencephalogram (EEG), which of the following findings can be seen?
questions.solution:
• ·This woman’s presentation is suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy
  • .Triphasic waves are a characteristic finding on EEG in this disorder.
  • These waves are of low frequency and high amplitude

questions.text: Psychodynamic theory of mental illness is based on:

choices.text: Focuses on teaching patients to restrain absurd thoughts

questions.solution: • ·The psychodynamic (or psychoanalytic) theory holds that psychiatric problems are caused by unconscious memories and conflicts.·The "conflict" could be between distinct elements of the mind, such as the id and the ego, or the ego and the superego.·Psychodynamic psychotherapy is sometimes known as insight-oriented or expressive psychotherapy, whereas psychoanalysis is the more structured version.·It might be brief or restricted in duration, although it is frequently open-ended and carried out over a lengthy period of time.·Sessions are normally held once or twice a week, and the patient is invited to discuss "anything comes to mind."The purpose of psychodynamic psychotherapy is to identify, interpret, and work with dysfunctional unconscious beliefs and drives so that more mature defence mechanisms can be developed.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female comes to the physician complaining of a lump in her right breast that she noticed 4 months ago. After a complete workup, the diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma is established. Before starting treatment, the physician suggests HER-2/neu immunohistochemistry staining. Which of the following scores on this patient’s test results will most likely need further confirmatory testing?
questions.solution:
Option C: 2+

  • This patient, who has been diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma, should have additional testing for molecular markers.
  • Various molecular markers, including those involved in the steroid hormone receptor pathways (estrogen and progesterone receptors), and molecules involved in the human epidermal growth factor receptor pathway (HER-2), are routinely tested for targeted treatment.
  • HER-2 protein is the product of the ERB-B2 gene.
  • This protein is amplified in almost 20% of breast cancer cases, and its testing is therefore included in the routine pathologic reporting of breast cancer.
  • The HER-2 receptor has an extracellular domain and intracellular tyrosine kinase.
  • Overexpression of the HER-2 gene product results in the proliferation of tumor cells.
  • HER-2 overexpression is measured by immunohistochemistry.
  • The results are reported on a scale of 0 to 3+.
  • A score of 0 or 1+ indicates a negative, whereas a score of 3+ indicates a positive HER-2/neu amplification status.
  • If the test yields a score of 2+, it is considered equivocal, and further testing with fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) is done to confirm a positive or negative status.
  • HER-2-positive breast cancer can be treated with trastuzumab, a humanized monoclonal antibody targeted against the HER-2 receptor.

 

 

Option A: 0

  • If the immunohistochemical staining reveals a score of 0, it is considered negative for HER-2 gene amplification.
  • No further testing is indicated in this scenario.

Option B: 1+

  • Obtaining a score of 1+ on immunohistochemistry labels the tumor as HER-2 receptor-negative, and no further testing is required.

Option D: 3+

  • If the immunohistochemistry for the HER-2 gene reveals a score of 3+, it marks the overexpression of the gene and its product protein.
  • The patients with a positive HER-2/neu status are treated with trastuzumab-based targeted therapy.

questions.text: A 49-year-old post-menopausal female presents to the surgical OPD with complaints of breast heaviness and purulent discharge from her left breast for the past 20 days. On physical examination, a mass is felt in the left breast that is hard and immobile on contracting the ipsilateral pectoralis major. The breast does not fall forward on leaning forward. No skin changes were noted. What is the T stage of this patient's cancer?
questions.solution:
Option B: T4a

  • The breast does not fall forward on leaning forward, which is suggestive of chest wall fixity. Hence the T stage is T4a

Stage

Size of tumor

T1

up to 2 cm

T2

2-5 cm

T3

>5 cm

T4a

Extension to the chest wall (chest wall is formed by Ribs, Intercostal muscles, and Serratus Anterior)

T4b
  • Ulceration
  • oedema including Peau d'orange
  • Satellite nodules

T4c

T4a + T4b

T4d

Inflammatory breast cancer

Not included in T4

  • Involvement of the dermis alone
  • Nipple retraction/ deviation
  • Involvement of Pectoralis major/ Pectoralis minor

 

Option A: T3

  •  In the T3  staging of breast cancer, the tumor size is greater than 5cm; however, it has not penetrated the chest wall or the skin.

Option C: T4b

  • Ulceration, ipsilateral satellite skin nodules, or skin edema, including peau d'orange skin appearance in breast skin, is visible.

Option D: T4c

  • In the T4c stage of breast cancer, the combination of T4a and T4b  is seen. In addition to the involvement of the underlying chest wall, skin involvement is noted in T4c.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the emergency department complaining of excessive drowsiness and decreased oral intake for the past 3 days, along with difficulty getting up from the squatting position, combing her hair, and dressing. She complained of weight gain in the last few months, increased sensitivity to cold, skin dryness, hair loss, hoarseness of voice, and easy fatigability. She also had no family history or any major illnesses. On physical examination, periorbital puffiness and dry, coarse skin were noted. No tremors or fasciculations were elicited. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hypothyroidism

  • These symptoms are suggestive of hypothyroidism. A deficiency in circulating levels of thyroid hormone leads to hypothyroidism.
  • Hypothyroidism signs and symptoms may include:
    • Easy fatigability
    • Increased sensitivity to cold (cold intolerance)
    • Constipation
    • Dry skin ( due to reduced conversion of carotene to vitamin A)
    • Weight gain
    • Patients with severe hypothyroidism or myxedema develop characteristic facial features due to the deposition of glycosaminoglycans in the subcutaneous tissues, leading to facial and periorbital puffiness.
    • Hoarseness of voice
    • Muscle weakness (thyroid myopathy), Muscle aches, tenderness, and stiffness
    • Elevated blood cholesterol level
    • Heavier than normal or irregular menstrual periods
    • Infertility
    • Thinning hair and loss of outer two-thirds of eyebrow
    • Enlarged thyroid gland (goiter)
    • Cardiovascular changes include bradycardia, cardiomegaly, pericardial effusion, reduced cardiac output and pulmonary effusion.
    • Hypothyroidism in children leads to cretinism and characteristic facies

Option B: Hyperthyroidism

  • Hyperthyroidism presents with weight loss despite increased appetite, heat intolerance, tremors, gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhea), and warm moist palms. Such findings are not seen in this patient.

Option C: Anemia of unknown cause

  • A patient with anemia presents easy fatigability, excessive drowsiness, dry skin, and dry/damaged hair; however, patients with anemia do not show periorbital puffiness, cold intolerance, and hoarseness of voice. Such symptoms are suggestive of hypothyroidism.

Option D: Underlying malignancy

  • A patient with malignancy will present with weight loss, decreased appetite, and easy fatigability gradually progressively. However, periorbital puffiness, dry, coarse skin, weight gain, and cold intolerance are signs of hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with known liver cirrhosis comes to the emergency department with bleeding per rectum for 4 days. He had variceal banding after an episode of esophageal bleeding 2 months ago. Non-tender abdomen with positive shifting dullness and normal bowel sounds on examination. There is grade 2+ peripheral pitting edema. BUN and serum creatinine are raised. Urine dipstick is negative for protein and blood. Urine sodium is 5 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hepatorenal syndrome

  • The patient with a history of liver cirrhosis presents with an abnormal renal function test and most likely a hepatorenal syndrome diagnosis.
  • The risk factor is advanced cirrhosis.
  • The Precipitating factors are Reduced renal perfusion, GI bleeding, vomiting, sepsis, excessive diuretic use, reduced glomerular pressure, and NSAID use (constricts afferent arterioles).
  • The diagnosis is made by Renal hypoperfusion, FeNa <1% (or urine Na <10 mEq/L), absence of tubular injury, no RBC, protein, or granular casts in the urine, and no improvement in renal function with fluids.
  • The management includes addressing precipitating factors (e.g., hypovolemia, anemia, infection), Splanchnic vasoconstrictors (midodrine, octreotide, norepinephrine), and Liver transplantation.

Option A: Nephrotic syndrome

  • Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by the loss of proteins in urine (more than 3 grams per day).
  • The nephrotic syndrome patient does not present with ascites and abdominal distention, which is the Hallmark of liver cirrhosis.

Option B: Acute kidney injury

  • Acute kidney injuries are caused by ingesting nephrotoxic drugs like aminoglycosides.
  • Granular casts are seen in the urine.

Option D: Acute interstitial nephritis

  • In acute interstitial nephritis, the inflammation of the kidney interstitium occurs.
  • WBC casts, and eosinophils are seen in the urine.
  • Proteinuria can also occur.

questions.text: For a 47-year-old male liver recipient with hepatitis B virus (HBV) cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (two tumors, each ≤ 3 cm without extrahepatic and major vessel involvement), a BMI of 19.8 kg/m2, MELD score of 18, and CPT classification B7, what criteria are employed to assess eligibility for liver transplantation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Milan’s criteria

  • Milan's criteria are used for Liver transplantation
  • This criteria is used to predict the risk of recurrent disease after transplantation
    • Patients who meet the criteria- the risk of recurrence <20%
    • Patients outside the criteria - the risk of recurrence- 60%
  • Currently used to define acceptable candidates for transplantation in the United States
  • After the Liver transplant, the patient has a 4-year survival of 80%.

 

Option A: Ranson criteria

  • Ranson criteria are used to predict the severity and mortality of acute pancreatitis.
  • Five parameters are assessed on admission, and the other six are assessed 48 hours after admission.

 

Option C: Eagle's criteria

  • The eagle score is a 5 points scoring system used for the vascular patient.
  • The Eagle criteria include age over 70 years, angina, diabetes, Q wave on ECG, and history of congestive heart failure to predict adverse cardiac events following major vascular surgery.

Option D: Rockall criteria

  • Rockall scores are designed to combine information such as the patient's age, the occurrence of shock assessed from systolic blood pressure records and pulse rate, and the presence and severity of co-morbid conditions.

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker presented with painless jaundice, pruritus, and clay-colored stools for 2 months. History of waxing and waning of jaundice was present. A CT scan reveals a dilated main pancreatic duct and common bile duct. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas

questions.solution:
Option B: Periampullary carcinoma

  • This patient with obstructive jaundice symptoms and being a chronic smoker indicates a carcinoma of the biliary pancreatic region.
  • The patient has symptoms suggestive of obstructive jaundice, pruritus, and clay-colored stools.
  • Causes of intermittent jaundice include periampullary carcinoma and common bile duct stones.
  • As the jaundice is painless and the CT scan shows dilated main pancreatic duct and common bile duct, findings favour periampullary carcinoma.
    • Jaundice - painful and intermittent- common bile duct stones
    • Painless and intermittent jaundice - periampullary carcinoma
    • Painless and progressive jaundice- carcinoma head of the pancreas
  • Periampullary cancers include tumours arising from the
    • Distal bile duct
    • Duodenal mucosa
    • Pancreas just adjacent to the ampulla

Option A: Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas

  • Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas will present with progressive jaundice that increases with time, but this patient is experiencing intermittent jaundice, a feature of periampullary carcinoma. On CT scan, mostly a mass will be seen in the head of the pancreas with metastasis toward the liver at the time of the diagnosis

Option C: Chronic pancreatitis

  • Chronic pancreatitis will present with epigastric pain and steatorrhea, mostly in alcoholics. Chronic pancreatitis cannot cause obstructive jaundice

Option D: Hilar cholangiocarcinoma

  • Hilar cholangiocarcinoma presents intermittent jaundice but will not present on CT with pancreatic and common bile duct dilation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient diagnosed with chronic liver failure presented to the emergency department with 2 episodes of bloody vomiting. His vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 80/60 mmHg, a heart rate of 120 per minute, a respiratory rate of 23 per minute, and a temperature of 98.7° F. Which of the following is the first line of management?
questions.solution:
Option D: Fluid resuscitation

  • In the case of acute variceal bleeding secondary to chronic liver disease (CLD), we should ensure airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC). 
  • In this patient, the airway is patent, and breathing is normal, but circulation is compromised by variceal bleeding and resultant hypotension.
  • Ringer’s lactate, also known as Hartmann’s solution, is the fluid of choice for acute variceal bleeding.
  • The systolic blood pressure threshold is 100 mmHg, below which fluid resuscitation is indicated.
  • The hemoglobin threshold is 8g/dL, below which blood transfusion is indicated.
  • Pharmacotherapy management to control the bleeding is started after fluid replacement.
  • The drug of choice is octreotide and the second line pharmacologic modality is terlipressin combined with nitrates.
  • After controlling the bleeding, gastric lavage can be performed with room-temperature saline. Cold saline is not used because of the risk of hypothermia, which can lead to coagulopathy or platelet dysfunction, but it is reversible.
  • An endoscopic intervention should be performed after gastric lavage. Endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL) is preferred to endoscopic sclerotherapy.
  • Patients should be kept on intravenous antibiotics for 7 days because they have been shown to decrease the risk of infections, rebleeding, and duration of hospitalization.
  • Surgical intervention is warranted if rebleeding occurs within 24 hours of endoscopic intervention.
  • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS or TIPSS) is only performed when two attempts of endoscopy were unsuccessful at controlling the bleeding.

Option A: Octreotide infusion

  • Pharmacotherapy management to control the bleeding is started after fluid replacement.
  • The drug of choice is octreotide and the second line pharmacologic modality is terlipressin combined with nitrates.

Option B: Urgent endoscopy

  • Endoscopic intervention is performed after fluid resuscitation and pharmacologic therapy, either by octreotide, terlipressin, or nitrates.
  • Gastric lavage should be performed before endoscopy to increase visualization and remove any blood clots.

Option C: Packed RBC

  • The hemoglobin threshold is 8g/dL, below which blood transfusion is indicated.
  • Transfusion of packed red blood cells can be performed after achieving hemodynamic stability with ringer’s lactate.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman was evaluated 3 days after ingesting bleach. She was lethargic, had diffuse abdominal pain and tenderness and had an SBP of 80 mmHg. Pneumoperitoneum was present on a CXR. Endotracheal intubation was performed, and massive resuscitation with 14 liters of IV crystalloid was instituted in preparation for exploratory laparotomy. Abdominal exploration revealed multiple perforations along the greater curvature and fundus of the stomach. Intra-op esophagogastroscopy revealed denuded gastric mucosa and hyperemic esophageal mucosa. She underwent total gastrectomy with stapled closure of the distal esophagus and duodenal stump. Postoperatively, the patient was hypotensive and had persistent severe metabolic acidosis. Her SBP was consistently below 90 mmHg for 10 hours, in spite of high-dose dopamine and norepinephrine infusions. Her abdomen was palpably tight, and the IAP measured via a urinary bladder catheter was 21 cmH2O. Her peak inspiratory pressure & central venous pressure have also risen. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Immediate decompression

Abdominal compartment syndrome of Grade 3 is mentioned in the question.

Symptoms

  • Anuria increased ventilation pressure.

Treatment:

  • Decompression

Option A: Emergency Re-exploration

Exploratory laparotomy can be used when you:

  • Have serious or long-term abdominal symptoms that defy diagnosis.
  • Have had major abdominal trauma, and there's no time for another test.
  • Are not good candidates for laparoscopic surgery.

This surgery can be used to explore the following:

Abdominal blood vessels

Large intestine (colon)

Pancreas

Appendix

Liver

Small intestine

Fallopian tubes

Lymph nodes

Spleen

Gallbladder

Membranes in the abdominal cavity

Stomach

Kidneys

Ovaries

Uterus

Option C: Hypovolemic resuscitation

  • Hemorrhage is the leading cause of preventable deaths in trauma patients. After presenting a brief history of hemorrhagic shock resuscitation, this article discusses damage control resuscitation and its adjuncts.
  • Massively bleeding patients in hypovolemic shock should be treated with damage control resuscitation principles, including limited crystalloid, whole blood or balance blood component transfusion to permissive hypotension, preventing hypothermia, and stopping bleeding as quickly as possible.

Option D: Normovolemic resuscitation

  • The practice of maintaining normovolemia and normotension during intracranial surgery is now well-established. Hyperglycemia, which worsens the consequences of cerebral ischemia,101,103,132 and hypo-osmolality (target osmolality, 290 to 320 mOsm/kg), which can increase brain oedema, should be avoided. Colloid oncotic pressure plays an unclear role in brain oedema.
  • Glucose-containing or hypo-osmolar solutions (e.g., lactated Ringer’s solution, 254 mOsm/kg) should be avoided. Suitable choices for infusion liquids during intracranial surgery include 0.9% NaCl and modern 6% hydroxyethyl starch 130/0.4 solutions (304 mOsm/kg) with no deleterious effect on coagulation. The hematocrit should be kept above 28%. Fluids should be warmed at the end of the procedure to ensure normothermia for emergence from anaesthesia.

questions.text: Smoking increases the risk of which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Option B: Urinary bladder

  • Cigarette smoke increases the risk of many cancers. It includes:
    • First-hand smoke: smoke inhaled by the smoker
    • Second-hand smoke: exhaled smoke that is inhaled by others in the vicinity of the smoker
    • Third-hand smoke: smoke particles that adhere to surfaces in the surroundings of the smoker
      • All three have been proven to be carcinogenic
  • Smoking is an important risk factor for:
    • Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder
    • Squamous cell carcinoma (cervix, oropharynx, esophagus, larynx, lung)
    • Small cell lung cancer
    • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma
    • Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus
    • Renal cell carcinoma

Option A: Thyroid

  • Smoking is not a risk factor for thyroid cancer.

Option C: Blood

  • Cigarette smoke does not increase the risk of blood cancer.

Option D: Gallbladder

  • Smoking is not a risk factor for carcinoma gallbladder.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presented to the OPD with a long-standing history of dysphagia and oral ulcers. He also gave a history of tobacco and alcohol consumption over the last 20 years. Now he has developed a whitish patch over the tongue, and there is painful  opening of the mouth. On examination, there was cervical lymphadenopathy, and a hard lump was found on the underside of the oral cavity. Which of the following is a major risk factor for oral cancer?

choices.text: Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis are seen in Leukoplakia
Speckled erythroplakia is having lower risk than erythroplakia
Erythroplakia lesions with moderate to severe dysplasia should be excised
Leukoplakia is most commonly found on the soft palate and tonsillar pillars

questions.solution:
Option A: Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis are seen in Leukoplakia

  • Parakeratosis is a mode of keratinization characterized by the retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum.
  • Oral frictional hyperkeratosis is a benign white lesion of the oral mucosa caused by chronic trauma to the site.
  • Basic microscopic characteristics of oral leukoplakia include hyperkeratosis of ortho- or parakeratotic type and acanthosis of the epithelium, with various degrees of chronic inflammatory infiltrates in lamina propria. Also, various degrees of epithelial dysplasia may occur.

Option B: Speckled erythroplakia is having lower risk than erythroplakia

  • Speckled erythroplakia has a higher risk than erythroplakia
  • Erythroplakia and speckled leukoplakia are oral precancerous lesions with a high potential for malignant transformation.

Option C: Erythroplakia lesions with moderate to severe dysplasia should be excised

  • Leukoplakia lesions with moderate to severe dysplasia should be excised.
  • Moderate and severe epithelial dysplasia is usually treated by removing the patch surgically. In some cases, laser treatment is offered. 

Option D: Leukoplakia is most commonly found on the soft palate and tonsillar pillars

  • Erythroplakia is most commonly found on the soft palate and tonsillar pillars.
  • Erythroplakia appears as abnormal red lesions on the mucous membranes in your mouth. The lesions typically occur on the tongue or on the floor of the mouth. They can't be scraped off. Erythroplakia lesions are often found alongside leukoplakia lesions.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant has undergone surgical treatment for meningomyelo encephalocele. At birth, an operation was carried out in the posterior cranial fossa to partially replace cerebellar brain contents to an intracranial position, leading to the development of hydrocephalus. On investigating progressive hydrocephalus, it is noted that the cerebellar tonsils are herniated through the foramen magnum. The neurosurgeon has diagnosed the baby with a syndrome that may include which of the following?

choices.text: Fusion of the temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes
Abnormal elongation of the medulla and lower cranial nerves
Partial or complete absence of the pituitary gland

questions.solution:
Option C: Abnormal elongation of the medulla and lower cranial nerves

  • Based on the surgical history for meningo myelo encephalocele, development of progressive hydrocephalus, and herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, the most likely diagnosis is Arnold-Chiari syndrome.
  • In Arnold-Chiari syndrome, there is an abnormal elongation of the medulla and lower cranial nerves.
  • There is the displacement of the cerebellar tonsils, medulla, and the fourth ventricle into the spinal canal, sometimes with accompanying meningomyelocele. In such circumstances, the cord cavity connects with and may merely represent a dilated central canal.
  • Additional features include the fusion of the corpora quadrigemina, leading to a "beaked tectum''; the partial or complete absence of the corpus callosum; and microgyria.
  • MRI is the most useful imaging study for diagnosing Chiari malformation.
  • Patients with Chiari malformations with minimal or equivocal symptoms without syringomyelia can be treated conservatively. Mild neck pain and headaches can be treated with analgesics, muscle relaxants, and the occasional use of a soft collar. The symptomatic patients should be offered surgical treatment.
  • The goals of surgical treatment are decompression of the cervicomedullary junction and restoration of normal CSF flow in the region of the foramen magnum.

Severity

Chiari Spectrum

Dandy-Walker Spectrum

Type I - Tonsillar herniation

Mega Cisterna Magna

Type II - Brainstem and vermis herniation, lumbar myelomeningocele

Dandy-Walker variant-Mild enlargement of 4th ventricle

Type III - cerebellar herniation into cervical myelomeningocele

Dandy-walker Malformation - Massive enlargement of 4th ventricle with large posterior fossa

Type IV - Cerebellar agenesis with small posterior fossa

 

Option A: Fusion of the frontal lobes

  • Based on the diagnosis of Arnold-Chiari syndrome, a fusion of frontal lobes is unlikely.
  • Fusion of the frontal lobes is seen in the Holoprosencephaly group of structural disorders.

Option B: Fusion of the temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes

  • Based on the diagnosis of Arnold-Chiari syndrome, no fusion of the temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes will be seen.
  • In Arnold-Chiari syndrome, there is neither fusion of the frontal lobes nor the fusion of the temporal, parietal and occipital lobes.

Option D: Partial or complete absence of the pituitary gland

  • Based on the diagnosis of Arnold-Chiari syndrome, the partial or complete absence of the pituitary gland is unlikely.
  • Empty-Sella syndrome is when the pituitary gland shrinks or becomes flattened.
  • The pituitary sits inside a bony compartment in the skull's base called the sella.
  • When the pituitary gland becomes smaller or flattened, it cannot be seen on an MRI scan. This makes the area of the pituitary gland look like an "empty sella." 
  • It is often filled with cerebrospinal fluid. With empty sella syndrome, CSF drips into the sella turcica, pressurizing the pituitary gland. This causes the gland to shrink or flatten.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a burn injury 2 hours ago. Examination reveals second-degree burns covering 20% of the total body surface area. The patient is immediately resuscitated with fluids. Which of the following fluids is most commonly used in the patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ringer lactate

  • Ringer Lactate is the most commonly used fluid in burn patients.
  • Some centres use human albumin, fresh frozen plasma (FFP), or hypertonic saline
  • Intravenous resuscitation is appropriate for any child with a burn greater than 10% of total body surface area (TBSA) and 15% TBSA for adults
  • Rule of 9 is used to calculate the body surface area with a burn.
  • The most widely used and simplest formula to calculate fluid requirement is the Parkland formula

Volume = total percentage body surface area x weight (kg) x 4

Half this volume is given in the first 8 hours, and the second half is given in the subsequent 16 hours

Option A: Dextrose 5%

  • Dextrose 5 % is a hypotonic fluid.
  • It is used to cover the free water deficit. It is not the best choice for burn patients.

Option B: Normal saline

  • Normal saline is not used in burn patients as it contains chloride in an increased amount, and it can lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
  • Normal saline also increases the risk for hypercoagulability.

Option D: Albumin 5%

  • Albumin 5% is a colloid. It is used in patients with hepatorenal syndrome and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
  • Although it can be used in burn patients, it is not the fluid of choice

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was hit by an auto and got dragged on the road for a distance of 50 meters. She was brought to ER in an ambulance and got admitted. On examination, multiple abrasions were noted all over the body, and a laceration of size 6x0.5cm on her left hand. There was no fatal injury noted and hence discharged on the 3rd day. The tensile strength of all these wounds would become normal after:-
questions.solution:
The tensile strength of wound never equals that of unwounded skin

Normal wound healing involves

  • inflammatory phase
  • proliferative phase
  • remodelling phase

Inflammatory phase

  • Begins immediately and lasts 2-3 days
  • Bleeding — vasoconstriction — thrombus formation to limit blood loss
  • Rubor, Tumor, calor and dolor occurs in this phase
  • Chemotaxis and proliferation of inflammatory cells

Proliferative phase (3rd day to 3rd week )

  • Fibroblast activity with the production of collagen (type III) and ground substance
  • Angioneogenesis
  • Reepithelialisation of wound surface

Remodelling phase

  • Maturation of collagen (type I replacing type III until a ratio of 4:1 is achieved)
  • This leads to increased tensile strength in the wound which is maximal at the 12th week post injury and represents approximately 80% of the uninjured skin strength

questions.text: A 27-year-old, 38-week pregnant woman is posted for an emergency cesarean section due to fetal distress. The classical skin incision was given for cesarean section. After surgery, she was monitored closely for 12 hours in the postoperative room, which was uneventful. In this patient's sutured surgical wound, when can you expect the epithelialization process to be completed?

choices.text: Begins from 3rd day and lasts for 3–6 weeks
