Begins from 2nd day and lasts for 1–2 weeks

questions.solution:
Option B: 48 hours

  • There  are four distinct phases of wound healing:
  • Hemostasis phase:
    • Vasoconstriction of blood vessels and clots' formation stops bleeding and prevents infection.
    • Inflammation Phase.
    • This phase begins within 0-5 days.
  • Inflammatory phase:
    • It is initiated by neutrophils that attach to endothelial cells in the vessel walls surrounding the wound (margination), change shape and move through the cell junctions (diapedesis).
  • Proliferative phase:
    • In this process, epithelialization occurs within 48 hours because the cell undergoes rapid mitotic divisions.
    • It results in the migration of new cells to the wound site until the wound bed is completely covered.
    • Angiogenesis, collagen formation and contraction also occur during this phase.
  • Maturation phase:
    • It is the final phase of the healing process in which the granulation tissue matures into a scar, and tissue tensile strength is increased.

Option A: 24 hours

  • The inflammatory phase occurs within 24 hours of wound healing.
  • This phase can last up to 2 weeks in normal wounds and longer in chronic non-healing wounds.

Option C: 72 hours

  • The proliferative phase is still taking place during this hour.
  • This phase is characterized by granulation tissue formation, collagen deposition, and angiogenesis at the wound site.
  • The primary aim of the proliferation phase is to fill the wound defect. 

Option D: 96 hours

  • The proliferative phase lasts 4 to 21 days.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the clinic with a change in bowel habits, occasional bleeding while defecating, flatulence, urinary urgency, and mild abdominal pain with heaviness in the left lower quadrant. He has an allergy to fibrous foods and does not use them routinely. His CT scan shows the thickening and outpouching of the colonic wall, and his enema contrast shows a saw-tooth appearance of the colon. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Colonic diverticulitis

  • The patient with Colonic diverticulitis usually describes his symptoms as rectal bleeding occasionally, altered bowel habits and pain in the left lower quadrant.
  • The pain and heaviness in the left lower quadrant are due to inflammation of the abnormal sac of colons, usually of the sigmoidal colon.
  • The etiology, in this case, is a low-fiber diet because a lack of fibers in the diet causes small-volume stools requiring high intra-luminal pressure and tension for propulsion resulting in muscular hypertrophy and pulsion diverticula.
  • The investigation of choice for colonic diverticulitis is barium enema.
  • The barium enema shows a saw-tooth appearance of the colon because of the outpouching of colonic mucosa.

Option B: Ulcerative colitis

  • The colonoscopic examination reveals inflammatory cells in mucosa and crypts.

Option C: Hamartomatous polys

  • In this condition, multiple polyps formation in the colonic wall is seen on colonoscopy.

Option D: Angiodysplasia

  • The colonoscopic examination shows dilated mucosal and sub-mucosal veins.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe gastritis. Her endoscopy is performed on the doctor's recommendation. During the procedure, the patient suddenly develops severe pain and swelling in the neck, with crepitus suggestive of iatrogenic esophageal perforation. Which part of the esophagus is most susceptible to this type of injury?

choices.text: Above the arch of the aorta
Below the arch of the aorta

questions.solution:
Option B: Cervical portion

  • The cervical portion of the esophagus is most susceptible to iatrogenic esophageal perforation

Common sites of esophageal perforation

Anatomic landmark Description
Piriform sinus Trumpet players, manual labourers, and singers are prone to develop piriform sinus perforations.
Killian triangle Pharyngoesophageal diverticula occur here, and inadvertent cannulation of the diverticulum results in perforation.
Cricopharyngeous muscle Most common site of iatrogenic perforation.
Aortic arch/bronchus Esophagus is in direct contact with the aortic arch and bronchus, which both create a small indentation on the esophagram.
Gastroesophageal junction Most common site of perforation in Boerhaave’s syndrome.

Etiology:

Esophageal perforation
Iatrogenic Spontaneous
  • Most common type(60%)
  • Caused by endoscopy
  • The most common site is the cervical esophagus (cricopharyngeal area)
  • Esophageal rupture after vomiting
  • Most common site: the left posterolateral side of the distal esophagus

 

 

Option A: Abdominal portion

  • It is the most common site of perforation in Boerhaave’s syndrome.

Option C: Above the arch of the aorta

  • Iatrogenic perforation rarely develops above the arch of the aorta.

Option D: Below the arch of the aorta

  • Iatrogenic perforation rarely develops below the arch of the aorta.

questions.text: Which of the following is the investigation of choice for a patient with esophageal rupture?

choices.text: Water soluble low molecular weight contrast swallow

questions.solution:
Option D: Water soluble low molecular weight contrast swallow

  • The investigation of choice for esophageal rupture is water soluble low molecular weight contrast swallow.
  • The use of a water-soluble medium such as Gastrografin is preferred due to the concern of exacerbating contamination if barium were used and leaked.
  • Esophageal rupture:
    • Pain is a striking and consistent symptom and strongly suggests that an esophageal rupture has occurred, particularly in the cervical area, following instrumentation of the esophagus or substernal in a patient with vomiting.
    • If subcutaneous emphysema is present, the diagnosis is almost certain
    • Within the first 8 to 24 hours following injury, frank sepsis may develop if the contamination is extensive
    • Investigations:
      • Initial screening evaluation is with a plain upright chest radiograph which may reveal a pleural effusion, pneumothorax, pneumoperitoneum, subcutaneous or mediastinal emphysema, or mediastinal widening suggestive of perforation. But normal X-ray does not rule out the possibility of a leak.
    • Abnormalities of chest radiograms are dependent on three factors: 
      • The time interval between perforation and radiographic examination
      • Site of perforation
      • The integrity of the mediastinal pleura
    • The diagnosis is confirmed with a contrast esophagram which will demonstrate extravasation in 90% of patients.
    • A 10% False negative rate is noted.
    • CT is another diagnostic modality which can be used.

Option A: Dynamic MRI

  • Dynamic MRI is not the investigation of choice in case of esophageal rupture.

Option B: Rigid esophagoscopy

  • Rigid esophagoscopy is not the investigation of choice in case of esophageal rupture.

Option C: Barium swallow

  • Barium swallow is the investigation of choice for zenker's diverticulum.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male arrives at the emergency department complaining of a mass in the epigastric region for the past two months. A history of weight loss and loss of appetite is present. Endoscopy and biopsy revealed a Stage 3 gastric adenocarcinoma in the antrum. A subtotal gastrectomy with D2 dissection is performed. The procedure includes which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: More than 15 lymph nodes removed

    Generally, in the radical subtotal gastrectomy procedure, the surgeon strives for a grossly negative margin of at least 5 cm.
  • In the absence of involvement by direct extension, the spleen and pancreatic tail are not removed.
  • D1 resection involves the removal of the primary tumour with perigastric nodes (stations 1,2, 3,4,5,6, and 7)
  • The operation provided that tumour-free margins are obtained, more than 15 lymph nodes are removed, and all gross tumours are resected.
  • Reconstruction is usually by Billroth II gastro-jejunostomy or Roux-en-Y reconstruction.
  • D2 dissection includes resection of stations 8 to 12a.

Option B: Grossly negative margins of 2 cm

  • Generally, in this procedure, the surgeon strives for a grossly negative margin of at least 5 cm.

Option C: Distal pancreatectomy

  • In the absence of involvement by direct extension, the spleen and pancreatic tail are not removed.

Option D: Splenectomy

  • In the absence of involvement by direct extension, the spleen and pancreatic tail are not removed.

questions.text: Which of the following is the investigation of choice for intermittent low-grade intestinal obstruction?
questions.solution:
Option C: Enteroclysis

  • Enteroclysis is the investigation of choice for diagnosis of low-grade intermittent small bowel obstruction.
  • IOC for diagnosis of Small bowel obstruction is Abdominal X-ray.
  • Enteroclysis:
    • Enteroclysis is a gastrointestinal technique designed to improve the small bowel's evaluation.
    • The conventional fluoroscopic technique is not widely used since it is somewhat invasive, time and labour-intensive, and not particularly pleasant for the patient.
    • The exam also requires a degree of skill to perform, and often the information can be gathered through other techniques.
    • In experienced hands, however, it is the best radiographic technique for evaluating the small bowel mucosa.

Option A: X-ray

  • Erect abdominal films are no longer routinely obtained, and the radiological diagnosis is based on a passive abdominal film
  • An erect film may subsequently be requested when further doubt exists.

Option B: USG

  • USG is used to diagnose intestinal hepatobiliary pathologies.
  • For intermittent intestinal obstruction, enteroclysis is preferred.

Option D: Barium meal follow-through

  • Barium small-bowel follow-through are used to diagnose small intestine disorders, such as ulcers, tumours, and inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital with severe hemorrhagic shock due to polytrauma with a hip fracture; she developed acidosis, coagulopathy, and hypothermia. Which of the following is the first line of therapy for this patient of trauma?
questions.solution:
Option A: Crystalloids

  • The first line of therapy in shock in the patient of trauma is crystalloids.
  • Most patients of shock, regardless of the cause, benefit from a trial of fluid resuscitation given in the form of a crystalloid bolus.
  • Resuscitation following blood loss in trauma patients begins with the administration of 1 litre of isotonic crystalloid immediately to restore blood pressure and peripheral circulation.
  • Lactated ringer (RL) solution is generally preferred over 0.9% NaCl (normal saline) as it is a balanced salt solution designed to mimic extracellular fluid.

Option B: Colloids

  • Resuscitation with colloids is no more effective than crystalloids but is more expensive.

Option C: Inotropes

  • Vasopressors and inotropes are drugs used to create vasoconstriction or increase cardiac contractility, respectively, in patients for shock or any other reason for extremely low blood pressure.

Option D: Blood transfusion

  • For actively bleeding patients, blood and blood products should remain the best therapy in resuscitating bleeding patients.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain during urination associated with fever, muscle pain, and weakness. Ten months ago, she underwent a pre-emptive renal allograft transplant. Her medication includes thymoglobulin, tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil (MMF), and methylprednisolone. Her temperature is 37.8ºC(100ºF), her pulse is 90/min, and her blood pressure is 163/85mm Hg. Examination shows a well-healed incision over the right lower abdomen. On laboratory testing, a positive urinalysis for decoy cells was found. It preceded a rise in creatinine to 2 mg/dL. Which of the following is the causal viral agent?
questions.solution:
Option A: Polyoma virus BK

  • A non-enveloped, double-stranded circular DNA virus of the polyomavirus family that infects the urothelium.
  • BK virus infection is widespread but asymptomatic in the general population.
  • Reactivation of the virus in immunosuppressed patients (especially transplant recipients) is associated with developing ureteric strictures, Polyoma virus-associated nephropathy, and generalized vasculopathy.
  • Renal biopsy, quantifying plasma or urinary BKV DNA, and urinary decoy cells in urine cytology are necessary for diagnosis.
  • Timely detection and early reduction of immunosuppression are critical and can reduce rates of graft loss related to polyoma virus-associated nephropathy from 90% to 10-30%.

Most common opportunistic infections in renal transplant recipients:

Peri-transplant (<1 month )

  • Wound infections
  • Herpes virus
  • Oral candidiasis
  • Urinary tract infection

Early ( 1-6 months)

  • Pneumocytis carinii
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Legionella
  • Listeria
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis C

Late (>6 months)

  • Aspergillus
  • Nocardia
  • BK virus (polyoma)
  • Herpes zoster
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis C

 

Option B: Human herpes virus type 6

  • Human herpes virus type 6 is a herpes virus that causes roseola infantum in infants and children.
  • Roseola infantum is characterized by high fever, which ends abruptly after three to five days, followed by the sudden appearance of a maculopapular rash. Roseola infantum is a self-limiting condition. Febrile seizures are a possible complication of infection.

 

Option C: Cytomegalovirus

  • Cytomegalovirus is generally asymptomatic in an immunocompetent host. Immunocompromised individuals (e.g., AIDS, post-transplantation) are especially at risk of illness following reactivation or initial infection, which can include severe manifestations such as CMV Retinitis or life-threatening CMV Pneumonia.

Option D: Human papillomavirus, high-risk types

  • High-risk human papillomavirus is associated with an increased risk of cervical, anogenital, oral, and oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female developed a tumor on the knee joint. She has pain in the affected area, which is not sharp. X-ray shows marginal sclerosis and lobulated structures. A biopsy was done, showing the pathology below. It is self-limiting most of the time. Which of the following are differentials of the given pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Non-ossifying fibroma

  • The above is a non-ossifying fibroma, a fibrous cortical defect.
  • Most common benign lesion.
  • Involves the metaphysis.
  • Self-resolving.
  • Not premalignant. 

Option A: Ossifying fibroma

  • The biopsy image shows a characteristic multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cell with nuclei similar to the surrounding mononuclear cells, suggesting a giant cell tumor.
  • An eccentric lytic lesion with no calcification is the commonest differential for giant Cell Tumors.
  • Calcification:
    • Ossifying fibroma
    • Chondroblastoma
    • Osteosarcoma
  • Hence non-ossifying fibroma is a preferred answer here.
  • A tumor of distal end radius is always a giant cell tumor until proven otherwise.
  • The most common site of giant cell tumors is lower end femur
  • The lower-end femur is the most common site for
    • Giant cell tumor
    • Osteosarcoma
    • Osteomyelitis
  • Tissue biopsy to differentiate b/w giant cell tumor & giant cell variants.
  • Giant cell variants: -
  • Have giant cells are lytic
  • On – Ossifying fibroma (commonest) fibrous cortical deficit
    • FD (fibrous Dysplasia)
    • Chondroblastoma
    • Chondromyxoid fibroma
    • Osteoblastoma/osteosarcoma
    • Brown tumor (Hyperparathyroidism) osteogenic

Non-ossifying fibroma:

  •  
  • Benign (non-cancerous)
  • Eccentric
  • Age <15 years
  • Non-aggressive tumor
  • Metaphyseal lesion
  • Sclerotic margin
  • Histologically giant cell with foam cell

 

Note: Closest differential is ABC.

Option C: Osteogenic sarcoma

  • Primary is idiopathic.
  • Secondary comes with Paget disease, bone infarction, and radiation injury.
  • Pain worsens at night and with activity.
  • Swelling is progressive.
  • A pathological fracture can happen.
  • Limping and decreased range of motion can happen.

Option D: Chondroblastoma

  • Benign tumor of cartilage.
  • It is very rare.
  • Peak incidence in ages 10-20.
  • Location epiphysis.
  • Joint pain and swelling.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to the clinic for the evaluation of his arm deformity for the past 2 months. Four months ago, he fell from the roof and got his humerus fractured. At that time, he was treated by a local doctor for his injury. On examination, his arm findings are given below.Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current deformity?
questions.solution:
Option B: Supracondylar fracture Humerus

  • The images show Cubitus varus deformity.
  • Cubitus varus (Gunstock deformity): Caused by supracondylar fracture of humerus leading to varus malunion, especially in medial comminution pattern.
  • Cubitus varus: Carrying angle decreases

Option A: Humerus lateral condylar fracture

  • Intra-Articular Fracture
  • This can also lead to ''Tardy Ulnar nerve palsy.''
  • Complication: Cubitus valgus is caused by the Non- union of fracture of lateral condyle of the Humerus bone.

Option C: Fracture shaft Humerus

  • Radial nerve injury leads to wrist drop.
  • The most common cause of radial nerve injury is the Fracture shaft Humerus.

Option D: Medial Condyle fracture of humerus

  • It is a type of avulsion injury.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with the complaint of generalized fatigue and pain in both the wrist and the knee joint for the past many months. She explains that she has associated stiffness which is worst in the morning but improves after two hours. Her medical history is consistent with diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years. Her only medication includes metformin. On examination, her wrist and knee joints are swollen bilaterally. Antibody screening shows IgM antibodies against the Fc component of the IgG antibody. Her ESR and CRP are markedly elevated. Further testing is pending. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis

This patient with bilateral knee and wrist pain, prolonged morning stiffness, elevated ESR and CRP, and Positive rheumatoid factor most likely has rheumatoid arthritis.

Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease of the joints.
  • In Rheumatoid arthritis, the synovium becomes oedematous and filled with fibrin exudates and cellular infiltrates.
  • There is an increase in synovial fluid.
  • As the inflammation persists, the synovium gets hypertrophied and surrounds the periphery of the articular cartilage to form a pannus

Deformities of Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Swan neck deformity: Flexion at DIP and hyperextension at PIP (Flexor insufficiency of PIP)

  • Boutonniere deformity(Buttonhole deformity): Hyperextension of DIP and flexion of PIP (extensor deficiency at PIP joint

Option A: Osteoarthritis

  • Signs of osteoarthritis: Narrowing of joint space, Age-related subchondral sclerosis, Marginal osteophytes, and Subchondral cysts.
  • Osteoarthritis in knee involving medial compartment: Genu varum
  • It is common in females, usually after the age of 65.
  • Morning stiffness is for less than 30 minutes
  • Joints are not inflamed unless infection occurs.

Option C: Gout

  • Fever is common
  • Presentation is often acute, and at night
  • Morning stiffness is not present
  • Inflamed Great toe
  • Crystal deposited: Uric acid- negatively birefringent needle-shaped.
  • X-ray findings: Bone and soft tissue erosions

Option D: Psoriatic arthritis

  • The radiological findings of Psoriatic arthritis include erosion of joints, pencil-in cup appearance, and acro-osteolysis.
  • It is common in young males.
  • The spine is the most affected joint

questions.text: A 38-year-old Lorry driver driving a long distance decides to take a nap, parks his vehicle on the side of the road, and sleeps under the lorry. Unfortunately, another lorry driver driving under the influence of alcohol loses control and hit this lorry on the backside. The patient is brought to the emergency 2 hours after the incident. Proximal limb amputation is planned for this patient. What is the normal permissible ischemia time?
questions.solution:
Option B: 6 hours

  • Irreversible necrotic changes begin in muscles after 6 hours of ischemia (warm ischemia time).
  • It is preferable to begin the replantation of parts with good muscular bulk (viz., parts proximal to palms and foot) within this time.
  • Cooling (to 4°C) may extend this time to 12 hours (cold ischemia time).

A sequence of re-implantation:

The sequence of reimplantation (Mnemonic: BE FAN VS)

  • B- Bone (first to be implanted)
  • E-Extensor tendon
  • F-Flexor tendon
  • A-Arteries
  • Nerves
  • V-Veins
  • S- Skin (preserved first and implanted last)

Option A: 4 hours

  • The permissible ischemic time for the heart and lungs is 4 hours.

Option C: 24 hours

  • The permissible ischemic time for the kidney is < 24 hours

Option D: 12 hours

  • Less than Twelve hours is the permissible ischemic time for the pancreas.

questions.text: What is the first-line treatment for a 60-year-old male with end-stage renal failure with severe hyperkalemia-induced ventricular tachycardia following DC shock?
questions.solution:
Option B: Calcium gluconate

  • Calcium gluconate must be administered first in a patient with hyperkalemia to make the cardiac membrane resistant to the effect of hyperkalemia.
  • Hyperkalemia:
    • Up to 10% of hospitalized patients have hyperkalemia, defined as a plasma potassium level of 5.5 mmol/L or higher; severe hyperkalemia (defined as a level of >6.0 mEq/L), which occurs in 1% of cases and carries a high mortality risk, is more common.
    • Hyperkalemia can be rapidly brought on by redistribution and decreased tissue uptake, but the most common underlying cause is a decrease in renal K+ excretion.
    • Because it has an adverse effect on the heart, hyperkalemia is a medical emergency.
    • Sinus bradycardia, sinus arrest, delayed idioventricular rhythms, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, and asystole are hyperkalemia-related cardiac arrhythmias.
    • Mild increases in plasma K+ concentration depress intracardiac conduction, leading to progressive elongation of the PR and QRS periods; additional increases in extracellular K+ concentration alter the repolarization phase of the cardiac action potential, altering T-wave morphology.
    • The loss of the P wave and gradual broadening of the QRS complex are signs of severe hyperkalemia. The emergence of a sine-wave sinoventricular rhythm is a warning sign of impending ventricular fibrillation or asystole.
    • The electrocardiogram (ECG) type I Brugada pattern, which includes a pseudo-right bundle branch block and persistent coved ST segment elevation in at least two precordial leads, can also be brought on by hyperkalemia.
    • This hyperkalemic Brugada's sign can be distinguished from hereditary Brugada's syndrome by the absence of P waves, strong QRS widening, and aberrant QRS axis in critically unwell patients with severe hyperkalemia.
    • The electrocardiographic signs of hyperkalemia often evolve from tall peaked T waves (5.5–6.5 mEq/L) to a loss of P waves (6.5–7.5 mEq/L), a broadened QRS complex (7.0–8.0 mEq/L), and, finally, a sine wave pattern (>8.0 mEq/L).
    • These modifications, however, are well known for being insensitive, especially in patients with chronic renal disease or ESRD.
    • Patients with hyperkalemia and characteristic ECG changes should be given intravenous calcium gluconate.
    • Acutely lower potassium by giving intravenous insulin with glucose, a beta2 agonist by a nebulizer, or both.
    • Total body potassium should usually be lowered with sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate).

Option A: Glucose insulin drip

  • Glucose plus insulin can be given in hyperkalemia, but the first step is to stabilize the cardiac membrane with calcium gluconate

Option C: Hemodialysis

  • Hemodialysis is indicated when the hyperkalemia does not respond to the medical treatment.

Option D: Potassium chelating resins

  • In cases when potassium is not controlled with insulin plus glucose or Beta-2 agonists, potassium chelating agents are used.

questions.text: What is a potential adverse effect of using a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) during the anesthesia for fibroadenoma removal in a 32-year-old female when Glycopyrrolate, Propofol, fentanyl, and succinylcholine are administered, and oxygen/nitrous oxide and sevoflurane are used for maintenance?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pulmonary aspiration

  • The endotracheal tube is the best device and definitive airway to prevent aspiration.
  • There is an increased incidence of aspiration of gastric contents with a laryngeal mask airway.
  • The laryngeal mask airway is a supraglottic airway device which sits in the hypopharynx and forms a seal around the epiglottic tissues.
    • The seal around the laryngeal inlet allows for the delivery of oxygen and volatile agents during spontaneous ventilation and permits positive pressure ventilation at pressures up to 20 cm H2O.
    • Once positioned, the cuff should be inflated with the minimum air volume, with a target cuff pressure of 60 cm H2O.

Advantages

Disadvantages
  • Easy and rapid
  • Less invasive
  • Better hemodynamic stability
  • Very useful in difficult intubations
  • Lack of need for muscle relaxation
  • requires a lesser plane of Anaesthesia
  • Avoidance of risk of some risks of tracheal intubation(trauma to teeth and airway, sore throat, coughing on emergence, bronchospasm)
  • It can be used for ventilation as a primary airway management device, rescue airway device, and a conduit for tracheal intubation.
  • Supraglottic airway devices have comparatively lesser seal pressures than tracheal tubes, which leads to ineffective ventilation when higher airway pressures required
  • Increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration when first-generation Supraglottic airway devices used
  • No protection from laryngospasm
  • Less safe in prone or jackknife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of the gas leak and pollution
  • Can cause gastric distention

Option A: Less invasive

  • LMA is a less invasive technique to provide ventilation than the other methods.

Option B: Less haemodynamic alteration

  • It is better hemodynamic stability
  • As there is no need for any specific arrangements been needed.

Option D: Lesser time for insertion

  • Its application needs no time as it's a less invasive technique, so less time is required for its insertion.

questions.text: What is a potential complication of positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) in a 50-year-old patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and respiratory distress who is receiving noninvasive ventilation in the intensive care unit?
questions.solution:
Option C: Increased intracranial pressure

  • PEEP causes an increase in end-expiratory pressure, which leads to changes to other organ systems as well.
  • It increases intrathoracic pressure and decreases venous return from the brain. This can result in increased intracranial pressure.

Option A: Increased Urine Output

  • Decreased venous return secondary to increased intrathoracic pressure leads to hypoperfusion of glomeruli. This results in decreased urine output, not increased output.

Option B: Increased Blood Pressure

  • Increased intrathoracic pressure causes decreased venous return. This causes a decrease in cardiac output, leading to hypotension, not hypertension.

Option D: Decreased intrathoracic pressure

  • PEEP is basically an extrinsic air pressure that is being delivered to distend alveoli and improve oxygenation.
  • However, this extrinsic pressure can lead to an increase in pressure in the chest wall cavity causing increased intrathoracic pressure.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented to the labour room with a full-term gestation in labour pains. She wants labour analgesia. What is the gold standard method of labour analgesia selected for this patient?

choices.text: Epidural anaesthetic in combination with spinal anaesthetic
Epidural anaesthetic in combination with a general anaesthetic

questions.solution:
Option A: Continuous lumbar epidural

  • Because it provides adequate analgesia in both phases of labour, continuous lumbar epidural analgesia is the most adaptable
  • The most often utilised strategy for producing labour analgesia is continuous lumbar epidural analgesia, which can give analgesia during the early stage of labour and anaesthesia for a vaginal birth or caesarean section if necessary.
  • T10-L1 sensory block is necessary during the first stage of labour for effective pain management, and S2-S4 (Pudendal nerve block) is required during the second stage. The epidural catheter inserted at the L3-L4 or L4-L5 interspace affords adequate T10-S5 neural blockage.
  • Advantages of this technique:
    • No dural puncture required
    • Able to titrate the extent of sensory blockade
    • Continuous intraoperative and postoperative anaesthesia and analgesia, respectively
    • Can use in situ catheters placed for earlier administration of labour analgesia
    • No significant hemodynamic alterations in a segmental or differential blockade

Option B: Epidural nerve block

  • Indications for Epidural nerve block include:
  • Sole epidural anaesthetic
  • Surgeries of lower limbs, including hip, knee, and pelvic areas
  • Lower limb amputations
  • Caesarean delivery
  • Surgeries of female pelvic organs
  • Prostate and bladder surgeries
  • Lower abdominal surgeries, including appendectomy, bowel surgeries, and hernia repair

Option C: Epidural anaesthetic in combination with spinal anaesthetic

  • This combination is referred to as a combined spinal epidural (CSE).
  • All indications noted above for sole epidural anaesthetic may also be performed with CSE.

Option D: Epidural anaesthetic in combination with a general anaesthetic

  • Epidural analgesia combined with general anaesthesia reduces the incidence of postoperative pneumonia in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease who are undergoing major abdominal surgery.
  • Indications include;
  • Penile procedures
  • Inguinal hernia repair
  • Lower limb orthopaedic procedures.
  • Thoracotomy
  • Cardiac bypass and other cardiac surgeries.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presented with complaints of a mass in the right upper quadrant of her right breast. Mammography is performed. Which of the following findings on mammography would suggest a malignant lesion?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: Microcalcifications

  • Deposits of calcium salts in the breast are referred to as breast calcifications and are radio-opaque on mammography.

  • Although the majority are benign, cancer may be connected to them.

  • The art and science of breast imaging include the capacity to identify, treat, and distinguish between serious microcalcifications and insignificant findings.

  • Microcalcifications are suggestive of a malignant lesion.

  • The pattern and shape of microcalcifications can also give radiologists clues about whether cancer may be present.

    • Linear, rod-like calcifications raise suspicion of underlying breast cancer.

    • Popcorn, eggshell, and rim-like calcifications are usually benign.

Option A: Round well-defined borders

 

  • Round and oval lumps with well-defined borders are often harmless.

  • An uneven form indicates a higher chance of cancer.

  • The edges may be circumscribed, microlobulated, obscured (partially covered by surrounding tissue), ill-defined, or spiculated (characterised by lines radiating from the mass).

Option B: Macrocalcifications

  • Popcorn calcifications, also known as macrocalcifications, are benign tumors called fibroadenomas.

Option D: Fat necrosis

  • When local fat is saponified, a degenerative condition known as fat necrosis in the breast occurs.

  • It is a benign inflammatory condition becoming more prevalent due to the increased usage of mammoplasty and breast-conserving surgery.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by the rescue team after a road traffic accident. The patient is in an unconscious state with a GCS of 8/15. On examination, the patient has an open wound on the parietal area of the head. The wound was washed and stitched, and the patient was sent for a brain CT scan. The CT brain showed no midline shift but multiple tiny haemorrhages in the brain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Diffuse axonal injuries

  • This is a case of diffuse axonal injury.

  • The patient sustained a head injury due to a road traffic accident. The CT brain of the patient shows multiple tiny hemorrhages in the brain.

  • These multiple tiny hemorrhages are called diffuse axonal injuries.

  • Diffuse axonal injury: -

    • Occurs due to shearing of white matter

    • This occurs mainly because of rotational acceleration

  • Shows multiple petechial hemorrhages, usually at the junction of white and grey matter

  • CT scan may be normal in some cases, so MRI is the investigation of choice.

  • A young patient with RTA→ NCCT- normal/ petechial hemorrhages→ Suspect diffuse axonal injury→ MRI (IOC for DAI).

Option A: Cerebral contusion

  • Cerebral contusion-

  • NCCT image showing hemorrhagic contusion in the bilateral basis-frontal lobe.

Option B: Cerebral laceration

  • A cerebral lesion is a tear in the brain tissue. On CT brain, it gives a salt and paper appearance.

Option C: Multiple cerebral infarcts

  • Multiple cerebral infarcts-

  • NCCT image showing multiple hypodense areas in the right frontal and left frontoparietal and occipital lobe s/o infarcts.

questions.text: A 6-month-old female presented with global developmental delay and history of generalized tonic seizures for 4 months. Her perinatal history and delivery were unremarkable. On physical examination, She had severe hypotonia, head lag, and hypertonicity in the extremities and would not interact socially. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed delayed myelinization at the corpus callosum, genu of the internal capsule, and posterior limb. subsequently, proton magnetic resonance spectrometry (MRS) revealed a prominent NAA peak on the posterior deep white matter lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Canavan disease, also known as spongiform degeneration of white matter (not to be confused with Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease) or aspartoacylase deficiency, is a leukodystrophy clinically characterized by megalencephaly, severe mental and neurological deficits, and blindness.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a genetic mutation on the short arm of chromosome 17. There is a deficiency of N-acetylaspartoacylase, a key enzyme in myelin synthesis, with resultant accumulation of N-acetyl aspartate in the brain, CSF, plasma, and urine.
  • MRS (Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy) of Canavan Disease shows NAA peak at 2 ppm.

Other salient points:

  • Alanine peak is seen at 1.48ppm in meningioma.
  • Lipid lactate peak is seen at 1.33ppm in tuberculoma.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents in the Emergency department after a road traffic accident. He is unconscious. His GCS is 5/15, and his pupils are pinpoint and non-reactive. Brain stem injury is suspected. He is to be intubated. What is the correct position of the endotracheal tube?
questions.solution:
Option C: 2-5 cm above the carina

The position of an E.T. tube is 2-5 cm above the carina, but it varies greatly with neck position and rotation, so including the mandible is a useful indicator.

  • Flexed: 3 cm (± 2 cm) above the carina
  • Neutral: 5 cm (± 2 cm) above the carina
  • Extended: 7 cm (± 2 cm) above the carina

Option A: 1-2 cm above the carina

  • The trachea is shorter in children, so the tip of the ETT should be 1.5 cm above the carina.

Options B and D: 2-5 cm below the carina

  • The location of ETT should be above the carina, not below the carina.

Option D: 1-2 cm below the carina

  • The location of ETT should be above the carina, not below the carina.

questions.text: All Intrauterine devices have a body/frame over which the copper is wound, or the drug is contained in the stem. A newer IUCD, which does not have such a frame, is proposed to have lesser expulsion due to the lack of a body. what is it called?
questions.solution:
Option B : Newer IUDs

Cu-Fix IUD (Flexi-Gard):

  • Frameless IUD consisting of six copper sleeves (300 mm2 of copper) strung on a surgical polypropylene nylon thread, which is knotted at the upper end.

Cu Safe IUD:

  • Device has a T-shaped radio-opaque plastic body. The ends of the flexible transverse arms are inwardly bent, providing a nonirritating, fundus-seeking mechanism.

Options A, C, D : Mirena, Copper T 380 A and multiload, all have frames.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of copious vaginal discharge. The discharge is grey in colour and foul smelling. A microscopic examination of the discharge revealed clue cells. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Metronidazole

Bacterial Vaginosis

  • Hemophilus vaginalis is the most common cause of bacterial vaginosis.
  • It is also known as Gardnerella vaginalis
  • There is a fishy odour from the vagina noticeable after coitus.
  • The vaginal secretions are grey and thinly coat the vaginal walls
  • On microscopy, clue cells can be visualized, which are vaginal epithelial cells embedded with the bacteria
  • There is no pruritus in contrast with candidiasis.
  • The Whiff test: Adding KOH to the vaginal secretions releases an amine-like odour.
  • Amsel's criteria are used for diagnosis
  • Treatment:
    • Metronidazole is the drug of choice
    • Treat the female
    • There is no need to treat her partner as it does not transmit sexually.

Option A: Azithromycin

  • Azithromycin is not routinely recommended for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis.
  • Azithromycin 1 g orally as a single dose can be prescribed to treat chlamydial infections.

Option B: Fluconazole

  • Oral fluconazole is an antifungal agent and can be used to treat Candida infections.

Option D: Clotrimazole

  • Clotrimazole is a topical antifungal agent and is among the drugs of choice for the treatment of Candida balanitis and vulvovaginal candidiasis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with leakage of urine for the last 3 months. She has been married for 14 years and is multiparous with 4 children. Her urodynamic studies suggest stress incontinence, demonstrating urine leakage only when she is asked to cough or do a Valsalva manoeuvre. She was advised some pelvic floor exercises, but she was not relieved. Which of the following surgeries may be helpful in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Kelly's stitch

  • Stress incontinence is the involuntary loss of urine when intravesical pressure exceeds the maximum urethral pressure with increased abdominal pressure.
  • Treatment of stress incontinence includes:
    • Conservative management:
      • Pelvic floor muscle training.
      • Biofeedback therapy.
      • Drugs.
      • Para urethral implants.
    • Surgical Management.
      • Kelly's plication (Kelly's stitch)— Features of Kelly’s plication are shown in the figure below:

 

1. Kelly operation 1914 

  • It consists. of repair of cystocele and/or urethrocele.
  • Vertical mattress sutures are then placed to plicate the whole urethra and bladder neck
  • This gives support to the urethra and restores the normal posterior urethrovesical angle.
  • Operation is done for mild and moderate cases of stress incontinence.
  • Long term success rate is 55-65%. 

 

      • Bursch colposuspension.
      • MMK procedure.
      • Transvaginal sling.
      • Trans obturator sling.
      • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck.

Option B: Le Fort

  • It is a surgery for vaginal prolapse for older women unfit for a vaginal hysterectomy.

Option C: Manchester

  • It is a conservative uterine surgery for prolapse, not for treating stress incontinence.

Option D: Posterior colporrhaphy

  • It is done along with vaginal hysterectomy for posterior compartment tightening. It has no role in the correction of stress incontinence.

questions.text: Which of the following gynaecological lesions listed below seen and diagnosed in women at a health care set up are most likely to pursue benign course and need less strict follow up in asmyptomatic women?
questions.solution:
Option B : Adenomyosis is a benign condition characterized by the presence of benign endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium,

Adenomyosis is a condition in which normal endometrial glands grow into the myometrium. Symptomatic disease primarily occurs in multiparous women over the age of 35 years. Patients with adenomyosis complain of progressive dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia, and the classical examination findings include a tender, symmetrically enlarged uterus without adnexal tenderness.

Option A : Vaginal adenosis is a DES-related precursor lesion for clear cell adenocarcinoma.

Option C : Extramammary Paget’s disease is an intraepithelial adenocarcinoma.

Option D : Endometrial hyperplasia is a precursor lesion of endometrial carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the appropriate statement regarding further treatment for a 58-year-old female with post-menopausal bleeding who is diagnosed with endometrial cancer and is on hormone replacement therapy for 1 year?

choices.text: ET less than 5 mm requires no further evaluation
ET 5 to 10 mm confers no risk of endometrial cancer
No evaluation required in women on HRT

questions.solution:
Option A : An endometrial stripe of less than 5 mm in a postmenopausal woman on HRT confers minimal risk of cancer. ET more than 10 mm correlates with a 10% to 20% risk of hyperplasia or cancer. Thus any endometrial thickness equal to or more than 5 mm in menopausal women whether or not associated with bleeding, must be evaluated. In premenopausal women, an ET of less than 12 mm is considered safe.

Option B : An ET of 5-10 mm carries risk of endometrial cancer.

Option C : Evaluation of the woman is required if ET is more than or equal to 5 mm.

Option D : A hysterectomy is not appropriate until a tissue diagnosis is obtained.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to Gynecology OPD with complaints of abdominal distention and pain over the previous 3 months. Her physical examination reveals an abdominal mass without shifting dullness and bilateral adnexal masses. Her digital rectal examination reveals the presence of induration in the rectal pouch. Her breast examination and recent mammogram are normal. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Option A: Serous cystadenocarcinomas of both ovaries

  • The patient is a 68-year-old woman with abdominal distention, pain with bilateral adnexal masses, and induration in the rectal pouch. Bilateral adnexal masses in postmenopausal must raise suspicion of epithelial ovarian cancers. Most common of which are serous cystadenomas/ carcinomas. Induration in the rectal pouch suggests locally advanced disease and favors a malignancy.
  • The picture below shows the Serous cystadenocarcinoma.

  • Serous cystadenocarcinomas are the most common malignant tumors of ovaries and the most common tumors associated with a bilateral origin.
  • The peak incidence of invasive epithelial ovarian cancer is about 60. About 30% of ovarian neoplasms in postmenopausal women are malignant.
  • Mostly unilocular
  • Bilateral in >50%
  • Mostly malignant
  • Surface growth present
  • Psammoma Bodies are present in 40-45%

​​​​​​​

Option B: Krukenberg’s tumors of the ovaries

  • Krukenberg’s tumors are also bilateral but are associated with another primary malignancy (most commonly gastric carcinoma) and are less common than epithelial tumors.
  • Hence, it is not the correct option.

Option C: Malignant ascites

  • It is ruled out as there is no shifting dullness. Please note that serous cystadenocarcinomas do present with ascites quite commonly.
  • So, it is a false statement.

Option D: Meig's syndrome

  • Meig's syndrome is ascites and pleural effusion associated with fibroma of the ovary, which is again ruled out due to the absence of ascites.
  • So, it is not a true option.

questions.text: An Asian woman aged 35 years with delayed cycles and a history of primary infertility presented to the infertility clinic for an infertility workup. On laparoscopic examination, she has a normal uterus with bilateral enlarged ovaries and normal fallopian tubes; chromotubation shows blue dye spillage; however, she did not give a history of any previous pelvic infection. What is the most probable cause of patient this condition and infertility?
questions.solution:
Option B: Polycystic ovarian syndrome

  • Patient with ovaries that are bulky in size (suggestive of PCOS), and the patient has a history of oligo ovulation as suggested by delayed cycles and infertility.

 

Rotterdam / ESHRE /Androgen excess Society /ASRM criteria

Diagnostic requisites: Any 2 out of 3

  • Anovulation/ oligo-ovulation
  • Hyperandrogenism: clinical or laboratory evidence of androgen excess
  • Polycystic ovaries on USG (20 or more follicles measuring less than 9 mm or ovarian volume of > 10 mL)

Features/ Complications associated with PCOD / PCOS

  1. Obesity
  2. Insulin resistance/hyperinsulinemia
  3. Hyperandrogenaemia
  4. Anovulation
  5. Metabolic X syndrome
  6. Oligomenorrhea
  7. Amenorrhoea

 

Option A: Endometriosis

  • There are no endometriotic cysts or peritoneal implants ruling out the endometriotic cyst. Laparoscopy is the single best investigation of choice for the diagnosis of endometriosis. 

Option C: Ovarian Cyst

  • Ovarian cyst is common and often without symptoms, and they are most of the time harmless and interfere not with fertility. There are no ovarian cysts mentioned and bulky ovaries are due to PCOD and ovarian cysts.

Option D: Tubo-ovarian mass

  • Laparoscopy shows no tubo ovarian mass, also ruled out with free spill from bilateral tubes.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to the gynaecology clinic complaining of vaginal bleeding and mild fever. She had a cessation of menstruation 5 years ago. A pelvic exam shows a normal cervix. Her pap smear done 1 month prior was normal. She has no other comorbidities. USG reveals an endometrial thickness of 1mm and atrophic ovaries. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Senile endometritis

  • The most common cause of bleeding in women after menopause is cervical carcinoma, but it is unlikely here as cervix appears normal and paps smear is also normal.
  • Senile endometritis : After menopause, the endometrium changes and loses its resistance. It is not shed repeatedly, which leads to the entrance of infection in the uterus. Post-menopausal endometrial atrophy due to lack of estrogen causes senile endometritis. It is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding in the west.
  • It is most likely here since more common causes here, such as cervical cancer and endometrial cancer have been ruled out.
  • USG reveals the endometrial thickness of 1mm and atrophic ovaries, so endometrial carcinoma is unlikely.

Option A: Carcinoma cervix

  • Carcinoma of the cervix usually presents itself as post-coital bleeding (PCB), prolonged intermenstrual bleeding (IMB) or post-menopausal bleeding (PMB).
  • Post-coital bleeding is a typical feature of carcinoma of the cervix. In the progression of the disease, patients may also present with several distressing symptoms such as incontinence, pain and anaemia due to vaginal bleeding.
  • Pelvic and speculum examination reveals a cervical mass that bleeds, and tissues appear hard and fixed in advanced disease. In this case, pelvic and speculum examination shows a normal cervix with no underlying pathology.
  • Pap smear in cervix carcinoma reveals abnormal cervical cytology and squamous cells at different stages of maturity, also known as dyskaryosis. In the case mentioned above, a pap smear done 1 month back is normal.

Option B: Carcinoma endometrium

  • USG findings suggestive of Endometrial carcinoma in post-menopausal women are;
  1. Endometrial thickness >4mm
  2. Polypoidal endometrial mass
  3. Fluid in the uterine cavity
  • Since endometrial thickness is 1mm, it is the least suggestive of endometrial carcinoma.

Option D: Carcinoma ovary

  • Ovaries are atrophic, so ovarian cancer is unlikely.
  • Ovarian carcinomas present with a variety of clinical manifestations, including;
  1. Increased abdominal size and girth
  2. Abdominal bloating, digestion problems and non specific symptoms
  3. Irregular bleeding
  4. Backache
  5. Urinary symptoms
  • An abdominal and pelvic exam may reveal hard and fixed mass arising from the pelvis.
  • Pelvic mass, presence of ascites and omental deposits are characteristic features.
  • The patient is not presenting with the above mentioned features, and the presence of atrophic ovaries rules out ovarian cancer.

questions.text: What is true about the Organ of Rosenmuller in reproductive embryology and its associated pathologies?

choices.text: Remnant of Mullerian duct in males
Consists of horizontal tubules in the mesovarium
Tubules are lined by columnar cells
Represents the cranial end of the Wolffian duct

questions.solution:
Option D: Represents the cranial end of the Wolffian duct

  • The structure mentioned above is the organ of the rosenmuller (epoophoron).
  • The organ of rosenmuller (epoophoron) represents the cranial end of the Wolffian duct. It consists of vertical tubules in the mesovarium and mesosalpinx.
  • The tubule is lined by cubical cells.
  • Paroophoron sometimes forms a para ovarian cyst.

 

 

  • The epoophoron is a remnant of an epididymis, completely nonfunctional in the female. If not remnant, it would become an organ in a male, which is responsible for the temporary collection of sperm when going through final maturation.

 

Option A: Remnant of Mullerian duct in males

  • Remnant of Mullerian duct in males persists as appendix testis not organ of rosenmuller.

 

Option B: Consist of horizontal tubules in the mesovarium

  • The organ of the rusenmuller duct consists of vertical tubules in the mesovarium and mesosalpinx, not horizontal tubules.

 

Option C: Tubules are lined by columnar cells

  • The tubules in the organ of a rosenmuller are lined by cubical cells nio by cuboidal cells.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to a fertility clinic with the inability to conceive for 3 years. She and her husband live together and have been married for 4 years. They are not using any contraception at present and are sexually active. Her menses are at regular 28 day intervals. Her husband is a cyclist by profession. The initial tests that should be advised to this couple are?

choices.text: Semen analysis, Tubal patency test, Ovulation test
Testicular biopsy, USG, Sperm penetration test

questions.solution:
Option B: Semen analysis, Tubal patency test, Ovulation test

Order for initial work-up for infertility

    1. Semen analysis
    2. Ovulation test
    3. Tubal patency test

Semen analysis:

  • A test to assess male infertility.
  • Parameters tested include the number, morphology, and mobility of sperm, the semen volume and the semen PH.
  • Test results can include pathologies, such as low sperm count (oligospermia) or complete lack of sperm in the ejaculation.

Ovulation test:

  • Test for ovulation usually includes follicular monitoring for growth and rupture.

Tubal patency test:

  • It is used to check the patency of the tubes if they are blocked or not.
  • Tubal patency test is done in 2 ways
  1. HSG (initial test)
  2. Laparoscopy with Chromopertubation(Confirmatory)

Option A: Semen analysis, CXR, Mantoux test.

  • Semen analysis should be advised to this couple, but chest x-ray and Mantoux skin test may be adviced in patients where TB is a suspected cause and are not first line tests.

Option C: Ovulation, tubal patency, Mantoux test

  • Ovulation and tubal patency tests should be done,
  • Mantoux skin test may be adviced in patients where TB is a suspected cause and is not a first line test.

 

Option D: Testicular biopsy, USG, Sperm penetration test

Testicular biopsy:

  • It is used to diagnose lumps and causes of infertility and obtain sperm for in vitro fertilisation.
  • However, it is not an initial test for infertility evaluation.

Ultrasound:

  • It plays an important role in detecting any fibroid, mass, or tubal defect in females.
  • In males, it is used to check the position of testes and testicular torsion.
  • However, it is not a first-line investigation to detect infertility.

Sperm penetration test:

  • It is used to check if sperm can move through the cervical mucus or not.
  • However, it is not done very often as it gives less information than other fertility tests.

questions.text: A 29-year-old nulliparous woman presents with the complaint of a mass descending per vaginum for three months. She says she's never been married and was sexually active two years ago with her boyfriend for a few months only. On pelvic examination, there is a descent of the uterus and cervix beyond the introitus. Which of the following is the most suitable procedure for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Purandare

  • Fixing the uterus through a cervical stitch into the abdomen is called Abdominal cervicopexy or sling surgery.
  • These surgeries are carried out in young and nulliparous patients where uterine preservation is required for future childbearing.
  • They are of 3 types:
    1. Shirodkar's sling operation (Sling to the sacrum)
    2. Purandare's sling operation (To the Rectus Sheath)
    3. Khanna's sling operation (To the Anterior superior Iliac spine)
  • In Purandare's sling operation, two fascial strips are prepared using a rectus sheath. Then they are passed through the internal inguinal ring and brought to the posterior aspect of the cervix extraperitonially, forming a sling. This sling will pull the uteri upward when the abdominal and rectal muscles contract.

 

Option A: Le Fort's operation

  • This surgery is done in very old and weak patients because of its reduced operating time.
  • In this surgery, a septum is created in the vagina by suturing its anterior and posterior walls with each other. It is advisable only in old patients, unfit for a major surgery, not requiring sexual or childbearing function.

Option B: Thiersch operation

  • It is not a surgery for uterine prolapse

Option D: Manchester

  • It is a vaginal procedure done for uterine prolapse for the preservation of the uterus. In this, the cervix is amputated, and bilateral transverse ligaments are plicated in front of the amputated cervix, followed by anterior and posterior colporrhaphy.
  • Manchester is associated with pregnancy complications related to cervical incompetence, so it is not the procedure of choice in women desiring future childbearing.

questions.text: A radiologist performing an obstetric ultrasound visualizes the placenta and calls it Grade III. Placental grading on ultrasound is based on following criteria:-
questions.solution:
Option D : Placental grading (Grannum classification)refers to an ultrasound grading system of the placenta based on its maturity. It primarily affects the extent of calcifications.

Factors evaluated include placental calcium deposits and chorionic plate undulations.

GRADE FEATURES
Grade 0

<18 weeks

uniform echogenicity

smooth chorionic plate
Grade I

18-29 weeks

Scattered echogenicities and subtle chorionic plate undulations
Grade II

30-38 weeks

Echogenic stippling at the basal plate
Grade III

≥ 39 weeks

Echogenic indentations extending from the chorionic plate to the basal plate which resemble cotyledons.

 

Option A : Placental location is described as fundal, low lying or previa.

Option B : Placental dimension is not routinely measured, may measured in some cases of placentomegaly (width > 4cm).

Option C : Amniotic fluid is measured as amniotic fluid index.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, who achieved pregnancy through in vitro fertilization (IVF), undergoes a bedside transvaginal ultrasound at 7 weeks gestation. The ultrasound reveals the presence of twins at 7 weeks with two normal heartbeats. What is the most likely type of twin pregnancy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D : Most common twins after assisted reproduction are dizygotic twins. For increasing the success of IVF and the expenses involved, it’s a norm to transfer 2-3 embryos of day 3 or 1-2 embryos of Day 5. For women lesser than 35 years, the implantation rate is better and hence these are the ones who have more multiple pregnancies. Please note that dizygotic twins are always diamniotic and dichorionic.

 

In the given USG image, twin peak/lambda sign is seen which is characteristic of DCDA placenta

 

Option A, B, C : In monozygotic twins, chorionicity depends upon time of cell division. Monozygotic twins are rarely seen in IVF pregnancies.

Time of cell division Chorionicity of placenta
First 72 hours post fertilization(morula stage) DCDA
4-8th day(blastocyst stage) MCDA(MC type of monozygotic twins)
8-12th day MCMA
>12th day Conjoined/Siamese twins, type of MCMA (Formation of embryonic plate occurs)

questions.text: A 30-year-old female G2P1L1 presents to the gynecologist with complaints of the passage of some products of conception followed by heavy bleeding 2 hours ago. She is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. A diagnosis of incomplete abortion is made, and the doctor performs an evacuation. He, however, doubts it is a molar pregnancy and thus sends it for histopathology. The point of distinction between a complete mole and a partial mole is?

choices.text: Partial mole shows trophoblastic proliferation with absent villi
Typical of partial mole is diffuse cellular atypia
Partial mole is more prone to tumor malignancy

questions.solution:
Option D: Partial mole is triploid

  • Partial mole is triploid with karyotype 69 XXX (most commonly) or XXY.
  • Partial mole results from fertilization of a haploid ovum by 2 sperms, both carrying X chromosome mostly; hence the resulting embryo is triploid ( 69, XXX most common, or 69, XXY).
  • Fetal tissue is present in a partial mole along with partial swelling of chorionic villi and focal hyperplasia of trophoblastic tissue.

Option A: Partial mole shows trophoblastic proliferation with absent villi

  • Choriocarcinoma is a malignant tumour of the trophoblast.
  • A characteristic feature is the identification of intimately related syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts without the formation of definite placental-type villi.
  • Since choriocarcinomas include syncytiotrophoblasts, they cause elevated blood levels of beta-human chorionic gonadotropin.

Option B: Typical of the partial mole is diffuse cellular atypia

  • Focal hyperplasia of trophoblastic tissue is seen in a partial mole.
  • The diffuse cellular atypia is seen in a complete mole.​​​​​​​

Option C: Partial mole is more prone to tumour malignancy

  • A complete mole is more prone to tumour malignancy than a partial mole.
  • A complete mole has a higher chance of transformation to choriocarcinoma than a partial mole.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic at 33 weeks of gestation for a routine checkup. Her BP is 170/100 mmHg. Her lipid profile and cardiac evaluation are normal. She never had raised BP in the past and has no family history of hypertension. Her urinalysis shows WBC 0-1/ HPF, albumin 2+, no glucosuria, and no pus cells. Which of the following is an expected renal change in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Glomeruloendotheliosis

  • This patient presenting with high BP and proteinuria at 33 weeks of gestation most likely suffers from preeclampsia.
  • The characteristic renal lesion in preeclampsia is glomeruloendotheliosis.
  • It leads to scarring of glomeruli, decreasing the glomerular filtration rate.

Option A: Increased Glomerular filtration rate

  • Glomerular filtration rate decreases, not increases, in preeclampsia due to glomerular scarring.

Option C: Increased renal blood flow

  • Renal perfusion is decreased in preeclampsia due to glomerular endotheliosis.

Option D: Persistent proteinuria after delivery

  • Proteinuria due to preeclampsia resolves on the termination of pregnancy. It does not persist after delivery.

questions.text: A primigravida is seen at 26 weeks, and an OGTT is advised. Her values are deranged, and she is started on a diabetic diet. She has no past or family history of diabetes. Which of the following is the best explanation for such a presentation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Exponential increase in HPL (human placental lactogen)

Human Placental Lactogen

  • HPL is secreted by syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta and is detectable in maternal serum as early as third week after fertilization. It is demonstrable in cytotrophoblast before 6 weeks.
  • This, however, increases exponentially around 24 weeks and is responsible for the insulinase action and the predisposition to GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus) around that time, hence the screening protocol of OGTT (Oral glucose tolerance test) at that time.
  • Induces maternal lipolysis
  • Has angiogenic properties, therefore, is responsible for the development of fetal vasculature.
  • Deranged OGTT is suggestive of gestational diabetes. Pathogenesis is believed to be a diabetogenic effect of pregnancy by an increase in hormones, namely
    • Human placental lactogen
    • Cortisol
    • Placental insulinase
    • Cortisol
    • Estrogen and progesterone

Option B: Activation of diabetogenic genes

  • Activation of the diabetogenic gene is not the primary mechanism for gestational diabetes mellitus.
  • The human placental lactogen is responsible for the insulinase action and the predisposition to GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus)

Option C: Fetal insulinase

  • Fetal insulinase is not the primary mechanism for gestational diabetes mellitus.
  • The human placental lactogen is responsible for insulinase action and the predisposition to GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus).

Option D: Downregulation of glucagon

  • Downregulation of glucagon is not the primary mechanism of gestational diabetes mellitus.
  • The human placental lactogen is responsible for insulinase action and the predisposition to GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus).

questions.text: The gestational form of diabetes in pregnancy usually occurs late compared with overt diabetes. This is the body's change in metabolism due to altering hormonal levels during pregnancy. All are consistent with diabetogenic effects of pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Option B: Decrease lipolysis

  • Pregnancy has various diabetogenic effects:
    • Insulin resistance (By production of human placental lactogen, cortisol, estriol, progesterone and placental insulinase).
    • Increased lipolysis (Mother uses fat for her caloric needs and saves glucose for fetal needs).
    • Changes in gluconeogenesis.

Option A: Insulin resistance

  • Human placental lactogen, cortisol, estriol, progesterone and placental insulinase exert a diabetogenic effect by  causing insulin resistance. 

Option C: Changes in gluconeogenesis

  • Cortisol and progesterone increase gluconeogenesis to increase the blood sugar level and maintain a diabetogenic state.

Option D: Placental insulinase

  • Placental insulinase cause degradation of insulin. Thereby creating an insulin deficiency and producing a diabetogenic effect.

Option E: Production of human placental lactogen

  • Human placental lactogen is the primary hormone that asserts a diabetogenic effect mediated by increased fatty acid levels.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0,   comes to the clinic at 32 weeks of gestation for a routine prenatal visit. She has felt normal fetal movements and has no abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, or fluid leakage. Physical examination is normal, and fundal height is appropriate for gestational age and her obstetrician examines the fetal head diameters abdominally. Which of the following is the shortest diameter of the fetal head?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bimastoid diameter

  • Bimastoid diameter is the diameter extending between the tips of the mastoid processes on the fetal skull. It measures 7.5 cm.

IMPORTANT FETAL SKULL PARAMETERS

  • Suboccpitobrematic 9.5 cm
  • Submentobregmatic 9.5 cm
  • Biparietaldiameter 9.5 cm
  • Mentovertical 13.5 to 14 cm
  • Submentovertical 10 cm
  • Bitemporal diameter 8.5 cm
  • Bimastoid: 7.5 cm

Option A: Biparietal diameter

  • It is the largest transverse diameter that extends between the parietal bones, and it is 9.5 cm

Option C: Occipitofrontal diameter

  • It is an Anteroposterior diameter extending from occipital protuberance to the glabella. It is also the presenting diameter of the fetal head when the head is deflexed, and it is 11.5 cm.

Option D: Bitemporal Diameter

  • It is the shortest transverse diameter extending between the temporal bones, and it is 8 cm.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presents at the 37th week of gestation with complaints of low-grade fever followed by vesicular rashes on the body. Her previous vaccination status is unknown. Multinucleated giant cells are seen in microscopy of the vesicle. PCR confirms varicella-zoster virus. Which of the following is true regarding varicella-zoster virus in pregnancy?

choices.text: No intervention for exposed seronegative mother
Immunoglobulins to be given to a neonate when the mother has varicella 5 days before delivery.

questions.solution:
Option D: immunoglobulins to be given to a neonate when the mother has varicella 5 days before delivery.

  • Varicella zoster virus, or human herpes virus-3, is a double-stranded DNA virus. It spreads via respiratory secretions and contact with the vesicular fluid.
  • It can cause varicella-zoster (chickenpox, shingles), encephalitis and pneumonia. The most common complication is postherpetic neuralgia.
  • The virus remains latent in the dorsal root ganglion of the trigeminal nerve and can cause herpes zoster ophthalmicus.
  • Pregnant women should be asked if they had chicken pox at the initial booking visit. If they do not have chicken pox, they should avoid contact with it during pregnancy, and if exposure does occur, they need to inform the doctor as soon as possible.
  • When contact occurs, a careful history must be about the time duration of exposure, the closeness of contact, and the patient's susceptibility. Significant contact can be in the same room for 15 minutes or more or face-to-face. Individuals with the virus are infectious 48 hours before the appearance of the rash and until the vesicles crust over.
  • If the woman reports contact with chickenpox, blood testing should be done to check for immunity by testing for VZV IgG.
  • If the immunity is not confirmed and there has been a significant exposure, a woman should be given VZIG (varicella-zoster immunoglobulin) as soon as possible. It is effective up to 10 days after exposure and may prevent or attenuate the disease. Women are advised to report to the doctor if the rash develops.
  • Women with chickenpox should avoid contact with other pregnant women and neonates until the lesions have crusted. The current recommendation states that 800mg acyclovir 5 times a day for 7 days should be given if they present within 24 hours of presentation of rash and are more than 20 weeks of gestation. Acyclovir is also given before 20 weeks of gestation. VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once the rash has developed.
  • Delivery during the infection is very dangerous to the mother and includes the risk of thrombocytopenia, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and hepatitis.
  • Congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by limb hypoplasia, cutaneous dermatomal scarring, eye defects (microphthalmia, chorioretinitis, and cataracts), and neurologic abnormalities (microcephaly, cortical atrophy, mental retardation, dysfunction of bowel and bladder sphincters). The risk of congenital malformations increases when the infection occurs in the 12th-20th weeks of gestation.
  • Elective delivery should be avoided until 5-7 days after the onset of maternal rash to allow for Passover transfer of maternal antibodies to the developing fetus.
  • Immunoglobulins can be given to neonates when the mother has varicella 5-7 days before or 2-7 days after delivery as it can lead to disseminated disease in the newborn, varicella syndrome. The infant should be monitored for 28 days after the onset of maternal infection.
  • The varicella vaccine should not be given in pregnancy as it can cause congenital varicella syndrome in the developing fetus.
  • If the mother has shingles, the baby is protected from infection with varicella zoster virus by maternal antibodies, and no contact precaution is required.

Option A: Minimal risk of congenital malformation as the first trimester is over.

  • The risk of congenital malformations with a varicella infection is more in the 12th-20th weeks of gestation.

Option B: Acyclovir is unsafe in pregnancy.

  • Acyclovir is safe to use in pregnancy.
  • It is the preferred treatment against chickenpox in pregnant women.

Option C: Varicella vaccine can be given.

  • The varicella-zoster vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy as it can cause fetal varicella syndrome.

questions.text: A primigravida at 10 weeks presents with fatigue, abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and fruity odour in her breath. A diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis is made. A history suggestive of which of the following must be elicited as a cause of her ketoacidosis?
questions.solution:
Option B : Diabetic ketoacidosis in a pregnant diabetic patient may occur as a result of Hyperemesis gravidarum. Other causes include

  • Use of sympathomimetic drugs for tocolysis
  • Infections
  • Use of corticosteroids to induce fetal lung maturation.
  • Non compliance with Insulin Therapy

Option A : Since patient is in her first trimester and there is no history suggestive of infection in the question, hyperemesis would be the answer of choice here.

Option C : Not taking flic acid does not cause diabetic ketoacidosis.

Option D : Pancreatitis causing Ketoacidosis ( Called ‘Kabadi’ Syndrome ) is seen in 15 % cases of Acute Pancreatitis… not the likely cause here as that presents with acute pain abdomen.

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-month-old boy for a regular check-up. She worries whether her baby's growth might be inadequate. His physical examination is unremarkable, weighing 6.4kg, and his length is 64cm. The boy was born at term gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery, and his birth weight was 3.8 kg. Postnatally, in which year of life is the maximum growth?

choices.text: In the first year of life
In the second year of life
In the seventh year of life

questions.solution:
Option A:  In the first year of life

  • The first few years following birth are when children grow the fastest.
  • During infancy, growth happens even more quickly than it does during puberty.
  • The average baby is twice as long and three times as heavy at the end of the first year.
  • Postnatally there are two periods of accelerated growth:
    • The first year of life
    • Growth spurt during puberty (1st year of life > puberty)

Option B:  In the second year of life

  • Growth slows considerably in the second year of life.
  • Appetite also decreases
  • The child may acquire 5 pounds (2.27 kg) and gain 4 to 5 inches in height (10 to 12 cm).

Option C: In the seventh year of life

  • Growth is not the fastest in the 7th year of life.

Option D:  In adolescence

  • Growth is rapid when there is a growth spurt during adolescence, but this growth is relatively slower than in the first year of life.
  • 1st year of life > puberty

questions.text: While a group of children was rehearsing for a play at an annual function, they were asked to stand in two rows, boys and girls, respectively, and tell their names. These children could do so, but they could not count the 10 coins given to them and could not reliably catch a ball. What could be the age of these children?
questions.solution:
Option B: 3 years

  • As the scenario explains that the children were able to tell their names but were not able to count coins that were given to them. The children who reach 3 years of age can easily tell their names and their parents' names, too; they also know their gender.
  • A child knows her full name and gender by the age of 3 years.

Important social milestones:

  • 3 months

Recognizes mother
  • 6 months

Smiles at a mirror image ('Mirror play')
  • 7 months

Stranger anxiety
  • 8 months

Object permanence
  • 9 months

Waves bye-bye
  • 10 months

Plays peek-a-boo

Kisses on request
  • 12 months

He plays a simple ball game

Points to objects
  • 15 months

Indicates wet pants

Domestic mimicry
  • 18 months

Dry during the daytime (bladder control during the day)
  • 2 years
  • Parallel play
  • Joins in play
  • 3 years
  • Knows name, age & gender
  • Dry during the night

 

Option A: 1 year

  • At the first year of age, the baby is developing many skills, i.e. cruising, crawling, and pointing towards objects.
  • Babies at the age of 1 year sleep for about 14 hours in the daytime and 11 hours at night on average.

Option C: 5 years

  • A five-year-old child is a grown-up child.
  • They can speak very clearly.
  • I like to sing and dance.
  • Can stand on the foot for 10 seconds or more.

Option D: 7 years

  • A seven-year-old child strictly adheres to the rules.
  • Can run up and down stairs
  • Able to brush and comb hair.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman G3P2L2 presents to the hospital with complaints of vaginal bleeding for the last 2 hours. She is at 28 weeks of gestation. She delivered a preterm baby boy weighing 1200 grams, and the neonate was shifted to the NICU for further treatment. As the baby's lungs are not mature enough by this time, what would be the recommended dose of steroids given to the child to attain lung maturity?

choices.text: Injection Betamethasone 12 mg for two doses 12 hours apart
Injection Betamethasone 12 mg for two doses 24 hours apart
Injection Dexamethasone 6 mg for four doses 24 hours apart
Injection Dexamethasone 12 mg for two doses 12 hours apart

questions.solution:
Correct option A : Injection Betamethasone 12 mg for two doses 12 hours apart is the correct choice. The standard regimen for Betamethasone administration is two doses given 12 hours apart. Each dose consists of 12 mg of Betamethasone. This protocol has been found to be effective in promoting fetal lung maturation and reducing the risk of respiratory distress syndrome.

Incorrect option B
Option b. Injection Betamethasone 12 mg for two doses 24 hours apart is not the recommended regimen. The doses should be given 12 hours apart, not 24 hours apart, to ensure optimal lung maturity.

Option c. Injection Dexamethasone 6 mg for four doses 24 hours apart is not the correct choice. Dexamethasone is an alternative corticosteroid used in some cases, but the recommended regimen for Betamethasone is preferred over Dexamethasone in promoting lung maturity.

Option d. Injection Dexamethasone 12 mg for two doses 12 hours apart is not the recommended regimen in this scenario. Betamethasone is the preferred corticosteroid over Dexamethasone, and the correct dose for Betamethasone is 12 mg, not Dexamethasone.

In summary, in this case, the recommended dose of steroids to promote lung maturity in the preterm baby would be a. Injection Betamethasone 12 mg for two doses 12 hours apart. This helps reduce the risk of respiratory distress syndrome and other complications associated with premature birth.

questions.text: A neonate is born to a 32-year-old female at 34 weeks by eutocic delivery. The baby weighs 2.9 kg at birth. Vital signs are within normal limits. A physical exam of the baby after 12 hours of birth shows that the soles and palms are yellowish. Pressing the skin down with a finger increases the yellowing. What is the probable bilirubin level in this neonate?
questions.solution:
Option D: 18 mg/dl

  • In this case, yellow staining is present on palms & soles. According to the modified Kramer rule, it indicates a bilirubin level > 15 mg/dl. 
  • Modified Kramer rule: 

Jaundice: 

  • The yellow colouration of neonate skin is called infant jaundice. 
  • It happens because neonates’ blood contains an excess of bilirubin which is a yellow pigment of red blood cells. 
  • A baby born before 38 weeks has a liver which is not mature enough to get rid of bilirubin in the bloodstream and resulting in infant jaundice. 
  • A very high blood level of bilirubin can be a risk factor for brain damage in newborns.

 

Option A: 6mg/dl 

  • According to the modified Kramer rule, if the face of neonates shows yellow colouration, it is an indication of a bilirubin level of 4-6 mg/dl. 
  • Normal bilirubin level in neonates before 24 hours of birth is <6 mg/ dl. 

 

Option B: 9 mg/dl 

  • According to the modified Kramer rule, if the upper abdominal area and chest of neonates show yellow colouration, it is an indication of a bilirubin level of > 6 mg/dl. 
  • Normal bilirubin level in neonates after 24-48 hours of birth is <10 mg/ dl. 

Option C: 12 mg/dl 

  • According to the modified Kramer rule, if the arms and legs of neonates show yellow colouration, it is an indication of a bilirubin level of 12-14 mg/dl. 
  • Normal bilirubin level in neonates after 3-5 of birth is <12mg/ dl.

questions.text: A 1-week-old baby girl is brought to the emergency room by her father due to yellowish discoloration of the skin and generalized swelling of the body. The symptoms started two days ago and progressed gradually. On further examination, there is evidence of hepatomegaly on USG. Labs reveal elevated unconjugated bilirubin and low RBC count. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Erythroblastosis fetalis

  • In this case, a 1-week-old female neonate presents to the emergency with pale colour, yellowing of the whites of the eyes, and swelling all over the body from the past 2 days. Ultrasound of the neonate shows an enlarged liver, and the patient's blood test shows raised serum bilirubin and low RBCs. The scenario indicates erythroblastosis fetalis due to Rh incompatibility.
  • Rh incompatibility occurs when a female with Rh-negative factor becomes pregnant with an Rh-positive baby. This incompatibility can lead to serious implications. The mother's immune system reacts and produces Rh antibodies. These antibodies then attack the immune system of the baby, destroying RBCs.
