  • The destruction of RBCs causes a decrease in the red blood cells, and erythroblastosis fetalis or haemolytic anaemia occurs. In this condition, the bilirubin of the neonate increases, causing jaundice. It can be life-threatening if not treated. It can be of 2 types.
  • Mild cases in which mild anaemia and jaundice(Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia) are present, while in severe cases, there is increased serum bilirubin (unconjugated), raised stool stercobilin and urine urobilinogen. It leads to CNS damage (Kernicterus) and death. The injection of anti-D gammaglobulin given to the mother right after the delivery of each Rh-positive infant has been a successful strategy for reducing Rh hemolytic disease.

Option B: Apnea of prematurity

  • Apnea is a disorder that is related to breathing defects in sleep. In this condition, the baby experiences a pause in breathing during sleep. The pause in breathing can last from 10 to 20 seconds.
  • Infants who are prematurely born or underweight are more likely to suffer from this condition. The cessation of oxygen can cause many complications, as oxygen is essential for the normal functionality of the brain. It can even cause the death of brain cells.

Option C: Benign rolandic epilepsy

  • It is the major type of childhood epilepsy with the most cases. The word benign is used in this condition because, in almost all cases, patients outgrow it in puberty.
  • They present with seizures in the part of the brain called the rolandic area. It mostly affects the face, causing symptoms like drooling, trouble speaking, and tingling.

Option D: Bacterial meningitis

  • Meningitis is an infection caused by bacteria or viruses. But bacterial meningitis is most common in newborn babies and children. In this disease, the layer that covers the brain and spinal cord become infected.
  • Bacterial meningitis in neonates is caused by E.coli, which is a group B streptococci. In infants and older children, it is caused by streptococcus pneumoniae

questions.text: CME is being conducted at a medical college, and all departments are supposed to present a seminar on topics related to maternal and neonatal care. The Department of Pediatrics presents a seminar on the benefits of breast milk. While giving the seminar, they have to inform them about the benefits of the higher lactose content of breast milk. Which of the following should they mention in the benefits?

choices.text: Helps in the deformation of galactocerebrosides
Helps in the absorption of vitamin A
Helps in decreasing the risk of infections
Helps in decreasing the growth of lactobacilli

questions.solution:
Option C: Helps in decreasing the risk of infections

  • Lactose is the main sugar in mammalian milk.
  • 40% of calories in milk are provided solely by lactose.
  • Lactose plays an important role in the following:
  • Promoting healthy gut bacteria lactobacilli
  • Insulin regulation
  • Growth of gut antimicrobial factors
  • Galactose helps in the formation of galactocerebrosides.
  • Lactose helps in the absorption of calcium.

 

  • Breast milk is known to stimulate and support the immune system. Such as, lactoferrin and interleukin 6, 8 and 10. 
  • These proteins help to balance the inflammatory response of the immune system
  • The risk of infections is decreased due to anti-infective substances like:
    • Phagocytic macrophages
    • PABA
    • Lactoferrin
    • Lysozyme
    • Antibodies especially IgA
    • Bifidus factor
    • Glycerol monolaurate (GML) present in breast milk is 200 times higher than in cow's milk, fights harmful bacteria such as Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus subtilis and Clostridium perfringens, and promotes the growth of beneficial bacteria. 

Option A: Helps in the deformation of galactocerebrosides

  • Galactocerebrosides are one of the simplest glycosphingolipids, consisting of a single galactose residue linked.
  • It is a major class of glycolipids in the nervous system.
  • Higher lactose content helps in the formation of galactocerebrosides.

Option B: Helps in the absorption of vitamin A

  • Lactose facilitates the intestinal transport of several minerals, such as 
    • calcium
    • iron 
    • zinc 
    • manganese 
    • cobalt magnesium
    • strontium

Option D: Helps in decreasing the growth of lactobacilli.

  • Lactobacilli are considered good bacteria and have a high potential to produce important metabolites.
  • Lactose helps in promoting healthy gut bacteria lactobacilli

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy arrives at the emergency department with a fever and two days of breathing difficulties. His vital signs include a blood pressure of 105/60 mmHg, a pulse of 102 per minute, a respiratory rate of 26 per minute, and a temperature of 102oF. An arterial blood gas analysis reveals respiratory acidosis. What's the likely cause of the acid-base disturbance in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Excess of carbonic acid

  • The patient has presented with a history of fever and acute shortness of breath. An infectious aetiology resulting in respiratory tract inflammation is most likely.
  • Respiratory acidosis is caused by CO2 retention leading to excess carbonic acid. (CO2 + H2O ---- H2CO3)
  • CO2 is a by-product of metabolism and is removed from the body by the lungs. Respiratory acidosis occurs when the alveolar ventilation falls or when carbon dioxide production is increased so that the arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) is elevated above the normal range (>45 mm Hg), leading to a blood pH lower than 7.35.
  • The common causes of respiratory acidosis are:
    • Central nervous system depression (encephalitis or narcotic
    • overdose)
    • Disorders of the spinal cord, peripheral nerves, or neuromuscular
    • junction (botulism or Guillain-Barré syndrome)
    • Respiratory muscle weakness (muscular dystrophy)
    • Pulmonary disease (pneumonia or asthma)
    • Upper airway disease (laryngospasm)

Option A: Deficit of carbonic acid

  • The acid-base disorder that results from a primary deficit of carbonic acid (washout of carbon dioxide) is respiratory alkalosis. Respiratory alkalosis results from the disorder causing hyperventilation.

Option C: Deficit of bicarbonate

  • Metabolic acidosis results from the deficit of bicarbonate. This is commonly seen in children who suffer from diarrhoea.

Option D: Excess of bicarbonate

  • An excess of bicarbonate results in metabolic alkalosis, not respiratory acidosis. As a compensatory mechanism, the pCO2 can rise.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child is admitted to a hospital for acute gastroenteritis. He had several episodes of diarrhea and vomiting. On examination, he has sunken eyes and dry oral mucosa. He is drowsy, and the skin pinch goes back very slowly. His current weight is 20 kg. He is now on fluid replenishment therapy. What is the daily maintenance fluid for this child?
questions.solution:
Option D: 1500 mL/day

  • The fluid requirement for this child, weighing 20 kg, is 1500 mL.
    • For first 10 kgs: 100ml/kg
    • For the next 10 kgs: 50ml/kg
    • For each kg above 20 kgs: 20 ml/kg
  • The Holliday - Segar 4-2-1 Rule to estimate maintenance hourly fluid (water) requirements

Weight (kg)

Hourly

Daily

<10 kg

4 mL/kg/hr

100 mL/kg/day

10-20 kg

40 mL + 2 mL/kg for every kg > 10 kg

1000 mL + 50 mL/kg/day for every kg > 100

>20 kg

600 mL + 1 mL/kg for every kg > 20 kg

1500 mL+20 mL/kg/day for every kg >200
  • So,
  • (1–10 kg) 100 x 10 = 1000 mL
  • (11–20 kg) 50 x 10 = 500 mL;
  • Total: 1000+500= 1500 mL

Option A: 1000 mL/day

  • 1000 mL per day is insufficient maintenance fluid for a child weighing 24 kg.
  • As calculated above, 1500 ml should be given to him as a maintenance fluid in 24 hours.

Option B: 800 mL/day

  • 800 mL per day is insufficient maintenance fluid for a child weighing 24 kg.
  • As calculated above, 1500 ml should be given to him as a maintenance fluid per day.

Option C: 1540 mL/day

  • As calculated above, 1500 ml should be given to him as a maintenance fluid in 1 day

questions.text:
A 3-year-old female child is brought to the clinic by her mother with the complaint of speech development problems; she states that her sister, who is also a doctor, has suggested that her baby might have a hearing problem which is leading to pathological speech development. The ENT doctor suggests BERA to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statement is correct about BERA?

1) Study of electric waves produced along the neural pathway of sound

2) It is an objective test

3) Screening test for neonatal deafness

4) Confirmatory test for neonatal deafness
questions.solution:
Option A: only 1, 2, and 4 are correct

  • The above statements given 1, 2, and 4 are correct about brainstem evoked response audiometry.
  • It is an objective test.
  • It is the study of electric waves produced along the neural pathway of sound.
  • It is a confirmatory test for neonatal deafness.
  • BERA (brainstem evoked response audiometry) or Auditory brainstem response (ABR). Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential), it elicits brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts.
  •  It is a non-invasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons, and midbrain.
  •  This method generates electrical potentials in response to several click stimuli or tone bursts and picked up. It measures hearing sensitivity in the range of 1000–4000 Hz.
  •  In a normal person, seven waves are produced in the first 10 ms. The first, third, and fifth waves are most stable. The waves are studied for absolute latency, interwave latency (usually between waves I and V) and amplitude.

Option B: Only 1, 2, and 3 are correct.

  • This option is wrong. It includes statement no.3, which says 'screening test for neonatal deafness' and is a wrong statement because it is a confirmatory test for neonatal deafness.

Option C: Only 1 and 2 are correct.

  • This option is wrong because it does not include statement 4, which is also correct about BERA.

Option D: Only 1 is correct.

  • This option is wrong because it does not include statements 2 and 4, which are also correct about BERA.

questions.text: An 8-year-girl was brought to the emergency department by her mother because of fever and pain in the left ear for 2 days. The mother says her daughter had three episodes of the same symptoms that resolved with antibiotics during the past year. The patient has a history of pulsatile ear discharge. She has no known medication allergies. What will be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: ASOM

  • The above given is a case of acute suppurative otitis media.
  • Acute earache and fever, and pulsatile ear discharge are suggestive.
  • Acute otitis media
    • Most commonly seen in children.
    • The most common cause is streptococcus pneumoniae.
    • The infection spreads to the ear through the eustachian tube.
  • Mucopurulent or purulent discharge, often pulsatile (light-house effect), may be seen coming through the central perforation of pars tensa is seen in acute otitis media.
  • Pulsatile otorrhoea: ASOM.
  • Pulsatile tinnitus: Glomus tumor.

Acute suppurative otitis media

  • It is an acute inflammation of the middle ear by pyogenic organisms. Here, the middle ear implies middle ear cleft, i.e., eustachian tube, middle ear, attic, aditus, antrum, and mastoid air cells.
  • Etiology: It is more common, especially in infants and children of the lower socioeconomic group. Typically, the disease follows viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, but soon the pyogenic organisms invade the middle ear.

Option A: CSF rhinorrhea

  • CSF leakage into the nose is called CSF rhinorrhoea.
  • It may be clear fluid or mixed with blood, as in acute head injuries.

Option C: CSOM

  • Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is a long-standing infection of the middle ear cleft characterized by ear discharge and permanent perforation.
  • A perforation becomes permanent when its squamous epithelium edges are covered by and do not heal spontaneously.
  • A permanent perforation can be lined to an epithelium-lined fistulous track.

Option D: Meniere’s disease

  • It is an inner ear disease that is caused by impaired endolymph resorption.

  • Etiologies include infection, allergies, and/or inner ear autoimmune.
  • It is characterized by peripheral vertigo, tinnitus, and sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Vertigo is of sudden onset and lasts for a few minutes to 24 hours.
  • Clinical features: Ear discharge. It is non-offensive, mucoid or mucopurulent, constant or intermittent. The discharge appears mostly at the time of upper respiratory tract infection or on accidental entry of water into the ear.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child has been brought to the pediatrician with nasal obstruction for the last 3 days. It is noted that the child is also bleeding from the same side of the nose. On examination, there is foul-smelling nasal discharge and a mass inside the nose. In which of the following conditions, foul-smelling discharge is not the key a finding?
questions.solution:
Option A: Choanal atresia

  • Choanal atresia does not cause foul-smelling discharge.
  • It is due to the persistence of the bucconasal membrane and may be unilateral or bilateral, complete or incomplete, bony (90%), or membranous (10%). Bilateral atresia presents with respiratory obstruction as the newborn, being a natural nose breather, does not breathe from the mouth.
  • Diagnosis of choanal atresia can be made by
    • Presence of mucoid discharge in the nose,
    • Absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge,
    • Failure to pass a catheter from nose to pharynx,
    • Putting a few drops of a dye (methylene blue) into the nose and seeing its passage into the pharynx, or
    • Flexible nasal endoscopy,
    • Installing radioopaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral film, and
    • Computed tomography (CT) scan in the axial plane is more useful.
  • Choanal Unilateral atresia is more common and may remain undiagnosed until adult life.
  • The presence of mucoid discharge in the nose and the absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge can be used to diagnose choanal atresia.

Option B: Nasal Myiasis

  • Maggots are larval forms of flies. They are seen to infest the nose, nasopharynx, and paranasal sinuses, causing extensive destruction.
  • Flies, particularly of the genus chrysomya, are attracted by the foul-smelling discharge emanating from cases of atrophic rhinitis, syphilis, leprosy, or infected wounds and lay eggs, about 200 at a time, which within 24 hr hatch into larvae. In India, they are mostly seen from August to October.

Option C: Foreign bodies

  • They are mostly seen in children and may be organic or inorganic. Pieces of paper, chalk, button, pebbles, and seeds are the common objects. Pledgets of cotton or swabs may be accidentally left in the nose.
  • The patient may present immediately if the history of a foreign body is known. If overlooked, the child presents with unilateral nasal discharge, which is often foul-smelling and occasionally bloodstained.

Option D: Rhinolith

  • It is stone formation in the nasal cavity. A rhinolith usually forms around the nucleus of a small exogenous foreign body, blood clot, or inspissated secretions by slow deposition of calcium and magnesium salts.
  • Over a while, it grows into a large, irregular mass that fills the nasal cavity and then may cause pressure necrosis of the septum and/or lateral wall of the nose.
  • Rhinoliths are more common in adults. Its common presentation is unilateral nasal obstruction and foul-smelling discharge, which is very often bloodstained. Frank epistaxis and neuralgic pain may result from ulceration of the surrounding mucosa.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic due to pain in her throat and upper neck for 2 weeks. The pain is sudden in onset, sharp radiates to the right ear, and gets aggravated on swallowing. The lateral skull x-ray of the patient is shown below:



What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Eagle syndrome

  • Eagle syndrome is due to an elongated (>3cm) styloid process or calcification of the stylohyoid ligament.
  • It is also called styalgia.
  • The patient usually complains of sharp nerve pain in the tonsillar fossa and upper neck, which radiates to the ipsilateral ear.
  • The pain aggravates with swallowing, jaw, and neck movement.
  • Other symptoms include difficulty swallowing, foreign object sensation in the throat, and ringing in the ears.
  • The vascular form of Eagle syndrome presents with a transient ischemic attack (TIA) or stroke due to impingement of the styloid process onto the internal carotid artery.
  • Compression of the internal jugular vein may lead to increased intracranial pressure sometimes.
  • Diagnosis can be made by transoral palpation of the styloid process in the tonsillar fossa and by an anteroposterior view radiograph with an open mouth or lateral view radiograph of the skull.
  • Treatment is by partial styloidectomy transoral or cervical approach.

Option B: Apert syndrome

It is an incorrect option because:

  • Apert syndrome, also known as type I acrocephalosyndactyly, is a syndrome that is predominantly characterized by skull and limb malformations.
  • Radiographic features of Apert syndrome include:
    • Craniofacial: Craniosynostosis(brachycephaly); facial hypoplasia
    • Limb: Syndactyly (tends to be complex)

Option C: Stickler syndrome

It is an incorrect option because:

  • Stickler syndrome (hereditary progressive arthro-ophthalmodystrophy) is a group of rare genetic disorders affecting connective tissue, specifically collagen.
  • Stickler syndrome is a subtype of collagenopathy, types II and XI.
  • It presents as prominent eyes, a small nose, and a receding chin giving a scooped-out appearance of the face.
  • No involvement of the styloid process is seen.

Option D: Usher syndrome

It is an incorrect option because:

  • Usher syndrome (USH) is the leading genetic cause of combined hearing and vision loss.
  • No involvement of the styloid process is seen.

questions.text: A 2-month child is brought to the hospital with noisy breathing since two weeks old. It gets worse when he is lying supine and gets relieved when the mother turns him to the prone position. The condition also aggravates on crying. Examination reveals inspiratory stridor. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. This increase in severity of inspiratory stridor in the supine position is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Option B: Laryngomalacia

  • Newborn develops intermittent, low-pitched inspiratory stridor within 1st 2 weeks of life ( presents at birth)
  • The severity of stridor increases on crying but reduces in the prone position as the epiglottis falls forward in the prone position and opens the airway.
  • Stridor usually starts resolving after 9 months and disappears by 2 years of age.
  • Cry itself as such is normal, but the stridor increases during the inspiratory phase while the child is crying.

Diagnosis of laryngomalacia is confirmed on direct laryngoscopy, which shows the following four important signs:

  • Elongated and large omega-shaped (Ω) epiglottis curled upon itself.
  • Floppy aryepiglottic folds.
  • Prominent arytenoids.
  • Excessive redundant tissue in the supraglottis.

Option A: Congenital subglottic stenosis

  • It presents with stridor. However, it is also associated with cyanotic episodes (blue spells)
  • An increase in stridor in the supine position and resolution in the prone position is typically associated with laryngomalacia.

Option C: Congenital subglottic hemangioma

  • Subglottic hemangiomas present with hoarseness, barking cough, and recurrent croup.

Option D: Laryngeal web

  • The laryngeal web is associated with a weak cry.
  • Increased stridor in the supine position and resolution in the prone position are typically associated with laryngomalacia.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the physician's office with a complaint of hoarseness of voice for the past six months. He is a chronic smoker and has a 50-pack-year history of smoking. On physical examination, neck lymph nodes are not palpable; however, laryngoscopy shows a large, infiltrating, fungating, soft papillary lesion. Two biopsies taken from the lesion proper show be­nign appearing papillomatosis with hyperkeratosis and acanthosis infiltrating the subjacent tissues. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Verrucous carcinoma

The squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor affecting the head and neck region (oropharynx, oral cavity, hypopharynx, larynx, and sinonasal tract). The head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) has many morphological variants.

Verrucous carcinoma:

  • Typically occurs in the oral cavity, rarely said to occur in the larynx, hypopharynx, sinonasal tract, and nasopharynx.
  • Verrucous carcinoma has a warty, exophytic lesion that arises from a broad base with a superficial spreading growth but can be deeply destructive by extending into the muscle, bone, and cartilage.
  • Slowly growing and locally aggressive well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, which does not metastasize.
  • Accounts for 1–2% of laryngeal carcinomas.
  • HPV 16 and 18 are associated with this lesion.
  • The larynx is the second most common site after the oral cavity
  • Presents as an exophytic and fungating carpet-like lesion that is hard to distinguish macroscopically from hyperkeratosis.
  • Significant inflammation surrounds the lesion & leads to enlarged inflammatory neck nodes.
  • Biopsy shows papillomatosis with hyperkeratosis and acanthosis infiltrating the subjacent tissues.
  • Biopsies are often repeated before adequate diagnosis. The diagnosis of VC is established by close communication between surgeons and pathologists.
  • Surgery is considered the treatment of choice.

Option A: Adenocarcinoma

  • Adenocarcinoma of the head and neck involves the salivary glands, not the laryngeal vocal cords.
  • Histology will show the presence of glanduloductal elements instead of hyperkeratosis and papillomatosis.

Option B: Sarcoma

  • Spindle cell carcinoma (sarcomatoid carcinoma) is a subtype of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.
  • It occurs mostly in the upper respiratory tract or less commonly in the oral cavity.
  • Patients are elderly males with previous radiation exposure.
  • Microscopically show polypoidal, exophytic configuration with either a broad base or narrow pedicle.
  • The tumor appears to be bi-phasic, with lesions showing areas of squamous cell carcinoma associated with bizarre spindle cell and/or giant cell proliferation of sarcomatoid appearance.

Option C: Adenosquamous carcinoma

  • Adenosquamous carcinoma is an uncommon variant of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Considered aggressive and associated with a poor prognosis.
  • Predominantly affects males in the sixth or seventh decade.
  • The larynx and hypopharynx is the most commonly affected site.
  • Macroscopically the tumor resembled squamous cell carcinoma; however, microscopically, it is characterized by the presence of squamous cell carcinoma admixed with a variable proportion of glanduloductal elements.
  • Histochemistry of mucin and keratin is seen.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to the hospital with a tender swelling at the angle of the jaw for 3 days. On examination, there is restricted jaw mobility and medial displacement of the affected tonsil. No membranous covering or discharging sinus is seen around the tonsils. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the given clinical condition?

choices.text: It is a case of parapharyngeal abscess
The female gender is predictive of high-risk cases
IV antibiotics are necessary for the treatment
An intraoral incision is given for incision and drainage

questions.solution:
Option D: Intraoral incision is given for incision and drainage

  • This patient, with fever, trismus, a history of tooth extraction at a local dental camp, medial displacement of the tonsils, and swelling at the angle of the jaw, most likely has a parapharyngeal abscess.
  • IV antibiotics are necessary to combat the infection, and drainage of the infection is done by giving an incision at 2 fingers below the angle of the jaw; hence, statement D is incorrect.

Option A: It is a case of parapharyngeal abscess

  • It is a case of parapharyngeal abscess, an infection involving the parapharyngeal space, the smallest space of the pharynx divided into anterior and posterior compartments via the styloid process

Option B: Female gender is predictive of high-risk cases

  • Predictors of high-risk cases in parapharyngeal abscess are:
  • Marked neck swelling
  • Female gender
  • Airway compromise

Option C: IV antibiotics are necessary for the treatment

  • In cases of parapharyngeal abscess, IV antibiotics are necessary to combat the infection and drainage by giving an incision at 2 fingers below the angle of the jaw.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and nasal discharge. He had a history of rhinosinusitis two weeks ago. An anterior rhinoscopy revealed a large shiny mass protruding from the anterior nares. Posterior rhinoscopy showed the same mass protruding from the posterior choanae. The child was diagnosed with an antrochoanal polyp. What is the current treatment of choice for a large antrochoanal polyp in this 10-year-old child?
questions.solution:
Option C: FESS

  • FESS stands for Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery.
    • FESS is the surgery of choice for both ethmoidal & antrochoanal polyps currently.
    • It is done through various endoscopes of 0, 30, and 70 degrees angulation.
    • Various steps of FESS are shown in the diagram below.
    • This procedure has superseded other techniques like intranasal polypectomy, Caldwell-Luc, ethmoidectomy, and lateral rhinotomy and excision.
  • This child is diagnosed with an antrochoanal polyp, which presents as a single, large and unilateral mass that originates from the maxillary sinus antrum and grows posteriorly towards the choanae.
    • It most commonly occurs in children with a sinus infection, as in this patient with a history of rhinosinusitis two weeks ago.

Option A: Intranasal polypectomy

  • Intranasal polypectomy was used to remove one or two pedunculated polyps with the help of a snare. Multiple and sessile polyps required special forceps.
  • Intranasal polypectomy is no longer preferred these days with the advent of FESS.

Option B: Caldwell Luc

  • This procedure was used for the removal of recurrent antrochoanal polyps.
  • Caldwell Luc/radical antrostomy is a surgery to remove irreversibly damaged maxillary sinus mucosa.
  • Ever since the advent of FESS, the indications for the Caldwell-Luc procedure have decreased.

Option D: Lateral rhinotomy & excision

  • Lateral rhinotomy is used to explore difficult sinonasal masses with extensive spread. It is an external approach.

questions.text: The lens of the human eye in Latin is called aquula, which means a little stream of aqua/water or crystalline lens. Which of the following is a true statement regarding the eye's lens?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above
Lens:

  • The lens is a transparent, biconvex structure of crystalline appearance placed between the iris and the vitreous.
  • It is suspended by the suspensory ligament of the lens or zonule of Zinn, which is attached to the ciliary body and equator of the lens.
  • The accommodative power varies with age, being 14 to 16 D (at birth), 7 to 8 D (at 25 years of age) and 1 to 2 D (at 50 years).
  • Structure
    i. Lenticular capsule is a smooth, homogeneous, acellular envelope. The hyaline lens capsule is secreted by the underlying epithelial cells.
    ii. Lenticular epithelium is a single layer of cuboidal cells deep     into the anterior capsule. There is no corresponding posterior epithelium.
    iii. Lenticular fibres: The anterior cuboidal cells gradually become columnar and elongated (lens fibres) towards the equator. Anterior and posterior Y-shaped suture lines are formed at the junction of lens fibres.
    iv. Suspensory ligament or Zonule of Zinn: This consists of transparent, straight and inextensible fibres.
  • Parts of lens:
    i. Lens capsule: A thin, transparent membrane thicker anteriorly. It is thinnest at the posterior pole measuring 4 µm (pre-equator region = 14 µm).
    ii. Cortex: lies between the lens capsule and the nucleus. It consists of lens fibres.
    iii. Nucleus: The lens has four nuclei which are formed at different stages of life up to late adolescence, namely the embryonic nucleus (1-3 months of gestation), fetal nucleus (from 3 months of gestation till birth), infantile nucleus (from birth to puberty) and adult nucleus (early adult life).    ​​​​​​​

Option A: Ectodermal in origin

  • The lens is ectodermal in origin.

Option B: Avascular

  • The lens is avascular.
  • It gets nourishment from the aqueous humour.

Option C: Epithelium is a single layer

  • The epithelium of the lens is single layered
  • The anterior lens surface is lined by a single cell layer of cuboidal-shaped epithelial cells.

questions.text: The neural crest is a highly migratory multipotent cell population that forms at the interface between the neuroepithelium and the prospective epidermis of a developing embryo. They result in the formation of various structures within the eye. Which of the following is a neuroectodermal derivative?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Sphincter pupillae:

  • The sphincter pupillae is a structure within the eye that is derived from the neuroectoderm. It is one of the muscles of the iris responsible for constriction of the pupil in response to light stimulation. The neuroectoderm gives rise to various structures in the central nervous system, including the retina and certain components of the iris.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lens: Derived from the surface ectoderm.

Option B - Lacrimal gland: Derived from the ectoderm of the head.

Options C - Corneal epithelium: Derived from the surface ectoderm.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of bilateral prominence and bulging of the eyes for 2 weeks. He is a known case of hypothyroidism. He is otherwise vitally stable. On examination, there is bilateral exophthalmos and proptosis with marked chemosis but without any diplopia. The MRI of the eyes of the patient is done, which is shown in the image below, which reveals the Coca-cola bottle sign. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Thyroid ophthalmopathy

  • This is a case of thyroid ophthalmopathy in which the patient presents with complaints of bilateral prominence and bulging of eyes for 2 weeks.
  • The Coca-cola bottle sign refers to the appearance of the muscles of the orbit in thyroid eye disease.
  • The belly of the muscle enlarges with the sparing of the tendinous insertion, giving the appearance of the traditional Coca-cola bottle.
  • The nature of the enlargement is important as it is one of the chief findings to differentiate it from orbital pseudotumor, in which the tendinous insertion is also involved and enlarged, unlike in thyroid eye disease.

Option A: Blowout fracture

  • The blowout fracture is the fracture of the bones of the orbit.
  • It usually results due to trauma of the eyes.
  • Road traffic accidents are the leading cause of trauma to the orbital bones resulting in blowout fractures.

Option B: Glioma

  • A glioma is a tumour of the brain and spinal cord.
  • It is usually a benign tumour.
  • It is the tumour of the glial cells which surrounds the nerve cells.

Option C: Sphenoid wing meningioma

  • Hyperostosis seen in case of sphenoid wing meningioma on CT scan

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A cataract is an opacity in the clear lens that leads to blurry vision. The most common type of cataract is senile cataract. Cataracts, however, are also formed in certain metabolic and congenital disorders. Which of the following leads to a rosette-shaped cataract?
questions.solution:
Option B: Blunt trauma

  • A rosette cataract is traumatic in origin.
  • Blunt trauma to the eyeball results in a rosette or stellate-shaped cataract.

Option A: Galactosemia

  • Galactosemia causes a particular type of cataract called oil droplet cataract.
  • Retinoscopy shows a classic oil droplet against the red reflex.

Option C: Corticosteroids

  • Long-term steroid use is associated with cataract formation.
  • Steroids commonly cause a posterior subcapsular cataract.
  • Steroids lead to hyperglycemia which increases the risk of lens opacification.

Option D: Atopic dermatitis

  • It leads to an anterior subcapsular opacity.
  • The opacity is shield-shaped.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 22-year-old obese man presented with the features of anterior uveitis in the left eye after a penetrating injury to his left eye, for which oral and topical steroids were prescribed. He developed sympathetic ophthalmitis (SO) signs in his right eye after a certain period. On general examination, the patient had a pulse rate of 78/min, blood pressure of 114/68 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 16/min, and was afebrile. Which of the following is the feature of sympathetic ophthalmitis?

choices.text: Accommodation failure in the good eye.
Presents between 2 days- 2 weeks after injury.
Retrolental flare is the late sign.
Dalen Fuchs nodules are seen on the choroid.

questions.solution:
Correct Options D - Dalen Fuchs nodules are seen on the choroid: Sympathetic ophthalmitis (SO) is a rare, severe, bilateral granulomatous uveitis that occurs after penetrating ocular injury. The inflammatory process can spread to the uninjured eye. Dalen Fuchs nodules are small, yellow-white lesions that can be found in the choroid and are a characteristic feature of sympathetic ophthalmitis. These nodules are composed of epithelioid cells and lymphocytes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Accommodation failure in the good eye: Accommodation failure is not a specific feature of sympathetic ophthalmitis. Accommodation refers to the eye's ability to change its focus from distant to near objects, controlled by the ciliary muscle.

Option B - Presents between 2 days- 2 weeks after injury: Sympathetic ophthalmitis usually occurs weeks to months after the injury to the fellow eye, not within 2 days to 2 weeks.

Option C - Retrolental flare is the late sign: Retrolental flare is not a characteristic sign of sympathetic ophthalmitis. It might be a feature of other eye conditions, but it is not specific to SO.

questions.text: The human eye is a specialized sense organ capable of receiving visual images, which are then carried to the brain. Intraocular pressure (IOP) is the pressure in your eyes. When that pressure is higher than normal, it causes ocular hypertension. While ocular hypertension isn't an eye disease in itself, it is an indication that you could develop glaucoma. Your eye pressure is measured in millimetres of mercury, expressed as mm Hg. The Ophthalmic investigation shown in the image below is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Tonometry

  • The image given in the question of applanation tonometry. In applanation tonometry, the cornea is flattened, and the IOP is determined by varying the applanating force or the area flattened.

  • The intraocular pressure (IOP) of the eye is determined by the balance between the amount of aqueous humor that the eye makes and the ease with which it leaves the eye.

Option A: Pachymetry

  • Pachymetry is a simple, painless test that quickly measures the thickness of the cornea.

Option C: Biometry

  • Biometry is used to calculate the refractive power of the cornea and the intraocular lens. It also measures the axial length of the eye.

Option D: LASER interferometry

  • Laser interferometry can be used to determine the diameter of fibres with a circular cross-section. The fibre is placed in the beam and the interference fringes projected onto a screen.

questions.text: A patient presented with the symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation and diminution of vision. A band-shaped white horizontal opacity can be seen in his eyes. Identify the eye disorder.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Band-shaped keratopathy:

  • Band Shaped Keratopathy is a slowly progressive degenerative condition that involves the deposition of calcium at the level of Bowman's membrane, typically in the interpalpebral zone beginning as a grey-white opacity nasally and temporally progressing centrally in a band-shaped pattern.
  • Appearance is called the Swiss Cheese Pattern due to minute small clear spaces between the opacities at points where the corneal nerves penetrate the Bowman's layer.
  • There also remains a clear zone between the limbus and the corneal opacity.
  • Patients remain asymptomatic initially, which can progress as the deposits cross the visual axis and affect visual acuity.
  • Erosion of the lesion may lead to painful recurrent corneal erosions.
  • Causes of Band Shaped Keratopathy:
    • Chronic ocular diseases
    • Chronic uveitis
    • Interstitial keratitis.
  • Management of Band Shaped Keratopathy
    • Management of the underlying cause by identification and appropriate systemic treatment.
    • Lubricant eye drops and ointments to smoothen the surface and may also improve the visual complaints.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Filamentary keratitis:

  • The open area of epithelium acts as a nidus for the deposition of mucous and debris which can cause significant discomfort.
  • Filamentary keratitis is a condition in which strands (“filaments”) composed of degenerated epithelial cells and mucus develop on and adhere to the corneal surface, causing pain and foreign body sensation.
  • Proposed treatments include non-preserved lubricants, topical steroidal and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents, punctal plugs for aqueous-deficient dry eye, mechanical removal of filaments, hypertonic saline, mucolytic agents, and bandage contact lenses for the filaments.
  • They stain best with rose bengal dye and less well with fluorescein. Filamentary keratitis can be a functionally debilitating and sight-threatening complication of several systemic and ocular conditions, most commonly the aqueous-deficient dry eye conditions, also known as keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS).

Option C - Pannus:

  • Area of superficial corneal neovascularization with associated degenerative sub-epithelial changes.
  • Pannus is a membrane of granulation tissue composed of mesenchyme- and bone marrow-derived cells. Formation of the pannus stimulates the release of IL-1, platelet-derived growth factor, prostaglandins, and substance P by macrophages, which ultimately cause cartilage destruction and bone erosion.
  • The corneal pannus is subepithelial fibrovascular tissue ingrowth from the limbus onto the cornea. It typically results from inflammation, which may be caused by many events, such as infection or chronic irritation.
  • Pannus is an extensive ingrowth of tissue from the limbus onto the peripheral cornea. The penetration occurs between the epithelium and anterior limiting lamina, resulting in separation of these layers and often destroying the anterior limiting lamina.

Option D - Wesseley's ring:

  • Immune ring of deep stromal haze indicating deposition of viral antigens and host antigen complexes in patients with Viral Keratitis (e.g. Disciform Keratitis).
  • Wesseley's rings are sterile, corneal intrastromal reactions resulting from an immune response to foreign antigens. They can be found in various corneal infections and non-infectious processes.
  • Diagnosis of the infection is made based on symptoms, growth of the Acanthamoeba amoeba from a scraping of the eye, and seeing the amoeba by a process called confocal microscopy.
  • Infiltrates can be caused by either an infectious or non-infectious (sterile) condition associated with contact lens wear, bacterial toxins, post-surgical trauma, autoimmune disease and other toxic stimuli.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old female presents to the clinic with the complaint of foreign body sensation in the eye for the past few weeks. She wears contact lenses. The examination shows the following findings.This condition occurs due to :



Which of the following is true about the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Soft contact lens use

  • Severe Papillary conjunctivitis on the superior tarsal conjunctiva is called giant papillary conjunctivitis. This patient has GPC due to soft contact lens use.

Option A: Allergic response to mycobacterial protein

  • An allergic response to staphylococcal antigen mostly causes GPC.

Option C: Intacs use

  • The GPC most occur with soft contact lens wearing.

  • Intacs are used in case of keratoconus.

Option D: Using the rigid gas permeable lens

  • Rigid gas permeable lenses do not cause GPC.

  • Rigid gas-permeable lenses are the most common lens type fitted postkeratoplasty as the curves can be manipulated to give adequate fit and acuity.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with bullae formation over the trunk and buccal mucosa. On examination, bullae are flaccid and slight rubbing of the skin results in exfoliation of the outermost layer. Biopsy of skin lesion shows acanthocytes and row of tombstone appearance. Which of the following is the most common variant of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pemphigus Vulgaris

  • This patient is diagnosed with pemphigus which is a blistering skin disorder.
  • Pemphigus Vulgaris is the most common variant of pemphigus.
  • Pemphigus is a group of life-threatening blistering disorders characterized by acantholysis (loss of keratinocyte to keratinocyte adhesion) that results in the formation of intraepithelial blisters in mucous membranes and skin.
  • The process of acantholysis is induced by the binding of circulating immunoglobulin G (IgG) autoantibodies to intercellular adhesion molecules.
  • Patients with pemphigus develop mucosal erosions and flaccid bullae, erosions, or pustules on the skin.
  • The four major entities of the pemphigus group include pemphigus Vulgaris, pemphigus foliaceous, immunoglobulin A (IgA) pemphigus, and paraneoplastic pemphigus.
  • P. Vulgaris is the most common type and has a worldwide distribution. It is most common in middle-aged adults and rare in children.
  • The age of presentation is younger in Indians compared to the West.

Option B: Pemphigus vegetans

  • It is a benign variant of P. Vulgaris (rare disease).
  • It has two forms: Neumann and Hallopeau.
  • It involves intertriginous areas and flexural surfaces.
  • It is less common than pemphigus Vulgaris.

Option C: Pemphigus foliaceus

  • It is a less common, flaccid subcorneal lesion with crusting and scaling on erosion over seborrheic areas.

Option D: Pemphigus erythematosus

  • It is a variant of P. foliaceous with overlap with lupus erythematosus.
  • It is a less common type of pemphigus than Vulgaris.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female visits the clinic complaining of a lesion on the upper lip. The intra-oral exam shows a pinkish nodule with irregular edges, a flat surface, and soft consistency. Histopathological examination of the lesion shows solitary rounded, amorphous, eosinophilic masses of basement membrane material at the dermo-epidermal junction. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Spitz nevus

This patient with a pinkish nodule having irregular edges, flat surface, soft consistency, and histo-pathological studies of the lesion showing Kamino bodies, solitary rounded, amorphous, eosinophilic masses of basement membrane material at the dermo-epidermal junction, most likely suffers from a Spitz nevus.

  • Kamino bodies are the eosinophilic globules seen in Spitz nevus
  • It is a benign melanocytic nevus
  • KBs histopathologically are solitarily rounded or confluent, amorphous, eosinophilic masses of basement membrane material found at the dermo-epidermal junction, most commonly at the tips of dermal papillae.

Option A: Lichen planus

  • Lichen planus and Lichenoid tissue reaction show interface dermatitis - basal cell vacuolization, apoptotic keratinocytes (Civatte bodies), and obscuring of the dermo-epidermal junction by inflammatory cells.

Option B: Hailey-Hailey Disease

  • It is characterized by supra-basilar and intraepidermal clefting, acantholysis of keratinocytes resembling dilapidated brick wall, epidermal hyperplasia, and immunofluorescence negative.

Option C: Lichenoid tissue reaction

  • Lichen planus and Lichenoid tissue reaction show interface dermatitis - basal cell vacuolization, apoptotic keratinocytes (Civatte bodies), and obscuring of the dermo-epidermal junction by inflammatory cells.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old male presents in the clinic with the complaint of rash for the past 3 days. Examination reveals numerous hypopigmented, macular, scaly lesions over the trunk, as shown in the picture.



Which of the following statements is most likely true regarding this rash?

choices.text: Selenium sulfide is used for the treatment
Wood's lamp examination shows branching septate hyphae
The causative organism also causes vulvovaginitis

questions.solution:
Option B: Selenium sulfide is used for the treatment

  • Selenium sulfide is used for the treatment of pityriasis versicolor.

Pityriasis versicolor:

  • Pityriasis Versicolor is characterized by the development of spreading, hypopigmented, scaly macular lesions most commonly involving the trunk region. Malassezia spp. is the causative organism, which is a yeast-like fungus. The infection remains confined to the stratum corneum.
  • Risk factors affect hot and humid weather.
  • Microscopic examination of the lesions’ scrapings reveals round yeasts with filaments, also referred to as ‘spaghetti and meat-ball’ appearance.
  • Treatment includes topical application of selenium sulfide and/or administration of systemic antifungal agents in resistant cases.

Option A: Trichophyton is the infecting organism

  • Trichophyton belongs to the class of dermatophyte fungi, which are commonly implicated in the development of tinea infections (tinea capitis, tinea corporis, tinea cruris, tinea pedis, etc.).

Option C: Wood's lamp examination shows branching septate hyphae

  • Branching septate hyphae are associated with dermatophyte infection.

Option D: The causative organism also causes vulvovaginitis

  • Vulvovaginitis is caused by Candida albicans which belong to the class of dimorphic fungi.
  • Candida albicans is also associated with the development of oral and esophageal thrush and candidemia in immunocompromised patients

questions.text:
A 15-years-old boy is brought to the hospital with the complaint of a skin lesion on his left leg. Examination shows asymmetric skin lesions characterized by erythematous plaques with elevated external borders and a hypochromic center. There is sensory loss over the lesion. Several satellite lesions are seen. A photograph of the lesion is given below:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Borderline Tuberculoid Leprosy

  • The image shows asymmetric skin lesions characterized by erythematous plaques with elevated external borders and a hypochromic center surrounded by satellite lesions. Satellite papules are characteristic of Borderline Tuberculoid (BT)
  Tuberculoid Borderline tuberculoid Mid Borderline Borderline Lepromatous
Number of skin lesions Single or up to 3 Multiple (3 to 10) Multiple (10-20) Multiple (>30)
Size in diameter >10cm Variable in size Variable in size  2-3 cm
Surface and Character Well-defined, hypopigmented plaque with dry, hairless, and usually scaly surface and moderately raised granular margins A distinct, erythematous hypochromic lesion with a dry surface and raised well-defined margins with satellite lesions Variable shaped and sized asymmetric papule, plaque, circinate lesions, and nodule Irregular, erythematous, infiltrated bands around anaesthetic central "immune" area; inner margins of lesion are better defined than the outer margins, i.e., punched out "Swiss cheese appearance." Irregularly shaped erythematous, slightly infiltrated patches with an area of apparently normal skin in between the shiny copper-coloured surface
Anaesthesia Completely anaesthetic surface Anaesthetic (less intense than tuberculoid type) Slightly diminished Slightly diminished
AFB Negative Scanty bacilli in lesions High density Plenty

Option A:  Tuberculoid Leprosy

Tuberculoid leprosy-

  • Well-defined, hypopigmented plaque with dry, hairless, and usually scaly surface and moderately raised granular margins.
  • Completely anaesthetic surface.
  • Satellite papules are not seen.

Option C: Mid-Borderline Leprosy

Mid-border leprosy-

  • Multiple (10-20) skin lesions and variable in size and shape.
  • Asymmetric papule, plaque, and circinate lesions.
  • Nodules are irregular, erythematous, infiltrated bands around a large, slightly anaesthetic central "immune" area.
  • Punched-out outer margins resemble a "Swiss cheese appearance."
  • Satellite papules are not seen.

Option D: Borderline Lepromatous leprosy

Borderline Lepromatous leprosy-

  • Multiple (>30) skin lesions a-3 cm in size
  • Irregularly shaped erythematous, slightly infiltrated patches with an area of apparently normal skin in between shiny, copper-coloured surfaces.
  • Slightly diminished sensation.
  • Satellite papules are not seen.
